Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Defendants' counterclaims against limited liability company's (LLC) agent and corporation for open account, promissory estoppel, quantum meruit, and unjust enrichment under Utah law, which arose from dispute over shared ownership of aircraft and were premised on alter ego liability, were not barred by statute of frauds and parol evidence rule; equitable theory of alter ego was conceptually unrelated from party's promise to answer for debt of another, whether court could, in its inherent power, fashion appropriate remedy for legal wrongs by disregarding corporate form was unrelated to regulation of private parties' promises to one another, and counterclaims were not premised on existence of any guaranty agreement. Utah Code Ann. § 25-5-4(1)(a).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Estate of Ewers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: There was no evidence that mining company was alter ego of owner of interest in company, even though there was some evidence that owner used company funds improperly by transferring money from company's checking account into an account owner used for both personal and business expenses; owner was not sole owner, and transfers were unauthorized.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Investors' claims against LLC owner's estate for fraud and unjust enrichment were not barred by applicable statutes of limitations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Boobuli's LLC v. State Farm General Insurance Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, insurer's parent corporation could not be held liable on alter ego theory in insured's suit alleging that insurer failed to properly adjust premiums for its business risk policies despite unavoidable decrease in insured's business operations due to COVID pandemic, absent evidence that insurer was inadequately capitalized and failure to disregard separate identities corporate would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Premiums. Challenge under Unfair Competition Law to lack of premium adjustment during COVID-19 pandemic was within jurisdiction of insurance department.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Lentner v. Upstate Forestry and Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of timber company's corporate veil to hold company's owner personally liable was not warranted, in action arising out of timber sale contract between company and property owner for breach of contract, fraud, violation of statute prohibiting unauthorized cutting of timber, conversion, and unjust enrichment, where company owner was acting on behalf of company at all relevant times, and did not engage in acts amounting to abuse or perversion of corporate form warranting piercing of veil. N.Y. RPAPL § 861.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of timber company's corporate veil to hold company's owner personally liable for breach of contract and other claims was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Estate of Ewers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: There was no evidence that mining company was alter ego of owner of interest in company, even though there was some evidence that owner used company funds improperly by transferring money from company's checking account into an account owner used for both personal and business expenses; owner was not sole owner, and transfers were unauthorized.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Investors' claims against LLC owner's estate for fraud and unjust enrichment were not barred by applicable statutes of limitations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Michigan GeoSearch, Inc. v. TC Energy Corporation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was not warranted under Michigan law to allow owner of natural gas well to seek recovery from parent company of owner of natural gas storage field, in well owner's action against parent company based on allegations that natural gas was migrating from field to well; parent company never owned or operated field, field owner never granted parent company storage rights, state and federal agencies recognized and issued permits to field owner as owner and operator of field, statements on companies' websites about companies' relationship were consistent with parent-subsidiary relationship, and alleged fraudulent and wrongful conduct of field owner related only to field owner's own actions, rather than parent company's use of field owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted under Michigan law to allow owner of natural gas well to seek recovery from parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute "pervasive control" in support of piercing corporate veil, and, thus, homeowners could not maintain their claims against contractor in his individual capacity for breach of contract, fraudulent misrepresentation, conversion, and breach of implied warranty of good workmanship, arising from renovations that homeowners hired contractor to perform at their residence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyds v. CSX Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, insurer for shipper of locomotives demonstrated a unity of ownership and interest between first railroad company, which was headquartered in Kentucky, and second railroad company, which operated railroads in Illinois, as required to pierce the corporate veil to confer personal jurisdiction over first company, in action for damages associated with train derailment; companies shared directors and officers, and companies entered management agreement, whereby second company's customer could use first company's internet booking service.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Railroad company did not provide a service through its railway booking website, as required for liability under the Interstate Commerce Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyds v. CSX Transportation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, insurer for shipper of locomotives failed to demonstrate that the adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence of first railroad company, which was headquartered in Kentucky, and second railroad company, which operated railroads in Illinois, would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce the corporate veil to confer personal jurisdiction over first company, in action for damages associated with train derailment; first company's presence in the action was not required to prevent an unjust outcome, as there was no evidence that second company was anything other than an adequately capitalized corporation, suggesting that insurer could recover against second company.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Railroad company did not provide a service through its railway booking website, as required for liability under the Interstate Commerce Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Sacred Heart Health Services v. MMIC Insurance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: Allegations by insured health system and surgery center that involvement of liability insurer's parent company in insurer's purported deceit and bad-faith conduct in process of settling underlying tort actions against insureds rendered it inequitable or unjust to adhere to fiction of corporate separateness were sufficient to state claim for breaching of corporate veil under South Dakota law, where insureds alleged that parent company's chief legal officer made unconditional offer for insurer to contribute $2 million to global settlement of underlying actions, that insurer, through such officer, suppressed the fact that insurer had no intention to perform on such promise, and that insurer failed to disclose that contribution would be contingent on waiver of bad-faith claims against insurer. S.D. Codified Laws § 20-10-2(4).
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Liability insurer's alleged defense under reservation of rights agreement could permit insureds to bind insurer to reasonable settlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Disciplinary Counsel v. Nordic Title Agency, Inc., and Hall
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish president of company engaged in the unauthorized practice of law, and thus disciplinary counsel could not pierce the corporate veil and hold president responsible for the acts of company's employees in preparing and filing deeds to real property that were not reviewed by an attorney; president did not prepare any of the deeds or affidavits at issue, and company's policy was that all deeds and legal instruments had to be reviewed by an attorney.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Unauthorized Practice. Civil penalty of $10,000 was warranted for title company's unauthorized practice of law by preparing and recording deeds to transfer title to real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator adequately alleged that Singapore company was alter ego of Dubai company sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of Singapore company in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; though operator did not allege fraud, operator alleged overlap in both leadership and ownership of companies, same individual acted as legal advisor to both companies and communicated on behalf of both companies from same email address, sole shareholder of Singapore company was manager of Dubai company, both companies conducted the same type of business and sold same type of products under same terms and conditions, and companies shared the same internet domain name.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Jurisdiction. Maritime vessel operator made prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction over Dubai company and Singapore company sufficient to defeat motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hanamura-Valashinas v. Transitions by Firenza, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: Managing partner and part-owner of construction company did not exercise control so complete over company that it had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and therefore corporate form of company could not be disregarded and managing partner and part-owner, as shareholders, could not be held liable for wrongs committed by company. (Per Lynch, J., with two judges concurring in judgment only.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Allegation by homeowners that managing partner falsified invoices before presenting them violated duty independent of construction agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Saks Management and Associates, LLC v. Sung General Contracting, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that construction contractor's business account was used to pay contractor's owner's personal credit-card bills and personal expenses and that owner transferred money between his personal and various business bank accounts was insufficient to warrant piercing contractor's corporate veil, absent evidence showing that the expenses were not legitimate business expenses or authorized by the corporation as part of owner's compensation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Industry Regulation. Repair rule exemption to ban on unlicensed contractors from enforcing construction contracts did not allow contractor to enforce contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Carter v. City of Montgomery
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Probation services company was not the alter ego of its principal company, as would establish successor liability for principal company by piercing the corporate veil based on excessive control in probationer's § 1983 against city and probation company, who entered into contract with city to supervise misdemeanor probation for those on municipal court-ordered probation, alleging violations of due process, equal protection, and the Fourth, Sixth, and Eighth Amendments for their involvement in municipal court's systemic practice of jailing traffic offenders for failing to pay fines without inquiring into their ability to pay; the record lacked evidence that principal company misused whatever control it had over probation company. U.S. Const. Amends. 4, 6, 8, 14; 42 U.S.C.A. § 1983.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS  Due Process. Issue of fact existed whether city knew and was deliberately indifferent to company requesting probation revocation despite no willful failure to pay fines.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate alter ego doctrine did not permit minority shareholders to assert that corporation and limited partnerships of which corporation was majority limited partner were effectively same entity for purposes of treating partnerships' acquisition of corporation's shares as corporation's reacquisition of its own shares; purpose of corporate alter ego theory was to prevent a company from using an interrelated company to escape liability, not to determine whether company effectively reacquired its shares such that shares should have been considered nonvoting. Ind. Code Ann. § 23-1-27-2(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court cited correct law regarding identity theory for piercing corporate veil, found facts in support of theory, and examined issue of owner's control of corporation in addition to other factors when making its determination that corporate veil of real estate development entities should be pierced, and thus, court did not improperly apply identity theory, in action by architectural firm against real estate development entities and their owners alleging breach of contract, quantum meruit, and unjust enrichment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court's factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entities, in action by architectural firm against owners of entities; trial court found that specific corporations were locus of power through which owners maintained virtually unchecked power and control of cluster of corporations, owners viewed lack of clarity in organizational structure as virtue, all entities were located in one office and shared office supplies, entities were stacked to provide layers of protection to owners, and owners were paid first without notice to legitimate creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: ETC Texas Pipeline, Ltd. v. Addison Exploration & Development, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Evidence that pipeline companies were subsidiaries of energy company, that they had common officers, and that energy company controlled pipeline companies did not establish energy company was vicariously liable for pipeline companies absent any evidence of abuse, injustice, or inequity that would support holding energy company liable for conduct of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Energy company and subsidiary pipeline companies did not owe duty to development company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Union Telecom, LLC v. United States
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Telecommunications carrier did not exercise complete domination of corporation which resold carrier's prepaid long-distance telephone cards, and thus reseller was not alter ego of carrier; although carrier owned 51% of reseller and had right to appoint most of reseller's senior leadership, including its president, chief financial officer (CFO), and chief operating officer (COO), in practice individual who owned remaining 49% controlled reseller, managing day-to-day operations, making all final decisions, and excluding carrier-appointed leadership from meetings, and carrier and reseller otherwise filed separate tax returns, maintained own records, handled own accounts payable and receivable, occupied separate offices, maintained own bank accounts, and prepared own financial statements.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Excise. Presumption that telecommunications carrier included excise tax in prepaid phone cards' price paid by first non-carrier to buy cards was rebutted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Mulugeta v. Ademachew
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Former boyfriend failed to establish that former girlfriend used her company to disguise some legal wrong, as required to establish an alter ego liability claim.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Former boyfriend failed to prove Ethiopian court judgments, which found no valid contract existed, were worthy of being afforded comity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality rule provided basis for judgment creditor's outsider reverse veil piercing of corporation owned solely by judgment debtor's wife; judgment debtor admitted that corporation "never actually did much" and that it was "superseded" by other companies shortly after being formed, he admitted that his wife and their children were able to write personal checks from their individualized accounts with corporation in order to extract allowances from it, and trial court found that the corporation was a vehicle for financial "hide the pea" exercises.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Prejudice to innocent equity holders or creditors did not weigh against allowing judgment creditor's outsider reverse veil piercing of three limited liability companies (LLC) and one corporation; one LLC's creditors appeared to be secured creditors, and while judgment debtor's wife was an equity holder in the entities, she received her ownership interests for no consideration and she gave judgment debtor full and effectively sole authority to make decisions for the entities and gave affirmative authorization to judgment debtor's conduct in his attempt to avoid his creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Sabre GLBL, Inc v. Shan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, doctrine of corporate separateness, pursuant to which individual could incorporate business and shield himself from personal liability for corporation's obligations, did not apply to shield former employee from personal liability for her own misappropriation of employer's clients, staff, and confidential information and trade secrets and breach of fiduciary duty by starting competing business while still working for employer; employee's misconduct not only benefited her competing business by giving it two-year development and operations head start but also benefited employee personally by increasing value of her ownership interest in business, and therefore, there was no need to pierce company's corporate veil to require employee to disgorge value she personally received as result of her misconduct.
Document Preview: TORTS  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitrator did not manifestly disregard Texas law governing award of head start disgorgement damages, as basis for vacatur of arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Innerimages, Inc. v. Newman
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, AT KNOXVILLE.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was appropriate and gated-community developer's president was personally liable for damages incurred by developer in action by homeowners for breach of fiduciary duty, where president was sole shareholder of developer, developer issued no stock certificates, developer's office was president's home, and developer and president shared same attorneys and hired same employees to perform lawn care and maintenance services.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Homeowners Associations. Developer of gated community breached fiduciary duty to homeowners and was required to create homeowner's association and relinquish property control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Doller v. Prescott
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Financial and investment advisor's claims that foreign corporation served as his client's alter ego were merely a means to hold the corporation responsible for client's conduct and, thus, did not provide a basis to hold corporation liable for any of the conduct alleged against it.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Alleged agreement that financial advisor would be given right of first refusal to acquire equity in client's company was not enforceable contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Riley v. Barringer
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Virginia, Abingdon Division.
Headnote: Former employee did not allege facts sufficient for district court to infer that the separate personalities of employer and its sole shareholder no longer existed or that employer was shareholder's alter ego, as required, under Virginia law, to state claims, including unjust enrichment and fraud, against shareholder personally, arising from, inter alia, employer's alleged failure to reimburse funds that employee purportedly deposited in employer's bank account from her own retirement account and personal funds; allegations did not suggest that shareholder personally guaranteed the alleged loan that employee made, allegations did not suggest shareholder personally benefited from loan, there was no evidence shareholder treated employer's funds as his own, and employee's remaining causes of action only mentioned shareholder's name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Former employee did not allege facts sufficient for district court to infer, under Virginia law, that employer was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Williams v. National Gallery , London
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Entity had no liability as alter ego of British national museum, in action by legal heirs of former owner of painting by Henri Matisse who sought to recover painting from museum, which had acquired painting after it was allegedly sold without owner's authorization when she departed from Ally-occupied Berlin in aftermath of World War II; entity had not even allegedly been used by museum to harm heirs.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Foreign Sovereigns. Painting was not taken by British national museum as would permit action against museum to recover painting under expropriation exception to FSIA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: City of Cleveland v. Embassy Realty Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: President of corporation had such a level of control over corporation which owned property on which building was demolished that corporation was indistinguishable from or alter ego of president and, thus, city could recover its costs for demolition of building from president; corporation was undercapitalized in that president put his own money into the property and received personal loan for improvements to the property prior to transferring the property to corporation, only corporate formality observed was filing of articles of incorporation, corporation kept minimal corporate records and had no separate bank account, and third-party lease payments to maintain a billboard on property continued to be paid to president personally after corporation purchased the property from president.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Issue of whether president held control over corporation to unlawfully maintain nuisance on its property precluded summary judgment in action for demolition costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Ancillary administrator for estate of original and allegedly rightful owner of painting that was taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris sufficiently alleged that art dealership was alter ego of dealership owner, such that trial court could pierce the corporate veil and exercise personal jurisdiction over owner, in administrator's replevin action seeking return of painting, where administrator alleged that owner held all stock in dealership, that dealership failed to adhere to corporate formalities such as keeping regular books and records, failed to generate income, and failed to have an independent board of directors, and that dealership was underfunded, such that administrator would be unable to recover reasonable costs if successful on claim. N.Y. CPLR §§ 302(a)(1), 302(a)(2).
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Replevin. New York was not inconvenient forum for replevin action seeking return of painting taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Ancillary administrator for estate of original owner of painting that was taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris sufficiently stated claims for conversion and replevin against owner of art dealership, art gallery owner, and art gallery; despite fact that dealership held title to painting, administrator asserted claims under theory of alter ego liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Replevin. New York was not inconvenient forum for replevin action seeking return of painting taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: American Federated Title Corporation v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporation's ultimate lack of success in bringing litigation did not establish or even suggest that corporation was a "dummy entity," and thus pierce of corporate veil was not warranted on that ground.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Extraordinary remedy of piercing corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Burkhead v. Stewart Title Guaranty Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced in civil action brought by investors against individual owners of real estate developer, even if it was a one man corporation, given absence of evidence that corporation was undercapitalized at time it was incorporated as well as contracts making clear that investors entered into agreements with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced to render individual owners of real estate developer liable for alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Morello v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: The principle that an individual can incorporate a business and thereby shield himself from personal liability is subject to exceptions in circumstances in which maintaining the corporate shield would result in injustice and inequity, including situations involving fraud, evasions of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and other similar behavior.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Owner of limited liability company could not be held personally liable for violations of environmental rules absent allegations of fraud or tortious conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hawes v. Kabani & Company, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington.
Headnote: Claim that managing principal of an auditing corporation participated in the audit of a Washington company, and that principal approved the use of the audit in the company's securities filings, sufficiently alleged that principal participated in an audit challenged as factually inaccurate, as required to pierce the corporate veil and state claims of negligent and intentional misrepresentation, violation of Washington state securities laws, and unjust enrichment against principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation purposefully directed its activities toward forum state, as required for specific personal jurisdiction, by auditing company in forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, individual who was officer, director and majority owner of Chapter 7 debtor's parent company had control and complete domination of company in both its finances and business practices, warranting piercing the corporate veil under instrumentality rule, where company was inadequately capitalized and had a number of months in which it was either completely insolvent or had extremely thin capitalization, there was a non-compliance with corporate formalities, including failure to file an annual report with the North Carolina Secretary of State's office for certain year and failure to maintain a current/active registered agent, and checks had been issued to individual to pay personal utility bill, student loan, and personal cable bill.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's parent company and its majority owner were liable for unjust enrichment for retaining security deposit rightfully payable to debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission v. Trade Exchange Network Limited
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Two Irish companies, one of which was transferee of transferor's non-sports prediction markets and technology-related intellectual property pursuant to transferor's deconsolidation, operated as common enterprise, and thus, after the transfer, transferor company still had customers, so that transferor company, based transferee company's offering of prediction-related binary options to United States customers through websites, violated consent order between transferor and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC); companies had same directors and officers, they shared office space, and they commingled funds, with transferor maintaining bank accounts that accepted funds from United States customers. Commodity Exchange Act § 6c, 7 U.S.C.A. § 13a-1.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Commodity Futures. Prediction-related contracts were binary options that were subject to regulation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Northwest Cascade, Inc. v. Unique Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil, thereby allowing contractor that obtained judgment against corporation to seek recovery from shareholders, did not entitle shareholders to claim a homestead exemption in property, which was owned by the corporation and on which the shareholders were living; allowing shareholders to have a homestead exemption would not have served the purpose of adjusting allocation of loss between creditor and persons who misused the corporate form, nor would it have rectified an abuse of the corporate privilege. West's RCWA 6.13.040(1).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Homestead. Shareholders did not have legal or equitable interest in corporation's property that would allow them to claim homestead exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Queens West Development Corp. v. Nixbot Realty Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In condemnation proceeding, petitioner failed to show that claimants abused corporate form, as required to pierce corporate veil with respect to their company that operated tennis club on subject property and their property management company, or that property should be treated as owner-occupied under alter-ego theory, and thus awarding club just compensation for taking of trade fixtures was warranted, separate from award to claimants for taking of fee; even though claimants' deposition indicated failure to adhere to some corporate formalities, there was no indication that either company was undercapitalized, that they commingled assets, or that claimants appropriated funds of either for personal use, both companies were formed at separate times and for separate, legitimate purposes, and bona fide lease existed between companies. McKinney's EDPL § 304(H).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. In condemnation proceeding, just compensation for taking trade fixtures was warranted, separate from award for taking of fee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: American Federated Title Corp. v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Claims that shareholders paid security deposits on behalf of three corporations from their own funds without a loan agreement or other formal documentation, that various transfers among the corporations and other business entities were not made in writing, and that the shareholders were entirely responsible for the corporation's administrative services, accounting, book-keeping, record-keeping, payroll, and staffing, sufficiently alleged that three corporations were dominated and controlled by their shareholders, as required to support a veil-piercing claim under New York law. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 5225(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment-creditor sufficiently alleged that three corporations were dominated and controlled by shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Bank of New York v. Yugoimport
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In dispute over ownership of funds in deposit account opened by former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's (SFRY) Federal Directorate of Supply and Management (FDSP), pursuant to interpretive rules set forth in Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, alter-ego analysis neither applied to determination of whether FDSP was SFRY "agency" within meaning of agreement that required SFRY agencies to distribute funds to SFRY successor states, nor overcame presumption of independence afforded to foreign sovereign; FDSP's assumedly corporate form did not shield it from succession agreement, no third-party sought redress, and alter-ego analysis was relied upon solely to shield instrumentality from foreign state that owned it. Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, Art. 31, 1155 U.N.T.S. 331.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Treaties and Conventions. Former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's Federal Directorate of Supply and Management had to distribute funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: OOO v. Empire United Lines Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporation was not alter ego of its sole shareholder, even though corporation did not have board of directors or, apparently, company treasurer or secretary, where corporation did not conduct shareholder's business, as opposed to its own, and there was no intermingling of personal and corporate funds, failure to maintain adequate records, or conducting of business by corporation for shareholder's personal benefit.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Shipping. COGSA limited common carrier's liability to $500 for each of two vehicles stolen after being delivered for shipment overseas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: First Express Services Group, Inc. v. Easter
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Fact that corporate owner personally owned more money when his business earned more money due to conduct of employee who breached contract with her former employer was not sufficient to impose personal liability on corporate owner for unjust enrichment.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Trade Secrets. Crop insurance agency's customer list was not a trade secret.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Taylor v. Bettis
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, piercing the corporate veil was not warranted, pursuant to the instrumentality rule, in consumers' action against attorneys with law firm that represented alleged operators of debt elimination and credit repair scheme, absent any evidence that attorneys abused law firm's corporate form.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Colorado River abstention was not warranted when allegedly parallel state court actions had concluded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Special security agreement (SSA) between American subsidiary of English security contractor and subagency of Department of Defense (DOD), which provided that subsidiary was "required to manage its own affairs to mitigate the risk of foreign ownership, control and influence," precluded contractor from exercising requisite control over subsidiary to establish agency relationship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: TemPay, Inc. v. Biltres Staffing of Tampa Bay, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is not necessary to hold an individual officer liable under the Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA); however, the aggrieved party must show that the individual was a direct participant in the improper dealings. West's F.S.A. § 501.204(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. A fact issue existed as to whether manager of staffing agency engaged in deceptive practices or breached duties as a manager.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, there was no connection between the alleged misuse of the corporate form by the parent corporation of a children's furniture manufacturer and the harm allegedly suffered by a wood sub-assembly provider, as required for the court to use the alter ego doctrine to pierce the corporate veil of the parent corporation in order to allow its principals to be liable.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: NTD Architects v. Baker
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: While, under California law, a partnership generally ceases to exist once business is incorporated, when evidence shows that corporation is mere agency for purpose of convenience in carrying out partnership or joint venture agreement, then fiduciary duties may be owed between parties in accordance with general partnership law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Plausible claim was stated to hold officers and directors personally liable for participating in alleged unfair practices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: D'Mel & Associates v. Athco, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Sole shareholder of transferee corporation did not benefit from conveyance of unfilled orders from debtor, or from his conveyance of his shares for no consideration, as required him to be liable for fraudulent conveyance on veil piercing theory.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Corporate officers were not liable for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: D'Mel & Associates v. Athco, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Chief executive officer (CEO) did not benefit from sole shareholder's sale of his shares for no consideration, as required for CEO to be liable for fraudulent conveyance on veil piercing theory.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Corporate officers were not liable for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Burke v. Ability Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, where the alter ego doctrine applies to allow piercing of the corporate veil, the two affiliated corporations are treated as one for purposes of determining liability for breach of contract or breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations supported piercing corporate veil, as would establish personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Mazzola v. Roomster Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations that online roommate matching service was inadequately capitalized and staffed corporation, that it lacked a registered agent for service of process, that it lacked a physical address, that it had an unusually high chargeback rate, that the corporation and its owners had such a unity of interest that they were indistinguishable, and that service was sham corporation used to run a fraud against the public stated claim for alter ego liability against individual owners, under New York law.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Contracts. Allegations against online roommate matching service stated claim for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Newcrete Products v. City of Wilkes-Barre
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Statutory provision that barred a city and an authority from being instrumentalities of one another did not restrict the trial court's equitable authority to pierce the corporate veil, where the city and the authority could have been operating independently from one another. 35 P.S. § 1704(a).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. City could not be liable for redevelopment authority's debts under a theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, booking agency's legal personality was adequately separated from identity of its owner, and thus piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, where corporation had issued stocks, held regular board and shareholder meetings, kept separate bank accounts, made separate corporate tax filings, paid dividends and salaries, and kept a minutes book.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Musical booking agency had separate identity from its owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chevron Corp. v. Salazar
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In action seeking declaration that multi-billion dollar Ecuadorian judgment against United States oil corporation was not entitled to recognition or enforcement outside Ecuador, oil corporation was not bound by legal consequences of statements made in prior environmental litigation by company that later merged with subsidiary of corporation, even if corporation owned all of company's common stock following merger, since company remained legal entity separate and distinct from corporation at all relevant times, and disregarding company's separate corporate existence was not warranted.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Judicial Estoppel. Judicial estoppel did not apply to prevent oil corporation from making due process arguments in seeking nonrecognition of foreign judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Nuevo El Barrio Rehabilitacion De Vivienda y Economia, Inc. v. Moreight Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no reason to pierce company's corporate veil where there was no evidence that sole shareholder exercised complete domination of company in respect to the transaction attacked or that sole shareholder, through its domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against plaintiff such that a court in equity should intervene.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Sale of stock of general partner did not constitute a sale of the project triggering general partnership's right of first refusal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: ABN AMRO Bank, N.V. v. MBIA Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Insureds' allegations that financial guarantee insurer abused its control of its wholly-owned subsidiary by causing it to engage in harmful transactions that shielded billions of dollars in assets from policyholders and exposed them to significant liability were sufficient to state claim for abuse of the corporate form that could support a declaration piercing insurer's corporate veil.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Industry Regulation. Administrative approval of insurer's restructuring did not bar challenge to restructuring as fraudulent transaction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Johnson v. Ross
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent evidence warranting piercing the corporate veil, West Virginia law precluded licensors from recovering, on a theory of unjust enrichment, from corporate licensee's controlling shareholder the benefit shareholder received by virtue of the increased value of licensee's stock due to technical assistance provided by licensors; assuming that licensors' technical assistance was valuable, that value was realized by corporate licensee, the company undertaking to improve licensor's technology, rather than by shareholder individually, and the value of the confidential technology disclosed to licensee's employees could not be said to have been conferred on shareholder, and thus he was not the unjust recipient of the value of that technology.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Assignments and Licensing. Corporate licensee's controlling shareholder was not unjustly enriched by licensor's disclosure to confidential technology to licensee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Kromrey v. Ali
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: District court abused its discretion in holding nonshareholder personally liable for corporation's debts when the corporate veil was pierced. Although nonshareholder held himself out as owners of the property that was owned by the partnership, he owned no ownership or management interest in the limited partnership or the entity that was the general partner of the limited partnership. Instead, nonshareholder helped his brother, who did have an interest in the limited partnership, in a supporting role without a direct relationship to the property, general partner, or the limited partnership. Minn.Stat. § 302A.425 (2010).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court abused its discretion in holding nonshareholder personally liable for corporation's debts when the corporate veil was pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Yellowstone Mountain Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Individual's holding company was his alter ego under Montana law where, during the time that individual was the controlling shareholder of the company, he dominated and controlled the affairs of the company to such an extent that it had no separate corporate identity apart from him, the only real distinction between the two was corporate structure, individual was company's sole owner and had sole control of its affairs, corporate formalities were not followed, and individual held himself out as owner of certain entities when in fact they were owned by company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Co-founder's prepetition removal of $209 million from debtors was a distribution, not a loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: 17315 Collins Ave., LLC v. Fortune Development Sales Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Parent company and subsidiary operated as alter egos as was required to pierce the corporate veil; the actual owner, developer, and operating entity for condominium development was subsidiary and parent owned the membership interests of subsidiary and was the managing member, but did not conduct any operations, have any employees or payroll, or have any bank accounts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent company used subsidiary for an improper purpose as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gunther v. Capital One, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Law of Virginia, where federally chartered consumer bank was headquartered, applied to determination of whether bank's corporate veil could be pierced to expose parent company to indirect liability for bank's alleged improper charging of fees.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Accounts. Checking account holder's account agreement with bank did not incorporate TISA requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: International Millennium Consultants, Inc. v. Taycom Business Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporation's veil would be pierced and judgment entered against an owner's new company; the owner's failure to inject any capital into the company more than a year after its founding, the fact that it did not have a bank account, and the fact that it had not engaged in ordinary business transactions, were all factors that militated very strongly in favor of piercing the corporation's veil, and of equal importance was the fact that the company was created by the owner while the instant litigation was pending.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Company's corporate veil would be pierced on the ground that it was a mere instrumentality of its individual owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Allegations were sufficient under Louisiana law to allow the court to draw the reasonable inference that, if true, affiliate company would be liable for demolition company's alleged misconduct under a single business enterprise (SBE) theory of liability; demolition company and affiliate used the same office space and shared resources, including servers, fax machines, and e-mail accounts, affiliate's president controlled financial operations of both affiliate and demolition company, finances of demolition company and affiliate were intermingled, and affiliate did not observe corporate formalities that might indicate its separateness, including the issuance of stock, annual shareholder meetings, formal board meetings, and corporate authorization for major transactions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Bank of America, N.A. v. Prestige Imports
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Car dealership's owner was not entitled to personally recover for bank's wrongful debit, where car dealership, rather than car dealership's owner, was the "customer" whose account was debited. M.G.L.A. c. 106, § 4–401.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Accounts. Damages on wrongful debit claims were limited to the amount of the wrongful debit, and did not include consequential damages, absent bad faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of employee, meeting that prong of three prong test for piercing of the corporate veil; employee used the corporate form to transact his own personal business, treated corporate funds as though they were his own, and decided what to pay to himself and to creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: District court may not make up for a lack of evidence to warrant piercing of corporate veil by assigning only contingent liability to an otherwise blameless defendant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gregorie v. Alpine Meadows Ski Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Parent company, who approved major projects over subsidiary, did not exert the degree of control necessary to reasonably deem the subsidiary an agent of the parent, thus parent company was not liable for acts or omissions of the subsidiary. The parent company reviewed and approved the subsidiary's budget, expenses, master plan and was involved in major decision making. There was no evidence presented of the parent company's day-to-day control of the subsidiary. It was undisputed that the parent and subsidiary maintained separate workforce and human resource departments and that they had separate payroll records, tax identification numbers, disbursement records, and issued separate tax forms to employees and contractors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company, who approved subsidiary's major projects, did not exert degree of control necessary to reasonably deem them an agent of the parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: PRA III, LLC v. Capital One, N.A.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: A bank was not required to turn over funds in a corporation's account because the turnover order issued to it did not indicate judicial recognition that the corporation was liable for the debts of the judgment debtor. The creditor received a judgment against an individual. It soon found out that the individual was using a bank account of a corporation to pay personal expenses. It attempted to access the money through levy, and two turnover orders, neither of which actually stated the specific account. N.J.S.A. 2A:17-63.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Bank was not required to turn over funds in corporation's account because turnover order did not indicate judicial recognition that corporation was liable for debts of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation under California law, on basis that corporations had same office location and telephone number, similar shareholders and directors, same person was president of both corporations, and older corporation paid royalties due under younger corporation's written licensing agreements and it created catalog and brochures to sell licensed products showing it as vendor and warrantor, since corporations maintained separate bank accounts and separate books and records, younger corporation had not been inadequately capitalized, and older corporation did not hold itself out as liable for debts of younger corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Lincoln General Ins. Co. v. U.S. Auto Ins. Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Movant company's motion to dismiss the claims against various corporations, to the extent that liability was based on the single business enterprise doctrine, was granted. Movant company had argued that the single business enterprise doctrine allowed veil-piercing in the case. However, the state's supreme court issued an opinion, after the parties had filed their briefing on the motion, indicating that single business enterprise was not a viable theory for piercing the corporate veil for the purpose of imposing liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Movant company's motion to dismiss the claims against various corporations, to the extent that liability was based on the single business enterprise doctrine, was granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Corporation's sole shareholder exercised complete dominion over corporation's finances, policies, and practices, such that unity of interest and ownership existed between shareholder and corporation causing corporation's independence to cease and making it mere conduit for shareholder's fraudulent scheme, satisfying identity rule under Connecticut law for purposes of reverse veil piercing claim against corporation; shareholder controlled all investment decisions relating to corporation's pooled investment fund, commingled investors' funds with his personal funds and funds of his other business entities, withdrew corporation's funds to make loan to his former wife and used majority of funds repaid by former wife to satisfy family court judgment against him, and caused corporation to make material misrepresentations and omissions concerning value of investment fund's assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Sunnyside Timber, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Florida law, trust's actions in enforcing its rights under a state-court order did not, without more, rise to the level of fraudulent conduct or a "illegal purpose" as required to pierce the corporate veil under Florida law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Rule 60 did not limit the time period for debtors' §363(n) damages claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Cunningham v. Advanta Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: A litigant's claims against a corporation for a subsidiary's alleged attempts to contact him through his cellular phone to collect a debt were dismissed because he did not sue the proper party. The subsidiary allegedly called the litigant on his phone five times to collect a debt from another individual. However, the litigant did not establish that the corporation's actions warranted piercing the corporate veil in order to hold it responsible for the subsidiary's actions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was not liable for subsidiary's alleged illegal phone calls to litigant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Doe v. Exxon Mobil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Oil corporation's Indonesian subsidiary acted as agent for corporation with regard to hiring Indonesian military security force to protect oil field, where corporation exerted significant control over subsidiary's security by outlining critical tasks for subsidiary to complete in order to ensure security, and subsidiary did not implement security procedures without significant guidance and participation from corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Foreign subsidiary and security force had master-servant relationship, supporting respondeat superior finding against parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. v. Ranger Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Petroleum distribution franchisee failed to allege that Venezuelan president was acting as an officer of state-owned franchisor when he made anti-American comments, which allegedly breached an implied duty not to impair value of franchisor's brand, although some of franchisee's customers allegedly boycotted franchisee's gas stations as a result of comments, and thus franchisee was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to make franchisor vicariously liable for comments.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Petroleum Marketing Practices Act. Gas station franchisee did not reasonably rely on statement of franchisor's representative, which at most modified agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Charter school did not have an agent-principal relationship with the parent corporation of the management company with which charter school formed a management contract, precluding school's breach of fiduciary duty claim against the parent corporation, even though the parent corporation was a party to the contract, where parent corporation's representative signed the contract with an express, written indication that it was only signing as to certain provisions, and such provisions did not grant or impose any rights or obligations upon the parent corporation.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Charter school's negligence claims were barred by the economic loss rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Pharmaceutical Industry Average Wholesale Price Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Pharmaceutical company's parent company could not be held liable for wrongful acts of pharmaceutical company in relator's qui tam action under False Claims Act, absent evidence which supported piercing corporate veil. 31 U.S.C.A. §§ 3729-3733.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Relator was original source of average wholesale price-based rebate fraud allegations under False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Fisher v. Zaks
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent evidence that corporation's owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff, resulting in injury, that corporation was insolvent, or that improper conveyances were made. McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 271-276.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent evidence of complete domination of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Ivanov v. Sunset Pools Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Natural person was not alter ego of alleged malfeasant corporation on basis that person was part-owner of corporation, and thus corporate veil could not be pierced under District of Columbia law, since corporation was adequately capitalized, funds had not been commingled, and person did not personally make use of corporation to perpetuate fraud.
