Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Natural person was not alter ego of alleged malfeasant corporation on basis that person was part-owner of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Reinsurance treaty between majority stockholder of title insurance company and title insurance company did not demonstrate a lack of separateness nor provide stockholder with excessive control over company as to satisfy first prong of alter ego theory, as required to justify piercing the corporate veil; treaty was in effect before stockholder purchased an interest in company and while the treaty provided stockholder with reasonable oversight of reinsurance-related issues, it did not allow the parent to control company's day-to-day operations.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Allegations that title insurance company was undercapitalized were insufficient to show injustice or inequity under the second prong of alter ego test, as to require piercing of the corporate veil between company and its majority stockholder, where evidence showed majority stockholder provided financial assistance to company when the company could not satisfy its obligations.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Betty G. Weldon Revocable Trust ex rel. Vivion v. Weldon ex rel. Weldon
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Upon incorporation of trust assets, the corporation becomes the alter ego of the trustees and as such, the propriety of the trustee's acts must be determined in the light of the trust and must be controlled by the provisions of the trust.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE - Trusts. Decision by trustees serving on trust's holding company's board to sell farm was not protected by business judgment rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Shepherd Montessori Center Milan v. Ann Arbor Charter Tp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing the corporate veil was not applicable to zoning dispute between township board of zoning appeals and parochial school, in which school alleged that board's denial of its request for a variance to operate a faith-based primary school placed a substantial burden on school's religious exercise, in violation of Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), as it could not be reasonably argued that board suffered an unjust injury or loss by any alleged fraud by school, nor was there any showing of fraud or wrongdoing. Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000, § 2(a)(1)(A), 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000cc(a)(1)(A).
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Religion. Denial of variance to parochial school for its proposed use of property as a faith-based primary school violated RLUIPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, subsidiary was not the alter ego of parent corporation's sole shareholder; subsidiary engaged in corporate formalities, had officers and employees other than shareholder, was adequately capitalized, and subsidiary's assets as his own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied, as would support piercing corporate veil of original and new corporations; sole shareholder had complete control over both corporations, shareholder did not follow corporate formalities, funds of corporations and shareholders were commingled, and vehicle, which was titled in original corporation's name, was used personally by shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, "promoting injustice" prong of test for piercing corporate veil was satisfied as to successor construction business, as required for predecessor's liabilities to attach to company that coordinated predecessor's dissolution and successor's incorporation; through series of structured transactions effecting dissolution/incorporation, company acquired $1.2 million of predecessor's contract receivables and materials in exchange for forgiving loans amounting to fraction of that, while purportedly assuming $1.5 million in liabilities that it then passed to successor, an undercapitalized shell corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, company that served as conduit in series of structured transactions that effected dissolution of predecessor construction business and incorporation of under-capitalized successor was subject to predecessor's liabilities once successor's corporate veil was pierced, even though it was not shareholder in successor; there was no legitimate purpose behind company's inextricable involvement, and at end of transactions company failed to honor even the artificial structure they had created.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, trust that was sole shareholder in companies that conducted series of structured transactions that effected dissolution of predecessor construction business and incorporation of under-capitalized successor was potentially subject to predecessor's liabilities once successor's corporate veil was pierced, even though it was not directly involved in transactions; trust made number of direct payments to successor during its life span, with no evidence of any loan or other documentation, that enabled successor to continue its fragile existence, thus facilitating effort to deprive predecessor's obligees of their entitlement.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, officer/director of companies that conducted series of structured transactions that effected dissolution of predecessor construction business and incorporation of under-capitalized successor could not be subject to predecessor's liabilities once successor's corporate veil was pierced, based on his status alone and absent other evidence of involvement.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re WorldClass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under total control test for imposing lender liability on lender corporation, control inquiry is whether the debtor corporation is little more than a legal fiction, and fundamental unfairness must be shown to exist.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Plans. Confirmed Chapter 11 plan barred debtor's assertion that creditor was undersecured as of petition date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Intek Auto Leasing, Inc. v. Gharib
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Corporate president and sole shareholder of truck repair corporation that was in possession of truck pursuant to bailment was not individually liable to bailor for damage to vehicle; corporation was engaged in the business of selling and repairing trucks, bailor always dealt with corporation under its corporate name, and there was no proof of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder of truck repair company was not individually liable for damages to truck held pursuant to bailment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Giordano v. Thomson
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation's former Chief Financial Officer (CFO) could not hold its former chairman individually liable on alter ego grounds, where evidence presented does not demonstrate that damages resulted from misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Company was not entitled to summary judgment on former CFO's ERISA retaliatory interference claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Secrest v. Gibbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: President of corporations involved in property development had no functional control over the corporations and delegated all decision making to her husband, and thus, she could not be held personally liable for actions of corporations under a theory of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's wife, who was corporate president, was not personally liable for actions of corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Summers
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that wife's business operated out of same building previously used as place of business by her husband's company, that companies had nearly identical names and conducted substantially similar business, and that telephone number for wife's business was same telephone number previously used by husband's company was insufficient, without more, to permit piercing of corporate veil under Michigan law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Numerous errors on schedules warrant inference of fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Acrymed, Inc. v. Convatec
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, corporate veil of parent corporation would not be pierced to hold corporation liable for alleged wrongful acts of division of independent subsidiary corporation, absent allegation that parent engaged in any improper conduct in its control over division or that plaintiffs were unable to obtain adequate remedy against division and subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongdoing of subsidiary division.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Cosgrove Distributors, Inc. v. Haff
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil of restaurant supply wholesale corporation was not warranted; the two shareholders held annual meetings, thereby maintaining corporate formalities, they did not commingle their funds with those of the corporation, they did not borrow from the corporation, and they did not loan money to the corporation, and the corporation had employees, customers, and suppliers and was a separate and distinct commercial enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholders were not equitably estopped from asserting corporate status.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Murdock v. Ventures Trident II
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Owner of silica sand mine failed to establish alter ego relationship between corporation that held majority equitable interest in joint venture that leased mine and limited partnership that held minority shareholder interest in corporation, so as to hold partnership liable for mine's failure; although owner demonstrated close business relationship with some overlap in personnel, there was no evidence of commingling, diversion, or misuse of corporate funds, no identical equitable ownership, domination, or control by equitable owners, no identification of directors and managing officers, no office sharing, and no showing of any bad faith or inequity if entities were treated separately.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Limited partnership that supplied collateral for loan was not liable under lender liability theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Crystal Towers, Ltd. v. Highlands Ins. Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Holding company that owned insurer's parent corporation was not liable for bad faith to insureds upon alter ego principles or under the integrated enterprise test in action alleging bad faith; the insureds failed to show such a unity of interest and ownership that an inequitable result would follow if holding company were not held liable, they failed to show day-to-day control over insurer's employment decisions or greater than normal control, and two people were common officers of both corporations.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Holding company for insurer's parent corporation was not liable for insurer's alleged bad faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Francis v. Equilon Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Car wash purchaser's decision to act through a recently-created S corporation of which he was the sole shareholder and for which he produced all the funds, instead of in his own name at time of purchase, did not preclude award of damages to corporation in action against vendor.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Purchaser's decision to act through wholly-owned S corporation did not preclude award of damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hardy v. Brock
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Corporate officer's assistance in the everyday sales and business operations of the corporation, without more, could be a basis for piercing corporate shield and hold officer liable for any misfeasance on part of corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officer could not be held individually liable for alleged misfeasance on part of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Al Sayegh Bros. Trading (LLC) v. Doral Trading & Export, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, fact that corporation was severely undercapitalized, standing alone, was insufficient reason to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court would not pierce corporate veil to hold affiliated company liable for corporation's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Patin v. Thoroughbred Power Boats Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, district court did not clearly err in piercing the corporate veils of boat manufacturer and its successor corporation based on findings that the corporations were both alter egos of owner, and that the transformation of manufacturer to successor involved "improper conduct"; observance of corporate formalities in the transformation did not preclude piercing the corporate veils.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court did not clearly err in piercing the corporate veils of boat manufacturer and its successor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Scandinavian Satellite System, AS v. Prime TV Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: District court could not conclude that parent corporation was barred from suing its purported former wholly-owned subsidiary without district court first, at minimum, determining actual relationship between them, including whether extent of control exercised by parent over purported former subsidiary rose to level necessary to disregard their separate corporate identities.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Contract defense did not preclude district court jurisdiction over copyright claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Nat Katz & Associates, Ltd. v. Barber
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: President of construction company did not abuse corporate form and disregard separateness of legal entities, so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, even though he used the company as general contractor when renovating his condominium, since president and company maintained separate bank accounts, president reimbursed company for expenses relating to renovation, and company owed president a significant amount of money.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not liable for corporation's debts where he and corporation maintained separate bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Warmus
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, mere fact that attorney wholly owned his professional services corporation was insufficient, under Florida law, to make him jointly and severally liable with his corporation on veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Attorney's due diligence did not bar him from asserting good faith transferee defense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Motorsport Engineering, Inc. v. Maserati, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although corporate shareholder owned 100% of automobile distributor and 84% of automobile manufacturer, and even though corporate shareholder was largely owned by individual shareholder, there was no reason to disregard the corporate separateness of the distributor and manufacturer under Massachusetts law since there was no evidence of active and direct participation by the representatives of manufacturer, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of distributor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creation of successor corporation did not result in successor assuming predecessor's liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Telecom Intern. America, Ltd. v. AT & T Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of telephone service reseller would not be pierced to allow telecommunications services provider to assert its counterclaim for shortfall penalties against parent corporation of reseller, since provider had full and fair knowledge that parent corporation wanted to limit its potential losses by setting up subsidiary for telecommunications venture, and provider knew of reseller's lack of capitalization and its consequences when it entered into agreement with reseller.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence of course of dealing after consummation of contract was precluded under parole evidence rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors v. R.F. Lafferty & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's existence could not be disregarded, in lawsuit asserting a "deepening insolvency" cause of action against corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants; although corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants used corporation to commit a fraud, corporation was not fictional or a sham, corporate formalities were not ignored, and corporation did not lacked an identity separate from sole shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. In pari delicto defense precluded recovery by innocent victims of Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, fact that most of the counts concerning alleged racketeering violations, conspiracy, and violations of charging or garnishment orders had been dismissed from plaintiffs' complaint did not prohibit plaintiffs from proceeding with their attempt to pierce corporate veil, even though the alter ego doctrine is not an independent cause of action but a means for complainant to reach a second corporation or individual upon a cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against the first corporation, where plaintiffs still had underlying causes of action to collect on their various judgments entered against the individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: National Union Fire Ins. Co. of Pittsburgh, Pa. v. Bodek
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Trial court properly pierced the corporate veil and found a partnership between husband, his wife, and his children, where after husband allegedly divested himself of any interest in or control over the corporation, he instructed accountants, negotiated business deals and credit extensions, and executed promissory notes for the corporation which he personally guaranteed, and the corporation paid his personal expenses.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil of family's corporation was properly pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Menetti v. Chavers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Texas Business Corporation Act (TBCA) required homeowners to show actual fraud in order to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders of construction corporation personally liable for faulty construction of addition on home, in light of nature of claims for Deceptive Trade Practices Act (DTPA), fraud, breach of contract, and negligence as relating to or arising from a contractual obligation. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to prove actual fraud as required to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's faulty construction of addition to home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Daley v. American Drug Stores, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Wholly-owned subsidiaries of same corporation were separate and distinct corporate entities for purposes of exception to moratorium on grant of new liquor licenses for licenses in common ownership, absent any indication that one subsidiary so controlled affairs of the other as to render one subsidiary mere instrumentality or dummy, or that observance of fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Liquor. Plain language of municipal ordinance imposing moratorium on issuance of new liquor licenses prohibited transfer of license between wholly owned subsidiaries of same corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Balut v. Loral Electronic Systems
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent cannot be held liable for its subsidiary's civil rights violations, unless parent and subsidiary were single, integrated enterprise, that is, companies maintained (1) interrelated operations; (2) centralized control of labor relations; (3) common management; and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporation under Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).  On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, William C. Conner, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent could not be held liable for any civil rights violations by former employer, and (2) employer's alleged statement to employee upon terminating him was at most a stray remark, and was insufficient to establish discrimination. Former employer's motion granted; former employee's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Dean v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: District Court predicted that Missouri courts would apply same alter ego standard used in corporate context to context of trust and that, at minimum, Missouri law would require showing that alter ego of trust so dominated it that trust had "no separate mind, will or existence of its own."
Document Preview: Trustees brought action asserting that Internal Revenue Service (IRS) made wrongful levy on trust assets. The District Court, Laughrey, J., held that irrevocable trust was not alter ego of delinquent taxpayers and, therefore, IRS wrongfully levied on trust assets. Ordered Accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced, under Massachusetts law, where separate corporate entities were not totally owned in common, there was no pervasive control between two companies, and there was no proof of intermingling of business activity or assets, thin capitalization, nonobservance of corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency at time of litigated transaction, siphoning of assets, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, or that shell corporation was used to promote fraud.
Document Preview: Suppliers brought action against, inter alia, vice president of corporation that owed them money and company that was erroneously represented as the imminent purchaser of the corporation, alleging breach of contract and fraud. Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ponsor, J., adopted the opinion of Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) company was not liable for corporation's debts; (2) statute of frauds barred suppliers' breach of contract claim against company; (3) suppliers did not confer measurable benefit on company, as required for quantum meruit claim; (4) fact questions precluded summary judgment on misrepresentation claims against vice president of corporation and company; (5) vice president of corporation was not agent of company; (6) fact questions precluded summary judgment on estoppel claims against company; and (7) fact questions precluded summary judgment on unfair and deceptive trade practices claims against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Land v. Midwest Office Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: "Alter ego test" is one method of deciding whether parent corporation is liable for subsidiary's acts of discrimination, and this test is founded in equity and permits court to pierce corporate veil when court must prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, or when recognition of corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for crime.
Document Preview: Employee brought employment discrimination action against corporate employer and owner and president of corporate employer.  Owner and president moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Crow, Senior District Judge, held that employee did not state claim for individual liability against owner or president under alter ego doctrine. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, university student was "equitable owner" of computer software company that was established to market software developed by student because student exercised considerable authority over company to point of completely disregarding corporate form and acting as though its assets were his alone to manage and distribute, and student thus could be held personally liable for company's actions by piercing corporate veil, regardless of fact that student was neither shareholder, officer, director, nor employee of computer software company.
Document Preview: Salesperson for computer software company which was controlled by university student who had developed computer software brought action against company, successor corporation, and student, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Kaplan, J., 931 F.Supp. 1115, granted salesperson's motion to compel student and company to arbitrate claims, pursuant to salesperson's contract with company, but denied motion to arbitrate claims against successor corporation, staying those claims pending outcome of arbitration with student and company.  Student appealed, and salesperson cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Miner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Court of Appeals had jurisdiction over cross-appeal; (2) Court of Appeals would exercise jurisdiction over appeal under doctrine of pendent appellate jurisdiction; (3) student was equitable owner of company who...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, university student who developed computer software and controlled software company would not be held liable for company's allegedly wrongful acts towards salesperson, under doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, even if student exercised complete control over company, unless student used such control to commit fraud or other wrong that resulted in unjust loss or injury to salesperson.
Document Preview: Salesperson for computer software company which was controlled by university student who had developed computer software brought action against company, successor corporation, and student, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Kaplan, J., 931 F.Supp. 1115, granted salesperson's motion to compel student and company to arbitrate claims, pursuant to salesperson's contract with company, but denied motion to arbitrate claims against successor corporation, staying those claims pending outcome of arbitration with student and company.  Student appealed, and salesperson cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Miner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Court of Appeals had jurisdiction over cross-appeal; (2) Court of Appeals would exercise jurisdiction over appeal under doctrine of pendent appellate jurisdiction; (3) student was equitable owner of company who...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Trans-World Intern., Inc. v. Smith-Hemion Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under Delaware and California law, no defendant-shareholder was alter ego of corporation, although one defendant had bank account with corporate name used for personal business and there may have been inadequate capitalization and failure to observe corporate formalities; no defendant was dominant shareholder, non-defendant shareholders controlled bank accounts and generally ran all aspects of corporation, defendant with bank account did not use it for any of corporation's business, corporate structure was conceived largely by non-defendant, and financial statement on which corporate creditor claimed to have relied was not materially inaccurate.
Document Preview: Production company sued musical performers in family group and performers' corporation, alleging promissory estoppel, fraud, and alter ego claims arising out of cancelled televised performance.  After mistrial, plaintiff dismissed fraud claim and parties submitted claims to court based on record created during trial.  The District Court, Laughlin E. Waters, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) production company failed to establish promissory estoppel claim against performer who stated intent to appear on show; (2) dismissal of fraud claim did not preclude alter ego claims; and (3) performers were not alter egos of corporation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: General contractor and subcontractor, who were both in construction industry and who both had employees performing some of same type of work on job site, did not share same business purpose, for purposes of determining alter ego status, even though vast majority of subcontractor's work was for general contractor, where there was distinction in scope and purpose of each contractor's work.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  The District Court, 946 F.Supp. 612, granted companies' summary judgment motion on all claims based on alter ego doctrine and held that any claims against second company directly for under-reporting hours remained.  Funds filed motion to reconsider. The District Court, United States Magistrate Judge, Ashman, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company; (2) companies did not share common management or supervision; (3) companies did not share same business purpose; (4) companies did not share identical business...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: General contractor and subcontractor did not share identical business operations, for purposes of determining alter ego status, where there was insufficient evidence that subcontractor was financially dependent on general contractor for its continued existence or that both contractors shared same facilities and functioned jointly on daily basis.

Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: General contractor and subcontractor did not share equipment, for purposes of determining alter ego status, where subcontractor owned its own equipment and while subcontractor may have sometimes used general contractor's equipment if necessary, this did not establish that subcontractor was dependent on general contractor for all its equipment or material needs.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  The District Court, 946 F.Supp. 612, granted companies' summary judgment motion on all claims based on alter ego doctrine and held that any claims against second company directly for under-reporting hours remained.  Funds filed motion to reconsider. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Construction companies did not share substantially identical management and operations, for purposes of determining alter ego status; only common supervision alleged was that occurring on job sites where first company was general contractor and second company was subcontractor and this alleged common supervision was nothing more than kind of supervision normally occurring on construction site when general contractor oversees work of subcontractor.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ashman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company, for purposes of funds' claims against first company under alter ego theory; (2) material issue of fact as to whether second company under-reported hours worked and, therefore, owed contributions to funds precluded summary judgment for second company; and (3) evidence was insufficient to raise genuine issue of material fact as to first construction company's alter ego status...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Construction companies did not share substantially identical business purposes and customers, for purposes of determining alter ego status; first company was general contractor, responsible for overseeing entire project, while second company was subcontractor, only responsible for performing masonry or carpentry work on given project.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Construction companies did not share identical business operations, for purposes of determining alter ego status; for bulk of second company's existence, two companies were run out of separate locations, evidence related to joint daily functioning indicated nothing more than normal relationship between general contractor and subcontractor, and there was no evidence second company would have gone out of business without first company or that second company was dependent upon first company for its financial well being.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ashman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company, for purposes of funds' claims against first company under alter ego theory; (2) material issue of fact as to whether second company under-reported hours worked and, therefore, owed contributions to funds precluded summary judgment for second company; and (3) evidence was insufficient to raise genuine issue of material fact as to first construction company's alter ego status...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Communist Party v. 522 Valencia, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Communist Party could not use alter ego doctrine to "pierce the corporate veil" of public benefit corporations it claimed to have set up for its own benefit, while treating them as legally separate from itself.
Document Preview: Constructive Trust. Community Party was not entitled to constructive trust over assets of public benefit corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: National Westminster Bank USA v. Century Healthcare Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Lender liability is predicated on unmistakable showing that subservient corporation in reality has no separate, independent existence of its own and was being used to further purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Lender-bank sued borrower after borrower defaulted.  Borrower counterclaimed, seeking to avoid repayment of and to invalidate loan on claim of lender liability by reason of alleged domination and control exercised by lender over borrower during course of loans.  The District Court, Milton Pollack, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) borrower could not avoid repayment of nor invalidate $30 million loan on claim of lender liability; (2) borrower and guarantors were jointly and severally liable to lender-bank in amount of $29,885,054.40, including interest, $118,243.09, constituting reasonable attorney fees and costs incurred by lender in connection with enforcement of payment of note, and lender's attorney fees and costs incurred at trial; (3) borrower was under no legally cognizable duress; and (4) in any event, borrower waived any claim of duress. Counterclaim dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Wolf v. Walt
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Shareholder of corporation which had leased cattle did not have liability to lessor under theory of bailment; corporation was bailee and under facts of case corporate veil would not be pierced.
Document Preview: Lessor of cattle brought suit against sole shareholder of lessee, seeking recovery under theories of conversion, constructive fraud, breach of contract and bailment.  Claims were either dismissed by trial court or found against lessor by jury, and the District Court, Cuming County, Robert B. Ensz, J., entered judgment for lessee.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Lanphier, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) shareholder had not converted cattle; and (3) shareholder had not committed constructive fraud. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Becherer v. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of developer of resort hotel could not be pierced, so as to allow investors to reach assets of developer's officers and affiliated corporations, on grounds that developer was thinly capitalized; developer had not concealed its thin capitalization from investors, and did not defraud or mislead investors as to capitalization.
Document Preview: Investors brought action against brokers and others for securities violations and other claims, arising from investments made in hotel project.  After judgment was entered, 799 F.Supp. 755, some investors commenced state court litigation against brokers.  On motion for injunction and other motions, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, John Feikens, J., entered judgment disposing of claims, 809 F.Supp. 1259, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) investors were not entitled to damages arising from early closing of transaction; (2) developer breached contract by leasing equipment for hotel which it was required to furnish; (3) trial court erred by piercing corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers and affiliated companies of developer; (4) remand would be required to determine whether developer had violated Land Sales Act prohibition against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Becherer v. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of developer of resort hotel could not be pierced by investors, in order to reach assets of developer's officers and affiliated corporations, based upon quotations from marketing guide, prepared for internal use by employees of escrow agent marketing investor shares in hotel, which made reference to developer as being a subsidiary of other corporations having total assets of $350 million, and containing sample speech explaining how officers and affiliated companies were "in bed" with investors; document was not intended for distribution to investors and there was no indication that developer had been involved in drafting of guide.
Document Preview: Investors brought action against brokers and others for securities violations and other claims, arising from investments made in hotel project.  After judgment was entered, 799 F.Supp. 755, some investors commenced state court litigation against brokers.  On motion for injunction and other motions, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, John Feikens, J., entered judgment disposing of claims, 809 F.Supp. 1259, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) investors were not entitled to damages arising from early closing of transaction; (2) developer breached contract by leasing equipment for hotel which it was required to furnish; (3) trial court erred by piercing corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers and affiliated companies of developer; (4) remand would be required to determine whether developer had violated Land Sales Act prohibition against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Samuels
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced, in order to hold corporate principal personally liable for corporation's unauthorized practice of law and deceptive trade practices in preparing Chapter 13 petition and other documents on behalf of pro se debtor, where corporate principal was solely responsible for overall operation of corporation and was so completely and fully identified with corporation that piercing of corporate veil was permitted.
Document Preview: PRACTICE OF LAW. layperson engaged in unauthorized practice of bankruptcy law by preparing petition, schedules and other documents on behalf of clients and explaining clients' legal rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Paul Steelman, Ltd. v. Omni Realty Partners
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Even if corporation, which was general partner of limited partnership formed to develop large commercial venture, was undercapitalized, its formative capitalization was not a sham designed to perpetuate fraud or impose injustice upon plaintiff, as required to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability upon shareholders.
Document Preview: Architectural firm brought suit against limited partnership formed to develop large commercial venture, the corporate general partner and individual shareholders and limited partners.  The Eighth Judicial District Court, Clark County, Jack Lehman, J., refused to pierce general partner's corporate veil and awarded damages.  Architectural firm appealed, and limited partnership and general partner cross-appealed.  The Supreme Court held that: (1) plaintiff was not entitled to pierce corporate veil, and (2) trial court abused its discretion in calculating damages. Affirmed in part, and reversed and vacated in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Richter v. Capp Care, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division. .
Headnote: Managed health care company was not alter ego of insurance company, so as to be subject to Virginia Any Willing Provider Statute, where its insurance company shareholders did not control or operate its business; company operated nationwide to organize preferred provider organization networks for numerous insurance companies and corporations that provided their own health programs, and its shareholder owners represented small portion of its total business, which also included self-insured employers and nonowner insurance companies. Va.Code 1950, §§ 38.2-100, 38.2-3407, subds. A, E.
Document Preview: Physician brought suit against managed health care company, alleging that company violated Virginia Any Willing Provider Statute in rejecting her application for membership in preferred provider organization. Following bench trial, the District Court, Hilton, J., held that: (1) managed health care company was not insurer subject to regulation under Virginia Any Willing Provider Statute, and (2) in any event, health care company did not unreasonably discriminate against physician under Virginia Any Willing Provider Statute in rejecting her application because she had been disciplined for professional misconduct by Virginia Board of Medicine. Judgment for defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Liability insurers and their parent corporation used separate corporate identities as means of evading legal duty or to justify wrong, for purpose of piercing corporate veil, where subsidiary insurers that insured codefendant of chemical company, in action by homeowners, settled with codefendant, who had entered Mary Carter agreements with homeowners, to recoup money from chemical company that was also insured by subsidiaries of parent corporation; insurers owed duty, imposed by public policy, to chemical company to not obtain financial gain as joint tort-feasor.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Subsidiary of parent corporation was subject to piercing of corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for conduct of subsidiary, though subsidiary was not corporation; subsidiary was set up under Insurance Code and was controlled by underwriters, maintained directors, officers, bylaws, books and records, and assets and liabilities, was authorized to write insurance, and shared many characteristics of corporations. V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, arts. 18.01–18.24.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Castillo v. First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: No ownership relationship existed between or among lawyer, his law firm, and property management company to support attempt to disregard management company's corporate structure on ground that lawyer and his law firm set up company as sham to perpetrate fraud; management company had no corporate veil between it and its lawyers and law firm.
Document Preview: Foreign property owners brought action against attorney for breaching various duties in course of representing lender and administrator of owners' properties pledged as security for $120 million loan.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Norman W. Black, Chief Judge, 873 F.Supp. 12 granted summary judgment for attorney and his law firm, and property owners appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Edith H. Jones, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) attorney's legal discussions with owners during loan negotiations did not create attorney-client relationship giving rise to fiduciary duty; (2) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment on whether attorney became fiduciary for owners by serving as de facto chief executive, soliciting buyers, and negotiating deals with their mortgaged and nonmortgaged property; (3) attorney did not incur fiduciary liability by acting as agent and broker for properties, since mortgagee...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Berlin v. Boedecker
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Substantial credible evidence in suit by investors against investment company and its principal shareholder to recover for losses in two overriding royalty purchases supported finding that shareholder was alter ego of corporation so as to warrant piercing corporate veil; shareholder used corporate entity to perpetrate fraud against investors.
Document Preview: Action was brought against investment company and its principal shareholder for losses incurred by investors in two overriding royalty purchases.  The District Court, Eleventh Judicial District, County of Flathead, Joseph B. Gary, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Hunt, J., held that: (1) action was not barred by doctrine of res judicata or by doctrine of collateral estoppel; (2) amendment to complaint to add investment company as party defendant related back to date of filing of action and action was not barred by statute of limitations; (3) substantial credible evidence supported district court's findings of fact; and (4) district court did not err when it pierced corporate veil of investment company. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: United Trade Associates Ltd. v. Dickens & Matson (USA) Ltd., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced to hold corporation's owner individually liable, despite allegations that corporation did not observe corporate formalities; while plaintiff alleged that president failed to sign copies of articles of incorporation or annual meeting minutes, that annual meetings failed to reflect any business transactions, and that corporate charter was automatically revoked and not reinstated for over two years, president stated that corporation had operated profitably for six years and paid all required taxes.
Document Preview: Ukrainian purchaser sued American seller and its president for, inter alia, breach of contract to provide telephones that complied with guidelines set by Ukrainian telephone commission.  The District Court, Anna Diggs Taylor, J., held that: (1) seller breached contract and various warranties; (2) seller's president was not individually liable; and (3) seller's drawing down on letter of credit opened by purchaser was not actionable under theory of negligent or innocent misrepresentation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Price v. Aronson
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Fact that corporation's status was not indicated on its signs or business cards did not warrant piercing the corporate veil. West's A.I.C. 23-1-23-1, 23-1-23-1(a).
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Failure to indicate on signs and business cards that body shop was incorporated did not warrant piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Price v. Aronson
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Failure to file certificate of assumed named after corporation changed name under which it did business did not warrant piercing corporate veil; statute containing certificate requirement was penal in nature and, thus, to be strictly construed, and if legislature had intended that corporate veil be disregarded in the event of noncompliance, it could have specifically provided for that. West's A.I.C. 23-15-1-1.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Failure to indicate on signs and business cards that body shop was incorporated did not warrant piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Daniels v. Kerr McGee Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, mere fact that parent's annual report mentioned subsidiary and that parent corporation included subsidiary's revenues in its statement of net worth did not establish interrelation of operations under integrated enterprise standard for imposing liability on parent for subsidiary's alleged wrongful conduct.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against parent corporation based on subsidiary corporation's alleged wrongful conduct in discharging employee.  The District Court, Brimmer, J., held that parent corporation was not liable for alleged wrongful discharge of employee by subsidiary under either alter ego test or integrated enterprise test for imposing liability on parent corporation for acts of subsidiary. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Pacific Landmark Hotel, Ltd. v. Marriott Hotels, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Management firm could not evoke alter ego doctrine in order to disregard its own incorporation and be treated as part of parent corporation for purposes of determining whether it had agency coupled with interest in hotel.
Document Preview: Agency. Management firm did not have agency coupled with interest in hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Alside Supply Co. v. Wager
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether corporate fiction should be disregarded and its shareholder held liable, evidence that shareholder had complete control of corporation, that corporate formalities were not observed and that corporation was undercapitalized sufficiently showed complete dominion and control such that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Shareholder liable for debts of defunct corporation over which he exercised complete dominion and control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: John S. Boyd Co., Inc. v. Boston Gas Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Parent companies can be held liable for CERCLA liability as operators of contaminated facility, and such liability is direct; it does not require piercing corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, Joseph L. Tauro, Chief Judge, apportioned liability for cleanup of coal gas waste and oil gas waste under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Massachusetts Superfund Act, court assigned full liability to successor of gas and electric company for cleanup of coal gas waste and ordered holding company that purchased 97% of the company which manufactured coal gas, and the company's subsidiary, to pay for the cleanup of oil gas waste.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Torruella, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) successor corporation was properly held responsible for coal gas waste created before any of present parties were involved with gas and electric company, and (2) court properly held holding company and subsidiary liable for the cleanup of oil gas waste. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Celi v. Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil would not be pierced to hold Canadian parent corporation liable for acts of American subsidiary; there was no showing that parent corporation had dominated finances, policies, and business practices of subsidiary to such extent that subsidiary had no separate existence of its own.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and its parent corporations, claiming breach of contract, consequential damages, and promissory estoppel.  Defendants filed motion to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) Canadian parent corporation was not subject to Court's in personam jurisdiction; (2) alleged three-year oral employment agreement was unenforceable under New York's Statute of Frauds; (3) allegations that employee had been excluded from obtaining employment in adhesives injury because defendants fraudulently induced him to leave his prior position were barred by New York's one-year limitations period for defamation; and (4) employee's alleged injuries did not arise to level of unconscionable injury required to recover under New York's promissory estoppel doctrine. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Superior Stores Co. v. Pennsylvania Dept. of Health, Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Department of Health could not justify its disregard for grocery store's corporate status and thus it improperly considered past food stamp program's sanctions against sole proprietor in evaluating corporation's new store application, despite consent order which stated that it was binding on successors and transferees of sole proprietor; terms of consent order delineated how judgment against sole proprietor was to be paid but did not refer to underlying conduct which caused her to be penalized and therefore, provision binding transferees of sole proprietor would only obligate them to pay any part of judgment left unsatisfied by sole proprietor.
Document Preview: SOCIAL SERVICES - WIC. Corporation owning grocery store was entitled to participate in WIC program.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. BCCI Holdings (Luxembourg), S.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of corporate defendant in RICO action given frequent commingling of property and business affairs of corporation and defendant, financial dependence of corporation on defendant and related entities, commonality of ownership and management of corporation and defendant, and sharing of same building, business logo, telex, post office box, and telephone line for facsimile with defendant, and given that corporation, defendant, and their sibling and parent corporations appeared to have conducted their affairs as single entity without clearly identifying which company or entity was concerned with or responsible for any particular transaction.
Document Preview: Government moved to include additional property in forfeiture order in RICO action. The District Court, Joyce Hens Green, J., held that: (1) bank accounts, proceeds from sale of condominium, legal fund, and claim filed in bankruptcy proceeding were forfeitable; (2) assets of racketeering corporation's alter ego are forfeitable interests; and (3) corporation was alter ego of racketeering corporations. Forfeiture ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Walter v. Holiday Inns, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law of alter ego liability, parent corporation, rather than subsidiary that entered into partnership formed to construct casino, owed fiduciary duties to other partners; parent was true entity behind subsidiary, and control by parent over subsidiary was absolute.
Document Preview: Former partners in partnership formed to construct casino brought action against corporate partner who bought out their interests.  On corporate partner's motion for judgment as matter of law, the District Court, Rodriguez, J., held that: (1) plaintiffs were not entitled to rescission of buyout transaction; (2) corporate partner did not have duty to disclose relevant information to plaintiffs after its relationship with them became adversarial; (3) corporate partner did not violate any fiduciary duty to disclose material information; and (4) plaintiffs were not entitled to award of punitive damages with regard to their fraud claims. Motion granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Parton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was justified, where debtor was president, sole officer, and sole shareholder of corporation, debtor governed all or substantially all affairs of corporation, corporation failed to issue any stock, debtor personally paid obligations of corporation on one or more occasions and corporation paid personal obligations of debtor on one or more occasions, debtor used corporate assets for his personal use, and debtor furnished all of corporation's capital.
Document Preview: Bank commenced adversary proceeding in Chapter 7 case, seeking determination that debt was nondischargeable.  Bank moved for summary judgment.  The Bankruptcy Court, R. Guy Cole, Jr., J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was justified; (2) debt was not nondischargeable on grounds of false pretenses, false representation, or actual fraud; (3) relationship between debtor and bank under agreement whereby debtor arranged leases for motor vehicles while bank provided related financial services was not fiduciary, for nondischargeability purposes; and (4) debt was not nondischargeable on grounds of willful and malicious injury. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Lorkowski v. J.C. Pitman Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for any acts of wholly-owned subsidiary; although boards of directors of the two corporations overlapped, in all other respects corporation had not disregarded subsidiary's corporate separateness, had not involved itself directly in management of subsidiary and had not otherwise dominated or controlled subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action was brought against subsidiary and its parent corporation. The Supreme Court, Erie County, Ostrowski, J., denied parent corporation's motion for summary judgment.  Parent corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that parent corporation could not be held liable for acts of wholly-owned subsidiary. Reversed, motion granted, complaint and cross claims dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Riggins v. Dixie Shoring Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced to render employee of corporation liable for claims against corporation; piercing of veil was effective only to reach individual assets of shareholders. LSA-R.S. 12:92, subd. D, 12:93, subd. D.
Document Preview: Homeowners sued for damages arising from allegedly negligent levelling of house.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Max N.
