Tobias, Jr., J., entered judgment for owners against individuals involved with corporation which had provided services.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Becker, J., held that: (1) corporate veil was properly pierced to reach individual assets of major shareholder of corporation; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to reach assets of person who was mere employee; and (3) homeowners were entitled to mental anguish damages. Affirmed in part; reversed in part. Armstrong, J., dissented and filed written reasons.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Woodstock Associates I, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporations which subleased nursing homes were not alter egos of leasing corporations, though corporations were incorporated within three weeks of each and had identical officers and directors, absent showing that sublessees failed to maintain separate corporate records or observe corporate formalities, or that corporations commingled their funds or were undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Debtor nursing home operators objected to creditor's claims. On cross motions for summary judgment, the Bankruptcy Court, John H. Squires, J., held that: (1) creditor did not have perfected security interest in debtors' medicaid reimbursements; (2) creditor's postpetition contributions were not entitled to administrative priority status; and (3) issue of material fact as to whether operators' Chapter 11 plan was proposed in good faith precluded summary judgment for creditor. Debtors' motion granted in part and denied in part; creditor's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Kayser-Roth Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: A parent corporation that controls the management and operations of its wholly owned subsidiary can be held responsible for its subsidiary's CERCLA liability without piercing the corporate veil. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., as amended, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: The United States brought suit under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liablity Act to recover cleanup costs occasioned by the discharge of trichloroethylene by a textile manufacturer.  The District Court, Francis J. Boyle, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence established that former parent of manufacturer was an operator for purposes of CERCLA; (2) former parent was also an owner for purposes of CERCLA; and (3) evidence established a causal connection between manufacturer's release of trichloroethylene and residential well contamination. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gershuny v. Martin McFall Messenger Anethesia Professional Ass'n
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: Professional service corporation was a legal corporate entity separate and distinct from the persons comprising it. West's F.S.A. § 621.07.
Document Preview: Malpractice action was brought against professional service corporation which employed nurse anesthetist.  Judgment was entered on verdict in favor of the association, but its request for attorney fees was denied.  The District Court of Appeal, 528 So.2d 1206, reversed.  The Supreme Court, Kogan, J., held that because nurse who administered anesthesia to patient was acting independently and not under the direct supervision of any physician, none of the physician shareholders of the professional corporation which employed her could be held liable, so that statute providing for award of attorney fees to prevailing party in medical malpractice action against a physician was inapplicable. Decision of district court quashed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Reflectone, Inc. v. Farrand Optical Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Neither subsidiary's grant of security interest in its assets to its parent nor the cutoff of funds from the parent to the subsidiary justified piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Plaintiff in action for breach of contract appealed from order of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, No. 87427CIV T15B, William J. Castagna, J., which granted summary judgment for parent corporation after ordering arbitration as to subsidiary.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) it was not an abuse of discretion to grant motion for summary judgment prior to discovery; (2) plaintiff was not entitled to respond to prior summary judgment motion in light of its amended complaint where amended complaint presented no genuine issues of material fact; and (3) there was no basis for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Oriental Commercial and Shipping Co., Ltd. v. Rosseel, N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere act of incorporation does not limit personal liability of chairman managing director of corporation who owns 70 of its 100 shares where corporation was merely dummy for chairman managing director who was in reality carrying on his personal business for purely personal ends.
Document Preview: After oil trading company served notice of intent to arbitrate upon British and Saudi Arabian corporations, Saudi Arabian corporation brought state court action to stay arbitration. Oil trading company removed state proceeding to federal court and then moved to compel arbitration and for appointment of arbitrator. In consolidated action, the District Court, Leisure, J., held that: (1) British corporation had apparent authority to bind Saudi Arabian corporation to fuel oil supply transaction, and fact oil trading company itself did not know identity of Saudi Arabian corporation prior to contract date would not preclude recovery from the Saudi Arabian corporation; (2) British corporation was controlled by its chairman managing director with respect to oil supply transaction and was used by its chairman managing director to commit fraud or wrong, and was accordingly alter ego of chairman managing director; and (3) Saudi Arabian corporation, which British corporation...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Geringer v. Wildhorn Ranch, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate alter ego theory would be applied to impose liability on owner of corporation in view of his domination and control of the corporation, his business cards which represented that he was the owner of corporation property, his use of funds from another corporation to make purchases for the corporation, and his personal involvement with the instrumentalities which caused the harm to the plaintiffs.
Document Preview: Widow and mother of resort guests who died in boating accident brought action against the resort, its owner, and others.  Following jury verdict in favor of plaintiff, the District Court, Sherman G. Finesilver, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence warranted application of the corporate alter ego doctrine; (2) punitive damages could be awarded against corporation which was found negligent, even though zero percent of the negligence was attributed to it; and (3) Colorado premises liability statute does not apply to act of landowner in supplying chattel to an invitee. Ordered accordingly. See also 706 F.Supp. 1452.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chaney v. Godfrey
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Informal meetings by three 25% shareholders without sending notice, general failure to keep minutes, and failure to reduce corporate resolutions to writing unless required by financial institutions did not indicate that shareholders in corporation were acting as one and did not justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Prospective purchasers of corporate assets brought action against shareholders to recover for breach of contract.  The First Judicial District Court, Parish of Caddo, Jeffrey P. Victory, J., rejected purchasers' claims.  Purchasers appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Sexton, J., held that: (1) letter of intent to sell corporate assets was not valid contract; (2) circumstances did not justify piercing of corporate veil; and (3) board chair and corporate secretary did not have apparent authority to sign contract for sale of assets. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Federal Sav. and Loan Ins. Corp. v. Quality Inns, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Related corporation would not be held liable for wrongdoings of corporations which acted as managing agent on ski resort construction project, absent evidence that related corporation operated as same organization as other corporations, that related corporation undertook to act on behalf of construction lender, or that related corporation played significant role in either relationship between other corporations and lender or relationship between other corporations and party constructing project; no fraud had been perpetrated by related corporation, nor was there paramount equity sufficient to enable district court to ignore separate corporate status of related corporation.
Document Preview: Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as receiver for construction lender, brought action against corporations which acted as managing agent of ski resort construction project and related corporation for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, and breach of escrow agreement.  The District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that: (1) managing agent had agency relationship with construction lender; (2) managing agent breached fiduciary duty owed construction lender by misapplying draw approved for furniture and fixtures; (3) managing agent was liable for portion of draw which would have been available to purchase furniture and fixtures and simple interest thereon; and (4) related corporation could not be held liable for wrongdoings of managing agent. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Arizona Public Service Co. v. Arizona Corp. Com'n
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department B.
Headnote: Corporate "veil" would not be "pierced," for purpose of finding that parent of public utility was itself a public service corporation, where both parent and subsidiary maintained separate corporate identities and there was no evidence of undercapitalization, fraud, misconduct, or impropriety in management or operation of the two companies.
Document Preview: Public service corporation and its parent corporation sought review of order of Arizona Corporation Commission requiring them to submit detailed monthly reports concerning their past business activities and future plans.  The Superior Court, Maricopa County, Cause No. C547409, Frank T. Galati, J., granted summary judgment for Commission, and corporations appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Haire, J., held that: (1) Commission lacked jurisdiction to order parent corporation to comply with reporting requirements; (2) reporting requirement was justified, reasonable in scope, reasonably articulated, and not unduly intrusive insofar as it applied to public service corporation; and (3) corporations were not denied procedural due process when order was issued. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Mitchell v. Rancho Viejo, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporation was not alter ego of 80% shareholder of corporation; there was no evidence to show corporation was used by shareholder to perpetrate fraud, void effect of statute, evade existing obligation, protect crime, achieve or perpetrate a monopoly, or justify a wrong, nor was there evidence to show separateness of corporation had ceased or that adherence to corporation friction would sanction fraud or foster injustice.
Document Preview: Owners of lots in subdivision brought action for declaratory judgment setting forth their rights vis-a-vis owner of certain large areas within subdivision.  The 197th District Court, Cameron County, Darrell B. Hester, J., entered judgment that denied all parties damages against each other and set forth declarations as to rights and obligations of parties in subdivision, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Dorsey, J., held that: (1) certificate of dedication which provided that owners dedicated all streets, easements, alleys and parks for use in benefit of owners and residents of subdivision did not constitute dedication of large areas in question, and (2) corporation was not alter ego of 80% shareholder of corporation which owned land in question. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Francis v. Beaudry
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Where remaining stockholders of corporations sold all assets of corporation and retained proceeds for themselves individually, corporation was "denuded" of its assets, and remaining stockholders were liable to estate of deceased stockholder for value of his holdings as of time of his death.
Document Preview: Estate of deceased stockholder brought action against remaining stockholders and directors of corporation to recover value of decedent's holdings in corporation as of date of his death.  The Probate Court No. 1, Dallas County, Nikki DeShazo, J., found in favor of estate, and stockholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Devany, J., held that: (1) remaining stockholders were personally liable to estate, where remaining stockholders continued to operate corporation for their own benefit after decedent's death and ignored existence of corporate form; (2) probate court had subject matter jurisdiction of cause; and (3) trial court erroneously included sum twice in its calculations of total net assets of corporation. Affirmed as reformed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Futch v. Head
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Real estate corporations owned by broker were not distinct from broker, and, thus, corporate veil could be pierced, where broker merged corporations' liabilities and assets with personal funds, failed to distinguish between individual and corporate capacities in connection with sale of property along with cobroker, and paid commission to one corporation upon sale of her property.
Document Preview: Cobroker brought action against broker for payment of commission and fraud. The Circuit Court, Escambia County, Lacey A. Collier, J., awarded damages for breach of contract and conversion and awarded treble damages under Anti-Fencing Act.  Broker appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Shivers, J., held that: (1) enforceable contract existed between broker and cobroker to pay cobroker portion of broker's 20% interest in sold property in order to compensate cobroker for efforts as joint venturer; (2) existence of contract negated any trebling of damages, regardless of whether conversion existed; and (3) cobroker was procuring cause entitled to commission. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Carlson v. Carlson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Trial court in dissolution action properly pierced corporate veil of husband's professional association where husband had not respected separate identity of personal and corporate assets, despite contention that corporate veil was improperly pierced because no finding of alter ego was made.
Document Preview: Husband appealed from judgment of dissolution entered in the District Court, Hennepin County, Sheryl Hvass, J.  The Court of Appeals, Popovich, C.J., held that: (1) trial court erred in its division of marital property, and (2) trial court did not abuse its discretion in failing to recuse itself given lack of demonstrated prejudice. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Molander v. Raugust-Mathwig, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Panel Four.
Headnote: Finding of personal knowledge on behalf of corporation's principal with respect to inaccurate letter did not provide basis for imposing personal liability on principal; failure of principal to warn recipient that an erroneous letter had been issued causing the recipient to take action to his detriment was not sufficient to warrant disregard of corporate form and impose personal liability.
Document Preview: Architect brought action for fee.  The Superior Court, Spokane County, John J. Lally and William Luscher, JJ., entered judgment in favor of architect, and principal of one corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Thompson, J., held that: (1) failure to form limited partnership resulted in general partnership liability of corporate entities which were to form the limited partnership, not in liability of corporate principal personally; (2) failure of corporate principal to inform architect of errors in letter sent to him by corporation did not provide basis for imposing personal liability; and (3) principal of corporation had not been unjustly enriched. Reversed. McInturff, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: L.B. Industries, Inc. v. Smith
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: It would be unfair to subject innocent corporate directors to liability for unscrupulous conduct of a single director who, as president, had operated company as if he and it were one and the same.
Document Preview: Action was brought against minority shareholder in corporation and its representative on the board of directors for alleged fraudulent transactions involving the purchase and development of small hydroelectric sites.  The District Court, Ryan, J., held that: (1) under Idaho law, minority shareholder and its representative would not be liable for any fraud committed by corporation, and (2) corporate entity could not be disregarded to impose personal liability on minority shareholder or its representative. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: "Collaborative activity" between related corporations did not present adequate grounds for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Iranian citizen brought action to recover payment for services he claimed to have rendered in Iran for Delaware corporation.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: British subsidiary corporation was not subservient to Delaware parent corporation, so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the two corporations, but rather was one corporation of group of related corporations, in different countries, working closely together, where subsidiary had separate board of directors, had its own bank account, had its own credit standing, maintained separate offices, was separately managed, and conducted its business affairs separate from that of parent.
Document Preview: Iranian citizen brought action to recover payment for services he claimed to have rendered in Iran for Delaware corporation.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Paynesville Farmers Union Oil Co. v. Ever Ready Oil Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Trial court correctly refused to pierce corporate veil of closely held corporation and hold two sole shareholders personally liable on theory that corporation was allegedly alter ego or instrumentality of shareholders, even though corporation depreciated property owned by the sole shareholders which they leased to corporation and there was no documentation of sale of some assets from the preexisting sole proprietorship to the corporation, where annual meetings were held, minutes were taken, separate bank accounts were kept, one dividend was paid, annual salaries were set, business was not undercapitalized, sole shareholders did not siphon funds and in fact when corporation was faltering shareholders took as draws less than they were entitled to as salary, and there was no evidence that corporation was operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner.
Document Preview: Petroleum business appealed from judgment of the District Court, Stearns County, Paul J. Doerner, J., which refused to hold sole shareholders of closely held corporation liable on debt owed by corporation to petroleum business.  The Court of Appeals, Lansing, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that closely held corporation was a disclosed principal, and (2) trial court correctly refused to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholders personally liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Dorton v. Dorton
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Finding that president of a corporation who was also a director and 51% shareholder mismanaged corporate property by allowing it to deteriorate and not realizing full rental potential from it was properly considered as one of several factors demonstrating domination and control of corporation to detriment of minority shareholder.
Document Preview: Equitable distribution order was entered by District Court, Durham County, David Q. LaBarre, C.J., after earlier actions concerning custody, alimony, and child support, and divorce were consolidated by stipulation of husband and wife.  Wife appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webb, J., held: (1) husband's dental license was separate property and must be considered as one of factors affecting equitable distribution; (2) husband who knew of existence of family corporation and shared in duty to observe corporate formalities would not be allowed to disregard corporate entity on basis of noncompliance with formalities; (3) trial court erred in terminating writ of possession regarding marital home contained in earlier child support order; and (4) trial court did not improperly consider marital fault as factor in distributing marital property. Judgment vacated and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Although records were kept of each advance made by parent to subsidiary, for purposes of determining if subsidiary was alter ego of parent, records did not reflect true economic reality of commingling of funds, where no collateral was posted for loans parent made to subsidiary, and subsidiary paid no interest on loans.
Document Preview: After obtaining criminal conviction against corporation and individuals in connection with fraudulent misrepresentations to obtain agricultural subsidies under upland cotton program, Government brought action to recover erroneously paid subsidies.  When corporation went into bankruptcy, and further proceedings were stayed, Government sought to hold corporation's parent company liable on ground that subsidiary was its alter ego or agent.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Halbert O. Woodward, Chief Judge, sitting without jury, found that parent exercised total domination and control over subsidiary and that consequently subsidiary was alter ego of parent, and entered judgment against parent in amount of $4,787,604.20, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) District Court's finding that there was commingling of corporate funds was supported by record; (2) subsidiary was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Under instrumentality rule, where affiliated corporation was without separate and distinct corporate identity, controlling shareholder exercised such control over existence and functioning of corporation that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction attacked even if he were not aware of such transaction.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Harris v. Best of America Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Maintaining separate bank accounts by corporation and its president and explaining questioned fund transfers as loan transactions did not demonstrate a commingling of corporate funds with funds of individual, thereby destroying the separate identities of the entities so as to justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Contractor and its president appealed from the Twenty-Second Judicial District Court, Parish of Washington, James R. Strain, Jr., J., which determined that owner was entitled to recover certain damages for faulty work under construction contract.  The Court of Appeal, Carter, J., held that: (1) stipulated damages provided in contract did not limit award of damages to owner for faulty workmanship; (2) trial court properly relied upon testimony of plaintiff's experts in determining award of damages; and (3) totality of facts did not support a finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on contract with plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Harris v. Best of America Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Two board meetings in two years was not an insufficient number of meetings so as to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Contractor and its president appealed from the Twenty-Second Judicial District Court, Parish of Washington, James R. Strain, Jr., J., which determined that owner was entitled to recover certain damages for faulty work under construction contract.  The Court of Appeal, Carter, J., held that: (1) stipulated damages provided in contract did not limit award of damages to owner for faulty workmanship; (2) trial court properly relied upon testimony of plaintiff's experts in determining award of damages; and (3) totality of facts did not support a finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on contract with plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Complaint of Sun Schiffahrts G.m.b.H. & Co., K.G.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Libyan law, Delaware corporation, which was operator and co-owner of oil terminal located in Libyan port at which Liberian tanker washed aground while attempting to unmoor, was not agent of Libyan oil company which owned 51% of the Delaware corporation, where the Delaware corporation and the Libyan oil company were separate corporate entities and Delaware corporation operated the terminal independently of the Libyan oil company and required the Libyan oil company to sign "Tanker Loading Advice" documents when its vessels used Delaware Corporation's facilities; thus, there was no basis for piercing corporate veils.
Document Preview: Owners of Liberian oil tanker brought action against Delaware corporation which was operator and co-owner of oil terminal located in Libyan port, for exoneration from and limitation of liability pursuant to Limitation of Liability Act for damages arising when tanker washed aground in storm while attempting to unmoor from the oil terminal. The District Court, Shapiro, J., held that: (1) Libyan law applied; (2) Tanker Loading Advice document, signed by the parties and proferred by terminal operator as condition to berthing at the terminal, was valid contract under Libyan law; (3) choice of English law under Tanker Loading Advice document was valid; (4) the document exempted terminal operator from any liability to tanker owners for damage sustained as a result of conduct of terminal operator's mooring master or mooring personnel launches or equipment under supervision and control of mooring master; and (5) the document did not require tanker owners...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Rhode Island Hosp. Trust Nat. Bank v. Almonte
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: In the absence of any evidence that any of the corporations involved in various check transactions benefited from the funds, corporate veil was properly pierced to hold owner of the corporations liable.
Document Preview: Bank brought action to recover from owner of various corporations amount which it had been required to repay to the federal government after bank paid to one of the corporations a federal Treasury check with an improper endorsement. The Superior Court, Providence District, Cochran, J., entered judgment in favor of bank and owner of corporations appealed.  The Supreme Court, Weisberger, J., held that: (1) evidence sustained the judgment; (2) corporate veil was properly pierced; and (3) evidence of demand for payment made by the government to the bank was properly admitted. Appeal denied and dismissed and judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Rollins, Inc. v. Heller
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: There was no need for homeowners to pierce corporate veil between subsidiary corporation that installed burglar alarm system and parent corporation which was a defendant in homeowners' action for damages arising out of burglary, where parent was itself a direct participant in the dealings with the homeowners.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action against burglar alarm company, seeking to recover damages arising from burglary and theft of property.  The Circuit Court, Dade County, Leonard Rivkind, J., found defendant liable for gross negligence and deceptive and unfair trade practices in connection with installation and servicing of burglar alarm system, and granted an award of compensatory and punitive damages totaling $228,487, and defendant appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Nesbitt, J., held that: (1) aggregate of compensatory and punitive damages recoverable by homeowners for defendant's gross negligence was limited to ten percent of one year's service charge or $250, whichever was greater, in light of contract provision limiting damages; (2) actual damages were recoverable by homeowners in full for the Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act violation, notwithstanding contractual limitation of liability; and (3) no award of punitive damages was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: LaDel, Inc. v. Fox
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil in order to impose liability upon officer of corporation was not required where plaintiff did business with officer without ever being aware that corporation was in operation.
Document Preview: Action was brought against officer of corporation, individually, for money due for goods and services on open account.  The Twenty-Fourth Judicial District Court for the Parish of Jefferson, Floyd W. Newlin, J., rendered judgment against corporate officer personally for full account, and officer appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Boutall, J., held that evidence supported trial court's finding that officer was personally liable, including evidence that bank accounts and checks of officer during relevant period were not in corporate name, that letters received from officer showed no corporate name, that officer's signature was never supported by identification of his corporate function, and that plaintiff did business with officer without being aware that corporation was ever in operation. Affirmed. Bowes, J., filed dissenting opinion and was of the opinion to grant rehearing. Boutall and Chehardy, JJ., were of the opinion to refuse rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Matter of Estate of Butterfield
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Where corporation is wholly owned by trust and directly owns and controls all corporate assets, courts are less reluctant to ignore corporate entity and to consider corporation, which is usually holding company, an adjunct of trust, but each case must be evaluated on its own facts with due consideration given to settlor's intent, i.e., whether corporation was formed during his lifetime with direction in trust document that it be continued. M.C.L.A. § 700.813.
Document Preview: Beneficiaries of trust sought disallowance of account and other relief.  The Calhoun County Probate Court, Wendell L. Schoder, J., issued order from which trustees appealed and contesting beneficiaries cross appealed.  The Court of Appeals, after dismissal of a prior appeal without prejudice, 100 Mich.App. 657, 300 N.W.2d 359, ordered remand, 108 Mich.App. 363, 310 N.W.2d 381.  After granting trustees' application for leave to appeal, the Supreme Court, Boyle, J., held that given intent of testator that principal of testamentary trust be maintained and that trustees be given broad discretion, court would not interfere with operation of trust, on suggestion of income beneficiaries that there were excessive retained earnings, absent showing of breach of fiduciary duty, and comparison of level of retained earnings to factual needs of businesses was to be made to determine whether retained earnings were excessive, and conclusory allegations of excessive retained...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Stevens v. Morrison-Knudsen Saudi Arabia Consortium
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: There was no fraud or paramount equity which would permit court to pierce corporate veil and hold corporation responsible for any acts of joint venture formed by several corporations including subsidiary of such corporation.
Document Preview: Employees brought suit against their private employers for alleged violations of their constitutional rights which culminated in the employees' prosecution by Saudia Arabian authorities and subsequent imprisonment in jail in that kingdom for possession of marijuana.  On various motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Alexander Harvey, II, J., held that: (1) no Bivens remedy would be fashioned to permit employees to recover damages under their federal claim; (2) acts of defendants did not amount to state action; (3) complete diversity did not exist; and (4) court would not exercise pendent jurisdiction. Defendants' motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: A.G. Edwards & Sons, Inc. v. Northwest Realty Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Corporate defendant which received a price for 1,500 shares of stock which should have been received only if dividend shares were also being sold was unjustly enriched and would be required to deliver the 750 dividend shares to plaintiff broker; the court, in making such determination, would look beyond corporate facade and recognize that the subject stock gift and sale was simply the business maneuverings of an individual who controlled both the corporate donor of the stock shares and the corporate donee; while the broker was not without fault in failing to clear up the details before sale was completed, it had been the individual's broker for 17 years, knew well of his long and financially rewarding career in market, and was warranted in assuming that he was aware of the consequences of selling stock for higher of two prices offered.
Document Preview: Broker brought suit against corporate customer to recover 750 dividend shares for delivery to purchasers of 1,500 shares of stock.  The Circuit Court, Fourth Judicial Circuit, Davison County, George W. Wuest, J., entered judgment in favor of broker, and defendant appealed.  The Supreme Court, Anderson, Circuit Judge, held that corporate defendant which received a price for 1,500 shares of stock which should have been received only if the dividend shares were also being sold was unjustly enriched and would be required to deliver the 750 dividend shares to plaintiff broker; the court, in making such determination, would look beyond the corporate facade and recognize that the subject stock gift and sale was simply the business maneuverings of an individual who controlled both the corporate donor of the stock shares and the corporate donee; while the broker was not without fault in failing to clear up the details before the sale was completed, it had been...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Hickman v. Rawls
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Failure to maintain proper records and to prevent creditors from collecting from corporation did not rise to level required to ignore the corporation, absent additional compelling facts.
Document Preview: Action was brought seeking to pierce corporate veil in order to hold sole shareholders of corporation liable for the corporation's breach of contract.  The 191st District Court, Dallas County, Charles Ben Howell, J., rendered judgment against shareholders, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Akin, J., held that where corporation was not a sham used for some illegal scheme, but was organized for legitimate purpose which failed due to circumstances beyond the control of the shareholders and where no evidence existed of any circumstance to suggest that the corporate entity was used against public policy, plaintiffs were not entitled to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold sole shareholders liable for corporation's breach of contract. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Pisani
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Physician was personally liable for medicare overpayments made to his solely-owned corporation where physician followed no corporate formalities, operated the corporation with his personal funds, loaned large sums to the corporation and then repaid the loans to himself with corporate funds while the corporation was failing, and kept the corporation undercapitalized by loaning it money instead of investing equity in it.
Document Preview: The Government brought action against physician to recover medicare overpayments made to physician's solely-owned corporation. The United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, Anne E. Thompson, J., entered judgment for the Government, and physician appealed. The Court of Appeals, Van Dusen, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) federal, rather than New Jersey, law controlled; (2) the corporate veil was to be pierced and physician was personally liable for the overpayment; (3) the action was not barred by statute of limitations or laches; and (4) the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was entitled to use cost data for a facility which it considered to be comparable in determining amount of overpayment, and such determination was not arbitrary or capricious. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Glacier General Assur. Co. v. G. Gordon Symons Co., Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Record established that insurance agency was wholly owned subsidiary and agent of parent corporation, as required to establish liability of the parent for issuance of policy in excess of authority.
Document Preview: Fire insurer brought action against agency and its parent corporation for issuance of unauthorized policy. The United States District Court for the District of Montana, William D. Murray, J., entered judgment, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Farris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) record established that insurance agency was wholly owned subsidiary and agent of parent corporation, as required to establish liability; (2) evidence was sufficient to sustain finding by District Court that the agency was unauthorized to write the fire policy; (3) insurer was entitled to collect entire loss from agency and its parent corporation even though insurer had received partial reimbursement from reinsurers; and (4) reinsurers were not necessary parties. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Citronelle-Mobile Gathering, Inc. v. O'Leary
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: That various companies engaged in the refining and sale of oil were operated for their common benefit did not permit court to ignore their separate existence. Economic Stabilization Act of 1970, § 205 as amended 12 U.S.C.A. § 1904 note; Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act of 1973, § 2 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 751 et seq.
Document Preview: Companies involved in the oil business brought action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against government agents who counterclaimed to collect overcharges allegedly made by plaintiffs. The District Court, Pittman, Chief Judge, held that: (1) transactions entered into by various corporations engaged in selling and refining oil and involving transfers of crude petroleum to Bahamian partnership for which export prices were granted violated regulations setting maximum prices for domestic crude oil; (2) restitution would be ordered in favor of the United States Treasury; and (3) no penalty would be assessed. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Mas Marques v. Digital Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts parent corporation did not sufficiently control its West German subsidiary so as to state a cause of action against parent for subsidiary's allegedly discriminatory acts with respect to a United States citizen residing in West Germany.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, a United States citizen residing in West Germany, brought suit against Massachusetts parent corporation and its West German subsidiary alleging discriminatory personnel practices of subsidiary with respect to age, sex, and national origin in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Upon defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Skinner, J., held that: (1) Massachusetts parent corporation did not sufficiently control its West German subsidiary so as to state a cause of action against parent and (2) West German subsidiary did not have sufficient minimum contacts with Massachusetts for exercise of personal jurisdiction over it. Motion allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Markarian v. Califano
Court: United States District Court, W. D. New York.
Headnote: Social Security Administration may not disregard corporate form in which a claimant has placed his business interest in determining claimant's eligibility for retirement insurance benefits where claimant can obtain tax savings by incorporating business. Social Security Act, § 202(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 402(a).
Document Preview: Review was sought of a final determination of the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare which denied retirement insurance benefits to claimant due to excess earnings. The District Court, Curtin, Chief Judge, held that Social Security Administration may not disregard corporate form in which a claimant has placed his business interests in determining claimant's eligibility for retirement insurance benefits where claimant can obtain tax savings by incorporating business. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Branham v. McGinnis
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Trial court properly disregarded corporate fiction where there was nothing inherent in transaction between plaintiff and defendant which would automatically categorize the transaction as corporate business and where retention of the fiction would have produced injustice and inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: Suit was brought to recover money on ground that defendant had guaranteed repayment of certain sum to plaintiff if codefendant failed to repay the same. The District Court, Douglas County, Patrick W. Lynch, J., affirmed municipal court judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Kortum, District J., held that: (1) trial court properly disregarded corporate fiction where there was nothing inherent in transaction between plaintiff and defendant which would automatically categorize the transaction as corporate business and where retention of the fiction would have produced injustice and inequitable consequences, and (2) where plaintiff loaned $1,200 to codefendant so that codefendant could pay the same to defendant as a condition of obtaining a new loan from defendant and defendant guaranteed repayment to plaintiff if codefendant failed to pay back the $1,200 or any part thereof, case was not within the statute of frauds since the transaction was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Associated Coal Sales Corp. v. Hughes
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Where none of the allegedly wrongful acts were attributable to one corporate defendant, and where, even if other corporate defendant was a division of the first corporate defendant and a wholly owned subsidiary of a subsidiary thereof, they were separate corporations and there was no claim of fraud or illegality which would justify piercing the corporate veil, the complaint did not state a cause of action against the first corporation.
Document Preview: Appeals were taken from orders of the Supreme Court, New York County, Hyman Korn, J., entered in action involving contract dispute. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) complaint stated no cause of action against one defendant; (2) claim predicated on an unsigned exclusive five-year agency which provided for commissions or bonuses pursuant to renewal or modification of export orders or supply commitments was barred by the statute of frauds, and (3) contracting party may not allege a conspiracy to breach the contract. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Jennings v. Speaker
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Where there was no business reason for retention of earnings in holding company which was wholly owned by inter vivos trust other than to convert income to principle at expense of income beneficiary of trust, court acted properly in exercising its equitable power to ignore corporate entity of holding company and to require trustees to account for corporate earnings as if they had held corporate assets directly.
Document Preview: In a dispute between the income beneficiary and the remaindermen under an express inter vivos trust over the right to earnings of a holding company owned by the trust, the District Court, Wyandotte County, Joe H. Swinehart, J., held, in essence, that the income beneficiary was entitled to all the corporate earnings, whether paid out of dividends or not, and cross appeals were filed. The Court of Appeals, Foth, J., held, inter alia, that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in ignoring the separate corporate entity of the wholly-owned holding company and treating its assets as if they were owned directly by the trustees. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Tennessee Public Service Commission v. Nashville Gas Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee.
Headnote: Tennessee Public Service Commission is not bound in all instances to observe corporate charters and form of corporate structure or stock ownership in regulating a public utility and in fixing fair and reasonable rates for its operations. T.C.A. §§ 4-507 et seq., 65-220.
Document Preview: Gas utility filed complaint alleging that rate structure authorized by Tennessee Public Service Commission was confiscatory. The Equity Court, Davidson County, Ben H. Cantrell, Chancellor, resolved most of disputed issues in favor of Commission and generally approved its order, but as to issues which were resolved in favor of utility, Commission appealed. The Supreme Court, Harbison, J., held that: (1) operations and revenues of parent corporation were a proper and relevant consideration for Commission in fixing reasonable rates for subsidiary; (2) a fundamental principle of rate making was not violated by Commission when it failed to separate interstate from intrastate operations where it was clear that Federal Power Commission only partially regulated operations of parent and that prices charged by parent to its customers were not regulated; (3) it was within jurisdiction of Commission to determine that it did not have enough information about present contracts, depreciation...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: BeWigged by Suzzi, Inc. v. Atlantic Dept. Stores, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: In replevin and conversion action brought by corporation which sought to recover goods, or value of goods, seized by defendant department store chain, trial court incorrectly determined that separate corporate entity of plaintiff corporation could be disregarded simply because certain individual was president and sole stockholder of such corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, corporation engaged in business of selling wigs to retail customers, brought replevin and conversion action seeking punitive damages and seeking to recover goods, or value of goods, seized by defendant department store chain, and defendant filed counterclaim for monies allegedly due under license agreement. The Court of Common Pleas, Cuyahoga County, entered judgment in favor of defendant on plaintiff's claim and under settlement agreement on counterclaim, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Jackson, J., held that plaintiff obtained license and not leasehold interest after termination of license agreement between defendant and plaintiff's sole stockholder and therefore plaintiff, as licensee, was only under such obligation as could fairly be implied from conduct of parties, and previous license agreement did not control; that in view of absence of evidence suggesting that plaintiff had given defendant lien upon its property, none could be said to exist and,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Dean Van Lines, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: While Belgian subsidiary corporation, which from 1965 to 1967 acted as freight forwarder for a federal agency, overcharged the United States by the amount of certain undisclosed rebates, the overcharge could not be recovered from the subsidiary's American parent corporation on a theory of unjust enrichment, even though, after the overcharge occurred, the parent sold subsidiary's stock and, in the Government's view, allegedly received a price inflated by the amount of the overcharge, where the parent was admittedly not the "alter ego" of its subsidiary nor were the facts sufficient to "pierce the corporate veil," where there had been no liquidation of the subsidiary, and where there was no showing that the Government could not pursue its claim directly against the subsidiary.
Document Preview: United States brought suit against Belgian subsidiary's American corporate parent, seeking an accounting and collection of overcharges made by the subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, at Jacksonville, Charles R. Scott, J., entered judgment for the Government on a theory of unjust enrichment, and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dyer, Circuit Judge, held that while the Belgian subsidiary, which from 1965 to 1967 acted as freight forwarder for a federal agency, overcharged the United States by the amount of certain undisclosed rebates it received from steamship lines, the overcharge could not be recovered from the subsidiary's American parent on a theory of unjust enrichment, even though, after the overcharge occurred, the parent sold the subsidiary's stock and, in the Government's view, allegedly received a price inflated by the amount of the overcharge, where the parent was admittedly not the alter ego of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Fidelity & Deposit Co. of Maryland v. USAFORM Hail Pool, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where to disregard distinctive corporate identities would work injustice, corporate form would not be disregarded.
Document Preview: Various corporations in a corporate complex controlled by one dominant shareholder were insured by fidelity bond and the insurer brought action for declaratory judgment with respect to liability on the bond. A judgment for the defendants, 318 F.Supp. 1301, was vacated and remanded in part and affirmed in part, 463 F.2d 4. On remand, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida at Jacksonville, Charles R. Scott, J., made findings and entered judgment from which the insurer appealed. The Court of Appeals, Wisdom, Circuit Judge, held that the trial court had acted properly in vacating and reentering its judgment under rule authorizing relief from final judgments, so as to permit an appeal which had not earlier been timely taken. The Court then held that the burden was upon the insurer, seeking to defeat recovery on the bond, to establish the legitimacy of various payments and transfers by some of the corporations. The separate corporate existence of various...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Freeman v. Sturdivant Development Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where optionee assigned option to corporation under contract whereby assignee would pay an additional $15,000 if, during the terms of the option or an extension thereof, a firm financial commitment was obtained for construction of an apartment complex on the optioned property and where second corporation having the same president and same secretary as the assignee ultimately obtained financing and derived benefits from assignor's original option, assignor could recover against both corporations on quantum meruit if jury were to find that the two corporations were one and the same.
Document Preview: Action was brought by assignor of option against assignee and another corporation to recover $15,000 allegedly due under assignment contract or, in the alternative, to recover in quantum meruit for services rendered, and defendants counterclaimed seeking damages for fraud. The Superior Court, Catawba County, Dennis J. Winner, J., denied defendants' motion for summary judgment, granted directed verdict for plaintiff on counterclaim, and granted directed verdict for plaintiff on contract claim against assignee but against plaintiff on quantum meruit claim against assignee and on both claims against the other defendant, and all parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Arnold, J., held that with respect to assignor's contract with assignee whereby assignee was to pay assignor an additional $15,000 if during the term of the option or any extension thereof assignee obtained a firm financial commitment for the construction of an apartment complex on the optioned property, genuine issue...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Nelson v. Control Systems Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Where it was clear that individual was sole owner of corporation to which money was due and was authorized to act for corporation, and parties treated individual and corporation as one and the same, debtor could not avoid liability on basis that money was due corporation, not individual who brought suit.
Document Preview: Suit to recover moneys allegedly due pursuant to provisions of contract. The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, No. 532749, Division C, Richard J. Garvey, J., found for plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeal, Boutall, J., held that in view of language of contract in its entirety, provision under which stockholder who, in addition to purchasing one-third of corporation's stock, loaned money to enable corporation to commence business, was to receive salary equal to one-half of combined salary and expenses of highest paid corporate employee would terminate at time money loaned corporation was repaid, and that defendant could not avoid liability on debt on basis that debt was owed to corporation, not individual plaintiff. Reversed in part, amended in part, affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Peters v. Golds
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a "professional corporation" is to be treated exactly as an individual member of the profession.
Document Preview: Malpractice action against individuals and a professional corporation. The District Court, Joiner, J., held that the action against the corporation was not barred by the Michigan two-year statute of limitations for any wrongful acts performed by any of its members if it was shown that one of the members treated the plaintiff within the two-year period. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Jolin v. Oster
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Where plaintiff's cause of action was for breach of fiduciary relationship between parties as joint adventurers and was not based on relationship which existed between them as stockholders in corporation which the joint adventure formed, the judgment in favor of plaintiff did not constitute a piercing of the corporate veil in derogation of the rights of the corporation's creditors and other stockholders.
Document Preview: Action for breach of fiduciary obligations created by alleged joint venture agreement between plaintiff and defendant who operated business through corporation. After remand, 44 Wis.2d 623, 172 N.W.2d 12, the Circuit Court, Milwaukee County, Michael T. Sullivan, J., rendered judgment for the plaintiff and the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Wilkie, J., held that evidence warranted submission to jury of issue of whether the parties intended to establish joint venture to form corporation for recreational land development and for the joint venture to survive the corporation. Affirmed. Heffernan, J., did not participate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: City of Los Angeles v. Public Utilities Commission
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: Where it appears that utility is dominant, it may not through use of corporate instrumentalities obtain a greater rate of return than it would be entitled to in the absence of such; it is not determinative whether the prices charged by one affiliated corporation to another might be considered reasonable; the utility enterprise must be viewed as a whole without regard to the separate corporate entities and rate of return should be the same for the entire utility enterprise.
Document Preview: Consolidated proceeding to review decision of Public Utilities Commission authorizing intrastate telephone rate increases. The Supreme Court, Peters, J., held that where portions of Public Utilities Commission's decision dealing with treatment of federal and state tax expense, adjustment of price paid for equipment to related corporation and certain capital expenditures which did not increase revenue could not be sustained on the record and it was possible that amount of money involved was equal to or exceeded the amount of the increase, the order increasing rates must be annulled in its entirety and Commission must reinstate rates of its last preceding lawful order, but it might grant interim rate increases upon appropriate findings. Mosk, J., filed concurring and dissenting opinion. Schauer, retired Associate Justice of Supreme Court, sat under assignment by Chairman of the Judicial Council.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Eagle Star Ins. Co. v. Deal
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Arkansas, Fayetteville Division.
Headnote: Where corporation, stock of which was wholly owned by orthodontist and which had been formed to furnish laboratory services generally to dentists, operated as a corporate entity and in a lawful manner, the corporate veil would not, under Arkansas law, be pierced for purpose of finding that five females, who were listed as corporate employees and who met their death in crash of orthodontist's aircraft while en route to orthodontist's branch office, were employees of orthodontist within meaning of orthodontist's aircraft policy excluding coverage for death of any employee while engaged in duties of employment.
Document Preview: Action by aircraft insurer seeking declaration of rights, duties and other legal relations between it and estate of insured, who along with five passengers, was killed in crash of insured aircraft. The District Court, John E. Miller, Senior District Judge, held that where corporation, stock of which was wholly owned by orthodontist and which had been formed to furnish laboratory services generally to dentists, operated as a corporate entity and in a lawful manner, the corporate veil would not, under Arkansas law, be pierced for purpose of finding that five females, who were listed as corporate employees and who met their death in crash of orthodontist's aircraft while en route to orthodontist's branch office, were employees of orthodontist within meaning of orthodontist's aircraft policy excluding coverage for death of any employee while engaged in duties of employment. In addition, the Court held that aircraft was being used within limits of insurance coverage at...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: General Tel. Co. of Southwest v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where purpose of the Communications Act could be easily frustrated through use of separate corporate entities, the Federal Communications Commission is entitled to look through corporate form and treat the separate entities as one and the same for purposes of regulation. Communications Act of 1934, §§ 1, 214 as amended 47 U.S.C.A. §§ 151, 214.
Document Preview: Proceeding on consolidated petitions to review orders of the Federal Communications Commission prohibiting telephone companies from furnishing CATV service in their telephone service areas, either directly or through affiliates, and disallowing construction by them of cable facilities for independent CATV operators unless carrier first offers to such operators the option of placing their own cables on the carriers' poles. The Court of Appeals, Tuttle, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that federal communications commission was not without statutory authority to issue rules. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: S. O. U. P., Inc. v. F. T. C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate form is convenient, organizational vehicle, but its convenience does not justify turning it into vehicle also for avoiding costs involved in lawsuit as if it were pauper. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1915(a).
Document Preview: Proceeding upon motion to proceed in forma pauperis on petition for review of an order of the Federal Trade Commission. The Court of Appeals held that where the costs of the review proceeding were not likely to exceed $100 and members of the petitioning corporation were able to pay same, the corporation would not be allowed to proceed in forma pauperis notwithstanding the good faith of its members and their public interest motivation. Motion denied. Bazelon, Chief Judge, dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Collins Pipeline Co. v. New Orleans East, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: That all the stock of corporate owner of interstate pipeline was owned by two entities, which were not common carriers of petroleum products, did not render corporation alter ego of such stockholders, and thus corporation was common carrier of petroleum products with right to expropriate. LSA-R.S. 45:251, 45:254; Interstate Commerce Act, § 1(1) (b), (3) (a), 49 U.S.C.A. § 1(1) (b), (3) (a).
Document Preview: Suit for expropriation of pipeline servitude. The Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans, No. 502522, Division B, Clarence Dowling, J., granted judgment of expropriation which fixed just compensation at $135,000. Landowner appealed. The Court of Appeal, Chasez, J., held that even though two entities, which owned all the stock of corporate owner of interstate pipeline, would initially be the only users of pipeline in question in suit for expropriation, taking of property was for public purpose, in view of shortage of pipeline, statutory requirement that common carrier allow third parties to use pipeline, and expression of interest in use of pipeline by other parties. The Court further held that where property on which expropriation of pipeline servitude was sought was variously zoned in places as commercial, residential, industrial and heavy industrial, property owner was entitled to severance damages for strip contiguous to servitude. Affirmed in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Pearl v. Shore
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Where difficulties of corporation, which was capitalized at $100,000 and which was general partner in partnership involving purchase of land and construction of apartment houses thereon, were apparently attributable to poor management rather than to initial undercapitalization and where there was complete lack of showing of bad faith by shareholder, who held 25% of stock, who had nothing to do with day to day operation of corporation, who advanced funds when additional funds for down payments on new properties were needed, and who had had nothing to do with limited partner, such limited partner, who had invested funds in partnership, was not entitled to recover from shareholder under alter ego theory.
Document Preview: Action by limited partners, who had invested in partnership involving purchase of land and construction of apartment houses, to recover from shareholders of corporate general partner. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Max Z. Wisot, J., granted one shareholder's motion to strike and dismiss first amended complaint, and limited partner appealed. The Court of Appeal, Kaus, P.J., held that where difficulties of corporation, which was capitalized at $100,000, were apparently attributable to poor management rather than to initial undercapitalization, and where there was complete lack of showing of bad faith with respect to shareholder, who held 25% Of stock, who had nothing to do with day to day operation of corporation, who advanced funds when additional funds for down payments on new properties were needed, and who had had nothing to do with limited partner, limited partner was not entitled to recover from such shareholder under alter ego theory. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Harrison v. Puga
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1, Panel Two.
Headnote: Where defendant stripped corporation of all its assets and took substantial assets in his own name for which he refused to account to corporation, he could not complain that court judged him by his conduct and likewise disregarded corporate entity to enforce right owed to persons dealing with corporation.
Document Preview: Action for monies advanced or paid. From a judgment of the Superior Court, King County, William J., Wilkins, J., in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Horowitz, Acting, C.J., held that in the absence of a provision in a contract making time of the essence or providing for a forfeiture, where plaintiffs never abandoned their efforts to obtain financing and defendant waived a deadling by accepting payments after the deadline, defendant who had conditionally agreed to gransfer his cable television system to a corporation could not legally forfeit the contract without prior notice giving plaintiffs reasonable opportunity to perform, and the failure to given such notice was a breach of contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Margarine Verkaufsunion G.m.B.H. v. M.T.G.C. Brovig
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
