J., held that the action must be dismissed, if such documents are not produced by plaintiff in obedience to established court procedures, but that the effective date of the dismissal order would be suspended...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Belle City Packing Co. v. R.F.C.
Court: United States Emergency Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Where note of processor or purveyor of meat was held by majority stockholder of nonprocessing slaughterer in an individual capacity and was acquired before the organization of the nonprocessing slaughterer, such fact did not render the nonprocessing slaughterer ineligible to receive special subsidiary. Emergency Price Control Act of 1942, § 1 et seq., 50 U.S.C.A.Appendix, § 901 et seq.
Document Preview: Suit by Belle City Packing Company against Reconstruction Finance Corporation to review determination by the defendant that complainant was ineligible during certain monthly accounting periods to receive the special subsidy payable to non-processing slaughterers of cattle under the regulations issued by the Defense Supplies Corporation. Determination set aside and order denying protest set aside and cause remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Transamerica General Corp. v. Zunino
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Trial Term, Part VI.
Headnote: Fact that corporations were closely intertwined by stock ownership and interlocking officers and directors did not establish that corporations were so essentially one and the same, that payment to one would be payment of the other.
Document Preview: Action by Transamerica General Corporation against Frank A. Zunino to recover a debt assigned to the plaintiff, wherein the defendant interposed a defense of payment. Defense held sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: International Aircraft Trading Co. v. Manufacturers Trust Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Where drawer of check dealt with individual corporate officers and on their representations made check payable to nonexistent corporation, drawer's bank could not avoid liability for charging his account with the check so drawn on theory that corporate veil ought to be pierced and loss be visited upon drawer, where elementary precautions of forwarding bank against whom drawer's bank had remedy would have prevented the wrong.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department. Action by International Aircraft Trading Company, Inc., against Manufacturers Trust Company to recover an amount charged to plaintiff's account upon cashing a check payable to the order of a nonexistent payee, wherein defendant cross-complained against the impleaded the Irving Trust Company as a defendant. From a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department entered May 20, 1947, 272 App.Div. 795, 71 N.Y.S.2d 923, unanimously affirming the judgment of the Supreme Court at a Trial Term for the defendant and entered in New York County dismissing the complaint on the merits, 184 Misc. 137, 53 N.Y.S.2d 200, Hofstadter, J., plaintiff appeals, and from that part of the judgment dismissing its cross-claim against impleaded defendant on the merits, defendant Manufacturers Trust Company cross-appeals by permission of the Court of Appeals. Judgment reversed with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Schenstrom v. Continental Machines
Court: District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Where partnership which was exclusive sales outlet of foreign corporation's products carried on its business in New York as a distinct entity, separate and apart from corporation, with all indicia of separate business, corporation was not "doing business within the state" notwithstanding partnership was a subsidiary of corporation.
Document Preview: Action by William Schenstrom against Continental Machines, Inc., for alleged breach of contract. On defendant's motion to set aside a service of summons on ground that it was not served upon a person authorized to receive it. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Consolidated Realty Co. v. Dyers, Finishers and Bleachers Federation
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: In corporate landlord's suit to enjoin labor unions from interfering with delivery of fuel oil and coal to complainant for use of its tenants, including corporate employer, owned and controlled by and having same officers and office manager as complainant, court will look through corporate forms to realities and disregard corporate identities in order to give defendants' claimed rights equitable consideration.
Document Preview: Suit in equity by the Consolidated Realty Company against the Dyers, Finishers and Bleachers Federation and others for injunction against interference with delivery of fuel oil and coal to complainant. On an order to show cause why defendants should not be restrained from interfering with such delivery until final hearing. Restraint pendente lite denied, and order to show cause discharged.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Gruenebaum v. Lissauer
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: A Dutch corporation doing business as permitted by laws of Netherlands is an entity recognized by the law, and has an independent life, and hence no liability for wrong done by such corporation can be asserted against its controlling stockholder.
Document Preview: Action by Arthur Gruenebaum, suing on behalf of himself and all other creditors of N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, and of Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, similarly situated, against Meno Lissauer and another, individually and as members of the firm of M. Lissauer & Cie., N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, and another. On motion of the defendants Meno Lissauer, Walter Rothschild, and Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation to dismiss the complaint pursuant to rule 106 of the Rules of Civil Practice, or, in the alternative, for an order pursuant to rule 103 striking out certain allegations of the complaint upon ground that they are irrelevant and scandalous and for an order pursuant to rule 90 directing the service of an amended complaint separately stating the several causes of action alleged in the complaint. Orders in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chapman v. Sky L'Onda Mut. Water Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Court was not compelled as matter of law to disregard corporate entity of mutual water company organized to supply water to owners of lots in subdivision who held stock in company as appurtenant to their lots so as to defeat company's claim to easement by prescription to maintain reservoirs, pumps, and pipe lines on other land retained by owner when land was conveyed for purpose of subdivision, on ground that promoters and directors of water company had recognized owner's superior rights and therefore company's possession was permissive and not adverse.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, San Mateo County; Maxwell McNutt, Judge. Action in ejectment by Frank F. Chapman against Sky L'Onda Mutual Water Company, a corporation, and others to oust defendant company from certain land used by it as reservoir sites, wherein defendants filed a cross-complaint. Upon death of plaintiff, William Chapman, executor, and Mary Klitgaard, executrix, of the estate of Frank F. Chapman, deceased, were substituted as plaintiffs. Judgment for defendant water company, and substituted plaintiffs appeal. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Chelrob, Inc. v. Barrett
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Liability of one corporation with respect to transactions with subsidiary corporation arises not from the power of control, but from breach of the duty which accompanies it.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department. Consolidated actions by Chelrob, Inc., and another, suing on their own behalf and on behalf of all other stockholders of Queens Borough Gas & Electric Company similarly situated, against Edward F. Barrett and others for accounting and damages alleged to have been suffered by Queens Borough Gas & Electric Company as a result of selling gas to its subsidiary Nassau & Suffolk Lighting Company, at alleged inadequate prices which were allegedly fixed by defendant Long Island Lighting Company, a stockholder in the Queens Borough Gas & Electric Company, for its own interest. From a judgment, entered upon an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Second Judicial Department, 265 App.Div. 455,266 App.Div. 669,39 N.Y.S.2d 625, which reversed, on the law and the facts, a judgment of the Supreme Court in favor of defendant Queens Borough Gas & Electric Company and against defendants Long...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Knecht v. George
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, First District, Hamilton County.
Headnote: Neither trustee nor beneficiaries of trust could hide behind a wholly owned subsidiary in their dealings relative to the trust property with third persons.
Document Preview: Action by Harold C. Knecht against Jacob George, and others, for partition, for an accounting, appointment of a receiver, a sale of the real estate, and distribution of the proceeds and for declaratory judgment. From an adverse judgment of court of common pleas, plaintiff appeals on question at law.[Editorial Statement.] Judgment affirmed. Appeal dismissed 142 Ohio St. 635, 53 N.E.2d 647.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Marshall Transport Co. v. U.S.
Court: District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: An application by corporate motor vehicle common carrier of petroleum products to Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to consummate sale to applicant of certain operating rights, motor vehicles, and equipment by another such carrier was made by "real party in interest", though majority of applicant's stock was owned by non-carrier corporation, in view of difference between corporation and its stockholders. Interstate Commerce Act, § 5(2) (a, b), 49 U.S.C.A. § 5(2) (a, v).
Document Preview: Action by the Marshall Transport Company, the Refiners Transport Terminal Corporation, and another for a temporary restraining order and an injunction to stay enforcement of and set aside an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission dismissing plaintiffs' application for authority to consummate a sale of motor vehicle common carrier operating rights, motor vehicles, equipment, and facilities to last-named plaintiff, and for a mandatory injunction requiring the commission to take jurisdiction of and consider the application, in which the Commission and others intervened. Judgment for plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: No. 37 and No. 39 Attorney St. v. Kirshbaum
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Where defendant had assisted his deceased father in management of real estate which was owned by corporation which was alter ego of deceased father, defendant, as a fiduciary, was obliged to account to corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, New York County; Samuel H. Hofstadter, Justice. Action by No. 37 and No. 39 Attorney Street, Inc., against Julius Kirshbaum to require defendant to account for rents collected by him. From a judgment of the Supreme Court, entered upon a referee's report, directing recovery in plaintiff's favor for $38,204.93, and from the order of reference, defendant appeals. Appeal from order dismissed, and judgment reversed, and matter remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: In re Lawyers Mortg. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: A safe deposit company did not become instrumentality of mortgage company merely because mortgage company owned all of safe deposit company's stock except that owned by safe deposit company's directors, where it did not appear that mortgage company ever profited by any use of the assets of safe deposit company.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department. Proceeding in the matter of the rehabilitation of Lawyers Mortgage Company. From an order of the Appellate Division, 259 App.Div. 889, 20 N.Y.S.2d 408, which affirmed an order of the Special Term, 259 App.Div. 735, 19 N.Y.S.2d 651, Brooklyn Trust Company as trustee be authorized and directed to register certain certificates of the mortgage company owned by Superintendent of Insurance of the state of New York as liquidator of the company on a parity with all other outstanding certificates opposed by Louis H. Pink as Superintendent of Insurance of the state of New York as liquidator of the Lawyers Mortgage Company. The following question was certified: Should Brooklyn Trust Company, as trustee for certificate holders, be directed to register Certificate No. 72 of Lawyers Mortgage Company, Series No. 200643, now owned by the Superintendent of Insurance of the state of New York, as Liquidator of Lawyers Mortgage...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Nettles v. Rhett
Court: District Court, E.D. South Carolina.
Headnote: In South Carolina, where bank stock is held by corporation, equity court will look through corporate entity and assess statutory liability against stockholders as real owners of bank stock, if stock was transferred to corporation to avoid liability, or if corporate form of organization was adopted in endeavor to evade statute or modify its intent. Code S.C.1942, § 7677, par. 5.
Document Preview: Action by Joseph L. Nettles, as receiver of the stockholders' liability of the Peoples State Bank of South Carolina, against R. G. Rhett and others. Complaint dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Nettles v. Rhett
Court: District Court, E.D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Joint adventurers, partnerships, and owners of stock of holding corporations may be sued and on proper showing held liable as true owners of bank stock issued to trustees, agents, or corporations, and corporate fiction will be set aside in interests of justice when necessary.
Document Preview: In Equity.  Suit by Joseph L. Nettles, as receiver of the Stockholders' Liability of the Peoples State Bank of South Carolina, against R. G. Rhett and others, and Bernard M. Baruch and others.  On plaintiff's motion to remand. Motion to remand denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1058 In general >
Title: Sunapee Dam Corp. v. Alexander
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: In determining liability of owners of power in river which dam corporation served for assessments for maintenance of dam, especially where corporation traced its corporate existence to special act of incorporation enacted in 1820, nature of a "corporation" was required to be viewed as an association formed by agreement of its shareholders, and as an outgrowth of law of partnership, rather than as an entity separate and insulated from those composing it. 8 Laws, 1820, p. 927.
Document Preview: Transferred from Superior Court, Sullivan County; Sawyer, Judge. Bill by the Sunapee Dam Corporation against George Alexander and others. Case transferred from the trial court for determination of main question involved and exceptions to rulings of the master. Case discharged.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TIG Insurance Company v. Republic of Argentina
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: A contract may be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Agreement was made by sovereign, within meaning of FSIA's arbitration exception, if it legally bound sovereign to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who paid to set up funding companies and continued to fund them exercised requisite level of control over companies with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased healthcare facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments of specified amounts over set period of time, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; although he was not on-paper owner or named director of companies, he made decisions on how and when MCA deals were made by companies that did not follow corporate formalities and effectively existed on paper only.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, manager of two entities that funded and provided management services for two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which funding companies purchased healthcare facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments of specified amounts over set period of time, did not exercise requisite level of control over companies to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory in order to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; although he signed settlement agreements on behalf of companies, at most he was companies' authorized representative, and his receipt of profits as syndicate member on some MCA deals did not equate to controlling companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who exercised requisite level of control over funding companies used his control to perpetrate fraud or wrongdoing against healthcare facility with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; companies were formed for fraudulent purpose, companies and transactions had no connection to Connecticut, and he intentionally structured companies to obfuscate his control implicitly to avoid liability for any wrongful act under their name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the instrumentality rule for determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, ordinarily, breach of contract standing alone is insufficient to prove the element of using control over the corporate entity to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; however, a breach of contract coupled with a showing that a the corporation was formed for an improper purpose, such as forming a corporation to shelter oneself from personal obligations incurred prior to the formation of the corporation or to commit or to avoid liability for any personal wrongful act, is sufficient.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who exercised requisite level of control over funding companies and used his control to perpetrate fraud or wrongdoing against healthcare facility with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments, proximately caused facility's monetary injury from companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility, thus justifying piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach, with result that he was liable for $50,071.77 that facility was over-charged on one agreement and for $170,000 that facility was over-charged on another agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chubb Capital I Limited v. New Orleans City
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, a corporation may be bound by an agreement entered into by its subsidiary regardless of the agreement's structure or the subsidiary's attempts to bind itself alone to its terms, when their conduct demonstrates a virtual abandonment of separateness.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Arbitration and Appraisal. Insurers, who were non-signatories to arbitration agreement, did not agree to arbitrate city's claims against insureds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pentacon BV v. Vanderhaegen
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits non-signatories to be held liable for breach of contract under limited circumstances, namely, where the non-signatory (1) is the alter ego of the signatory, (2) manifests an intent to be bound by the contract, or (3) acts so as to show they are in privity of contract or assumed obligations under the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Alleged sale of start-up after no sale period, which was planned during such period, did not violate no sale clause of share redemption agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, while it is generally true that only parties to contract are liable for its breach, traditional principles of law allow contract to be enforced by or against nonparties through, among other things, theory of alter ego.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, alter ego is not a claim for substantive relief, but rather a remedial theory in equity under which the corporate entity is disregarded and individuals or entities are held liable on the obligations of the corporation, including those obligations arising from breach of contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ward
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Valdosta Division.
Headnote: Creditors failed to pierce the corporate veil under Georgia law in nondischargeability proceeding so as to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for his businesses' debts arising from contracts to build pools at creditors' residences; there was no evidence that debtor abused the corporate forms to perpetuate alleged fraud against creditors, but rather, businesses filed their own consolidated tax returns, maintained balance sheets and other corporate accounting records, had their own bank accounts separate from debtor, maintained their own business address not at debtor's personal address, used form contracts with the name of the company on the header, and had many employees other than debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditors failed to pierce the corporate veil under Georgia law so as to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for his businesses' debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute fraud or wrong warranting piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. v. 29-33 Ninth Avenue, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law provides that a court may pierce the veil and bind a non-signatory to a contract's terms in certain circumstances.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Interpleader. Bank accounts frozen after bank received notice of conflict concerning them constituted identifiable res, as required for interpleader action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a breach of contract is sufficient to satisfy the fraud or wrong element of an alter ego claim.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mohawk Construction and Supply Company, Inc. v. Walsh/Consigli JV
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted to hold limited liability company (LLC) and company, which were related to joint venture but were not themselves part of the joint venture, liable for joint venture's alleged breach of construction subcontract, absent showing that LLC and company dominated the entities involved in the joint venture or that such domination was used to wrong the subcontractor.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Limited liability company and company related to joint venture were not liable for breach of subcontract between joint venture and subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Compass Concierge, LLC v. 142 Duane Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Authorized signatory for property owner, a corporation, in a renovation-services agreement between owner and real estate brokerage was not himself a party to the contract, and thus brokerage could not recover for breach of contract against signatory, absent either a showing that the contract suggested that the parties intended to bind signatory personally or a showing of facts supporting the piercing of the corporate veil to hold signatory personally liable for owner's alleged breach of the contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Real estate brokerage could not recover for breach of contract against authorized signatory for corporation in brokerage's contract with corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Plan B Holdings, LLC v. RSLLP
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: There are limited circumstances under which nonparty to contract may nonetheless be bound by it, including under an alter-ego theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could pierce the corporate veil to hold sole owner of LLCs personally liable for unpaid attorney's fees under an alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations requires plaintiff to show that shareholder or affiliate caused corporation to be used to perpetrate and did perpetrate actual fraud on obligee, and that fraud was primarily for direct personal benefit of holder, beneficial owner, subscriber, or affiliate. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: "Actual fraud," as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, is distinct from the tort of fraud and only requires a plaintiff to show dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: In assessing whether there was actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, courts may deduce fraudulent intent from all of the facts and circumstances. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: In assessing whether there was actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, courts generally look at the totality of a shareholder's actions to determine whether he committed actual fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: If funds are only used for corporation's benefit or are diverted to other ventures, limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law applies, and plaintiff's claim against shareholder or affiliate fails. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in business-transaction context that might be routine in vacuum, actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations, can be inferred from proximity or volume of transactions in context with other circumstances. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rogers v. Tug Hill Operating, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Circumstances in which a nonparty to a contract may be entitled to enforce it under standard contract principles include assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Arbitration. Oil and gas operator was not a third party beneficiary entitled to enforce arbitration agreement to which it was not a party in foreman's FLSA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Riverview Carpet & Flooring, Inc. v. Presbyterian SeniorCare
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Facilities management company's employee, who performed work for senior living facility operator, and employee's friends, who were architect and certified public accountant (CPA), created and used general contractor to perpetrate fraud, and thus, justice demanded piercing general contractor's corporate veil and holding CPA, as its 20% shareholder, directly liable for general contractor's breach of contractual obligations to pay renovation subcontractors; general contractor was formed solely as part of fraudulent scheme to overcharge operator for renovations, general contractor itself did no work and was never used for legitimate business ends, corporate and personal affairs were intermingled, and defrauded parties could not recover damages from general contractor, which was insolvent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Senior living facility operator's oral guaranty of general contractor's debts to subcontractors was enforceable under leading object rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly alleged that another factoring company was the "mere instrumentality" of assignor and the two entities were thus a single entity, for purposes of liability for breach of assignment agreement under Michigan law, by alleging that assignor and its alleged alter ego shared principal offices and staff, as alleged alter ego had no employees of its own but instead relied on assignor's employees to act on its behalf, and assignor and alleged alter ego did business under the same name and the entities transferred dealer's funds between one another.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Breach of contract can satisfy "fraud or wrong" element for piercing corporate veil under Michigan law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in an appropriate case, one company's conduct may be attributed to another for the purposes of establishing breach of contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt adequately alleged an injurious fraud or wrong for veil-piercing liability under Michigan law by alleging that assignor received the benefits of its alleged alter ego's contract with dealer, despite being prohibited by terms of assignment agreement from entering its own contract with dealer, and that assignor knowingly used alleged alter ego to avoid the assignment and take funds from dealer that should have been paid to assignee.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt adequately alleged an unjust loss or injury from breach of contract for veil-piercing liability under Michigan law by alleging that assignor used alleged alter ego to obtain funds from dealer that should have been paid to assignee, in violation of assignment agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York, Connecticut, or Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, at time he transferred holding company's assets to family trust and others, holding company's owner lacked specific intent to evade company's liability for margin calls bank made upon discovering insufficient collateral for company's risky trading, weighing against piercing corporate veil and holding owner personally liable for judgment that English court entered against company in bank's underlying breach-of-contract action, where owner reasonably believed, based on information then available to him, that he left enough money in company's accounts at bank to cover company's potential loss exposure, and owner expressed genuine shock upon learning of shortfall in company's accounts at bank after he made transfers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York, Connecticut, or Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, losses bank incurred when holding company failed to pay final margin call bank issued resulted directly and in large part from bank's own negligence and incompetence, weighing against piercing corporate veil and holding company's owner personally liable for judgment that English court entered against company in bank's underlying breach-of-contract action, where bank agreed to provide back-office services for company's risky derivatives trading without obtaining personal guarantee from company's owner and without being able to understand and accurately value company's trades or margin its accounts, resulting in bank failing to notice company's massive loss exposure and shortfall in company's accounts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brandsway Hospitality, LLC. v. Delshah Capital LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There is no independent cause of action to pierce the corporate veil, and a breach of contract claim, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. Trial court providently denied plaintiff's motion for leave to amend to add a cause of action to pierce the corporate veil of defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Coons v. Yum! Brands, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Traditional principles of Illinois law generally allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Arbitration. Corporation that owned restaurant chain and its subsidiaries had right to enforce arbitration agreement between employee and franchisee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: G & Y Maintenance Corp. v. Core Continental Construction LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Using one's domination and control to cause another to breach its contractual obligations is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil, as necessary to support a claim against the person exercising domination and control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Corporation failed to allege basis to pierce corporate veil and assert claim against limited liability company (LLC) president for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent corporation can be held liable for the breach of a contract signed by its subsidiary if (1) its intent to be bound by the contract were inferable from the parent's participation in the negotiation of the contract, (2) if the subsidiary is a dummy for the parent, or (3) if the subsidiary is controlled by the parent for the parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and allow suit against a non-party parent as an alter ego of a signatory to a contract, a court assesses whether (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, an ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Naranjo v. Nick's Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to contract through assumption, piercing corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Exotic dancer's claims for unpaid wages were not mooted when club sent check to her for wages that would have been due had she been an employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, whether a plaintiff may pierce an entity's veil pursuant to either the alter ego theory or the sham to perpetrate a fraud theory depends on whether the plaintiff's claims sound in tort or contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, whereas a tort claimant may freely pierce the veil under either the alter ego theory or the sham to perpetrate a fraud theory, a contract claimant may only pierce the veil if the defendant has also committed an actual fraud against the plaintiff for the defendant's direct personal benefit. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, exclusive licensee of disinfectant adequately alleged that licensor was organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of founding company, so they were part of single business enterprise, as required to treat licensor as company's alter ego and pierce corporate veil for breach of contract claim; licensee alleged that company's owners created licensor as shell entity mere weeks before negotiating with licensee to knowingly sell defective product and insulate company from liability, while sales revenue went directly to company, that licensor communicated with licensee via company's officers and employees using company's email accounts and signature blocks, and that company intended to deceive licensee as to product's quality and ability to destroy COVID-19 virus. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "actual fraud" required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is defined as involving dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in the context of piercing the corporate veil for contract claims, actual fraud is not equivalent to the tort of fraud; indeed, the requirements for showing actual fraud are less burdensome than those for establishing fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in practice, courts may deduce fraudulent intent required to establish actual fraud necessary to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims from all of the facts and circumstances of a given case. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the appropriate counterpart to actual fraud required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is not fraud but constructive fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "actual fraud" required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims involves dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive, whereas "constructive fraud" is the breach of some legal or equitable duty which, irrespective of moral guilt, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to injure public interests. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the very purpose of the intent inquiry in assessing actual fraud required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is to determine whether the defendant used otherwise legitimate corporate structures and procedures to achieve dishonest ends. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Etage Real Estate LLC v. Stern
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was not entitled to summary judgment on veil-piercing claim against 50% owners of nonparty judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hamilton v. Young Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted under Massachusetts law in order to bring within the jurisdiction of the district court either the successor to booking agent with which vacationer and her husband booked travel or an allegedly related partnership, in action brought by vacationer and husband, asserting claims for negligence and breach of contract, stemming from vacationer's injury at resort, despite their argument that agent, its successor, and partnership were alter egos of each other; although such entities had a common owner, shared an address, and had the common purpose of supporting owner's hotels, there was no evidence that owner disregarded corporate formalities, mixed assets among entities, or operated the companies as a front to perpetrate fraud or escape jurisdiction.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Booking agent availed itself of the privilege of conducting activities in forum state, thus subjecting it to jurisdiction in injured traveler's suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A breach of contract is not the type of fraud or wrongful act that will support an alter ego claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Estate of parent LLC succeeded to LLC's membership in special-purpose vehicle LLC, so automatic dissolution was not triggered for lack of members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hill International, Inc. v. JTS Realty Corporation
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation and affiliated limited liability company were operating in a single business enterprise with property developer bound by forensic accounting services contract with auditor, who was hired to conduct in-depth audit of costs billed to property developer by construction contractor, in auditor's open account action arising from unpaid invoices; entities had substantial identity of ownership, with same manager, office, in-house accountant, and corporate representative in open account action, all entities were in real estate business, whether in construction, development, or management, and it appeared entities were operating interchangeably.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation was operating in single business enterprise with property developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the veil and bind a non-signatory to a contract's terms where the non-signatory exercised complete control over a signatory and employed that domination to injure another signatory to the agreement.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts generally consider the following factors in determining whether domination over signatory by a non-signatory is present, for purposes of piercing of corporate veil to bind non-signatory to contract's terms: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, that is, issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff may bring breach of contract claim against counterparty-signatory's parent entity where the counterparty-signatory has been so dominated and its separate identity so disregarded that the counterparty-signatory primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, allegations of complete ownership, common officers and personnel, and shared office space are, without more, insufficient to impose contractual liability on a parent for its subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator adequately alleged that United States company was alter ego of Dubai company sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of United States company in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; operator alleged overlapping leadership and ownership of companies, as same individual acted as manager of Dubai company and director and registered agent for United States company and he acted as legal advisor to both companies, companies conducted the same type of business and sold same type of products under same terms and conditions, and parties used identical communication and use of web services.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual, a Greek citizen who acted as director and sole shareholder of Singapore company, manager of related Dubai company, and director and registered agent for related United States company, was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; individual's cross-involvement in companies did not justify disregarding corporate form of the entities, as there was no allegation that individual intermingled personal assets with the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Product Solutions International, Inc. v. Aldez Containers, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Company that provided new-product-development services did not plausibly allege any wrongdoing by purported affiliate of new-product developer, and thus, failed to state claims under Michigan law against affiliate for breach of contract, promissory estoppel, and non-acceptance of conforming goods under the Uniform Commercial Code; company alleged that new-product developer was agent, alter ego, and mere instrumentality of affiliate, but did not allege that purported affiliate was party to any contract, and piercing corporate veil was not cause of action under Michigan law.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Res judicata did not bar contract claims by company that provided new-product-development services against purported affiliate of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Highland Crusader Offshore Partners, L.P. v. Celtic Pharma Phinco B.V.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Bermuda law, veil piercing is not allowed where a counterparty knowingly contracts with a company rather than with an individual or other entity affiliated with the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff did not satisfy Bermuda-law requirements for piercing corporate veil of issuer and guarantors of notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: President of Canadian industrial equipment seller did not create new company, into which president transferred his 50% ownership interest in seller, with intent to make seller judgment-proof, and, thus, mere creation of new company did not constitute wrong sufficient under New York law to pierce corporate veil between seller on the one hand and president or new company on the other, where company was created for investment and tax planning purposes using structure common for such purposes in Canada.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, shareholder's creation of security interest in corporation's assets at time that shareholder sold half its shares in corporation to holding company did not constitute wrong sufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil in equipment buyer's breach-of-contract action against corporation, shareholder, and individual who owned shareholder and holding company and was president of corporation, where corporation remained profitable at time of security interest's creation, and no evidence suggested interest was created to render corporation judgment-proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, operation of nearly-insolvent corporation by its president and 50% shareholder, which was owned by president, did not constitute fraud or wrong justifying piercing corporate veil in buyer's action against corporation, president, and shareholder for breach of contract premised on corporation's sale of industrial equipment to buyer, where president and shareholder did not remove assets from corporation to render it judgment-proof, but, rather, shareholder repeatedly lent money to corporation to keep it at least temporarily solvent despite having no obligation to do so.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation's president and 50% shareholder, which was owned by president, did not exercise complete control over corporation with respect to its sale of industrial equipment to buyer, and, thus, under New York law, corporate veil could not be pierced in buyer's action against corporation, president, and shareholder for breach of contract for equipment sale, where at time of sale, president was not active in corporation and had backed away from involvement in transaction due to personal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporation's breach of contract for sale of industrial equipment to buyer, in and of itself, did not constitute fraud or wrong that would support piercing corporate veil between corporation and its president and shareholder.
