Title: Gecko Outdoor Products Corporation v. Casablanca Construction Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Non-performance of a contractual obligation does not justify disregarding the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Circumstances warranted piercing the corporate veil of successor corporations for subcontractor in order to hold owner individually liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shawmut Woodworking & Supply, Inc. v. ASICS America Corporation
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no basis to apply doctrine of piercing the corporate veil to hold franchisor liable for franchisee's alleged breach of contract for improvements that plaintiff had made in franchisee's retail store, where complaint did not allege that franchisor and franchisee had any corporate relationship or overlapping ownership, it did not allege that franchisee was a dummy corporation or that franchisor had complete control over franchisee and used that control to perpetrate a fraud or wrong against plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no basis to pierce the corporate veil to hold franchisor liable for franchisee's breach of contract, as there was no overlapping ownership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: P & S & Co. LLC v. SJ Mak, LLC
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil and holding a corporate director of each of two companies personally liable for the judgment against the companies for fraud and breach of contract was warranted, where the companies were the alter egos of the directors, who were a couple, and the directors used the companies to sell mortgages and notes that they did not own to defraud judgment creditor and others.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Stay from judgment debtor's bankruptcy case did not preclude impleading third-party defendants in judgment creditor's supplementary proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gordon v. Royal Palm Real Estate Investment Fund I, LLLP
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, individual managing member of management company involved in fraudulent investment scheme could be held personally liable under veil piercing theory for breaching partnership agreement with corporate investor of fund used in the scheme, where allegations in the complaint, as a whole, alleged that individual dominated and controlled the management company to such an extent that its independent existence was non-existent.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Investors who used funds from a Ponzi scheme to invest in a fraudulent investment scheme were not barred by in pari delicto doctrine from seeking recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Care Group Heart Hospital, LLC v. Sawyer
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Certain traditional principles of state law-such as assumption, agency, veil piercing, alter ego, waiver, estoppel, third-party beneficiary, and incorporation by reference-may bind a nonparty to a contract.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Contracts. Phrase any termination in joinder agreement among hospital, employer, and doctor did not require consideration of separate employment contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Warciak v. Subway Restaurants, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: The traditional state law principles that allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract include: assumption, agency, veil piercing, alter ego, waiver, estoppel, third-party beneficiary, and incorporation by reference.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Under Illinois law, restaurant could not use estoppel to enforce arbitration agreement entered into by consumer's mother with cellular phone provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: UIRC–GSA Holdings Inc. v. William Blair & Company, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a court may apply alter ego liability to contractual claims, but in a breach of contract case, piercing the corporate veil is even more difficult and courts often require additional compelling facts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment bank stated a claim for piercing the corporate veil of bond issuer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Partridge v. American Hospital Management Company, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In breach of contract actions, under District of Columbia law, piercing the corporate veil allows individual corporate owners and officers to be held liable for breaching contracts between their corporations and third parties, even though they were not personally in privity with the third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's allegations were sufficient to permit piercing corporate veil in order to assert breach of contract claims directly against CEO.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: A.L. Dougherty Real Estate Management Company, LLC v. Su Chin Tsai
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, FIRST DIVISION.
Headnote: In breach of contract cases, courts apply an even more stringent standard to determine when to pierce the corporate veil than in tort cases, because a party seeking relief for a breach of contract presumably entered into the contract with the corporate entity voluntarily and knowingly and expecting to suffer the consequences of the limited liability status of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court properly declined to evaluate corporate veil piercing claim under principles applicable to breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: A.L. Dougherty Real Estate Management Company, LLC v. Su Chin Tsai
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, FIRST DIVISION.
Headnote: Where there is no evidence of any misrepresentation, no attempt to conceal any facts, and the parties possess a total understanding of all of the transactions involved, Illinois courts will not pierce the corporate veil in a breach of contract situation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court properly declined to evaluate corporate veil piercing claim under principles applicable to breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Paguirigan v. Prompt Nursing Employment Agency LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a plaintiff may pierce the corporate veil and sue a non-party for breach of contract when the non-party is an alter ego of one or more signatories to the contract.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Human Trafficking. Nurse, a citizen of the Philippines whose employment contract included $25,000 termination fee, stated TVPA claim against staffing agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cajun Global LLC v. Swati Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: While it is true that non-signatories are generally not bound by contracts, traditional principles of state law may allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Franchises and Dealerships. Franchisors established substantial likelihood of success on merits of claim that putative buyer of franchise violated franchise agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Dealers that contracted with flooring business to provide installation services, as part of at-home service program of home improvement chain, were not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of corporation that also participated in the chain's program as independent contractor, in order to hold related parent corporations liable for alleged breach of contract and violation of Business Opportunity Plans Act (BOPA), although the independent contractor corporation allegedly served as agent of other two corporations, and the corporations shared officers and board members and office space; mere agency relationship was insufficient to pierce the corporate veil without a showing of fraud or illegal activity, independent contractor corporation was a separate company with its own assets, payroll, and employees, and evidence did not establish control over the independent contractor corporation by the parent corporations. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1334.01 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: American Federated Title Corporation v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, wrongs that may have given rise to claim for contract damages, without more, fell short of supporting extraordinary remedy of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Extraordinary remedy of piercing corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Landowners' complaint stated a claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil with respect to breach of contract claims concerning a payment in lieu of taxes reimbursement agreement for public infrastructure improvements for a mixed-use retail development, where landowners alleged developer entered into a contract of guaranty relating to the purchasers of the landowners' property, and landowners further alleged sufficient facts, when accepted as true, that suggested a single business enterprise existed among developer and other companies.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps it sold to bank, even though company exercised complete control over fund, transferred cash from fund to other entities it controlled after bank issued margin call, diverted cash received on underlying note assets to make required payments on other short-term financing facilities, and allegedly misrepresented value of notes that fund pledged as collateral, where transfers were to satisfy preexisting obligations owed by fund, there was no evidence of unjust motive for transfers, bank was not contractually entitled to receive cash distributions on notes, and there was no evidence that company believed that notes were overvalued when they were pledged.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, investment fund's management company was not liable as investment fund's equitable owner for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps it sold to bank, even though company exercised complete control over fund, absent showing that it committed fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Doe v. Bank of America Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Bank's parent corporation could not be held liable for negligence or breach of contract based on bank's alleged actions in abruptly closing, without explanation, accounts held by an international political figure and his daughter, where plaintiffs pled no facts under either a direct or derivative theory of liability and advanced no alternative theories under which parent could be found liable, as bank agreement governing the accounts made clear that relevant banking relationship was with bank, not its parent, which was accepted by plaintiffs when they signed personal signature cards that indicated that banking agreement governed their accounts.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Accounts. There was no claim for breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing where bank had no contractual duty to not close bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brittania-U Nigeria, Limited v. Chevron USA, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under the Federal Arbitration Act, background principles of state contract law, when relevant, allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel. 9 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Removal of dispute over auction of mineral leases was appropriate under Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Absence of corporate records did not establish alter ego theory in breach of contract action, under Ohio law, since plaintiff did not request these documents on time.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff in breach of contract action failed to establish alter ego theory, under Ohio law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation that used initial gift to start the business was not grossly inadequately capitalized when it sold computer system to purchaser, under Ohio law, for purposes of establishing alter ego theory in breach of contract action.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff in breach of contract action failed to establish alter ego theory, under Ohio law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ground Control, LLC v. Capsco Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Evidence failed to demonstrate that subcontractor's principal incorporated subcontractor solely to avoid personal liability of principal while reserving to principal benefits gained through use of corporate name or that subcontractor was so organized and controlled as to make it a mere instrumentality of principal, and thus sub-subcontractor failed to establish that subcontractor's principal was subcontractor's alter ego who was personally liable for subcontractor's debts, in sub-subcontractor's action for quantum meruit damages arising from unpaid labor and materials in hotel construction project.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Implied Contracts. Sub-subcontractor failed to demonstrate it expected payment from general contractor and project owner, as required for quantum meruit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TransFirst Group, Inc. v. Magliarditi
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: The piercing-the-corporate-veil test for attribution of contacts, i.e., personal jurisdiction, is less stringent than for liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Venue. Statute permitting transfer of action upon finding of lack of jurisdiction applies when court lacks either personal or subject matter jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Police & Fire Retirement System of the City of Detroit v. Leibowitz
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation breached its loan agreement with creditor was sufficient to support the existence of a legally sufficient wrong necessary to establish the second element of piercing the corporate veil, or that the corporate entity was used to commit a wrong or fraud, in creditor's action against sole shareholder of defunct corporation that sought to hold shareholder liable for corporation's debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. A genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether sole shareholder of defunct corporation used corporation as a mere instrumentality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Janvey v. Alguire
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Doctrines of alter ego, estoppel, and third-party beneficiary, which sound in equity, permit a court to impose a contract on a third party who is not a signatory to the contract.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Receiver for entities allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme was not bound by arbitration agreement between entities and employees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor's owner dominated decisions of judgment debtor, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where owner was sole shareholder and manager of judgment debtor, with final authority over all decisions, and he was also most significant source of its funding.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor and its owner's other companies disregarded corporate formalities, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where transfers of money to and from owner's other companies were tracked on judgment debtor's general ledgers, and there were no meeting minutes, corporate resolutions, business plans, or cash-flow projections for judgment debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor and its owner commingled funds and resources, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where owner frequently transferred money back and forth between judgment debtor and his other companies, judgment debtor paid for many of owner's personal expenses, and owner sometimes paid judgment debtor's bills personally.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor's owner used judgment debtor's resources for his personal benefit, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where judgment debtor often paid for owner's personal expenses, owner used judgment debtor's assets as collateral for mortgage on real estate that judgment debtor rented from his real estate company, and judgment creditor received no discernible benefit for having lien imposed on its assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor was undercapitalized and unable to pay its creditors without funding from its owner, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where judgment debtor was insolvent until it transferred its assets to owner's new company, its liabilities substantially exceeded its assets for years, there were no capital contributions to judgment debtor after year it was incorporated, judgment debtor consistently relied upon loans from owner to fund its business, and, because it was insolvent, it was able to pick and choose which creditors to pay.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor's owner used judgment debtor to commit a wrong against judgment creditor, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from owner, where owner's decision to prematurely terminate contract caused judgment debtor to breach its contract with judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment creditor suffered unjust loss as result of judgment debtor's breach of contract, as required to pierce the corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Vivir of L I, Inc. v. Ehrenkranz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditors were not entitled to pierce contractor's corporate veil and hold its principal personally liable for contractor's breach of contract related to partial construction of creditors' residence, even though principal exercised domination over contractor, since creditors failed to establish that principal abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form so as to perpetrate a wrong or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditors could not pierce contractor's corporate veil since there was no evidence of abuse of privilege of doing business in corporate form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Beram v. Ceaco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of puzzle licensee, so as to hold its president and chief financial officer (CFO) individually liable for its alleged breach of contract in failing to make contractually required royalty payments on designer's puzzle products, was not warranted, where alleged use of multiple entities with same name appeared to be mere evolution of licensee's corporate forms, and president's multiple roles did not suggest any impropriety.
Document Preview: TORTS  Limitations. Breach of contract did not rise to level of fraudulent concealment that would toll limitations periods applicable to tort claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boes Iron Works, Inc. v. Gee Cee Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: General contractor and related corporate entity were single business enterprise and, thus, entity was liable for contractor's debt in subcontractor's action for breach of contract and violation of prompt pay and misapplication of funds statutes for failing to pay amount due; both groups were in existence until contractor was abandoned, both groups had same mailing address, same phone and fax numbers, and same person served as president of both, entity was formed after one of contractor's clients filed for bankruptcy, which almost bankrupted contractor, and, since contractor was already approved vendor when project at issue was awarded, president did not correct name to change it to entity once he stopped conducting business under contractor anymore. La. Rev. Stat. Ann. §§ 9:2784, 9:4814.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. General contractor and related corporate entity were single business enterprise and thus entity was responsible for contractor's debt to subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Skanska USA Bldg. Inc. v. Atlantic Yards B2 Owner, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Statute governing liens under contracts for public improvements did not require posting of bond to guarantee performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Genband US LLC v. Metaswitch Networks Ltd
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Marshall Division.
Headnote: Alter ego theories cannot serve to modify the terms of a written agreement or contract.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Claims in patent directed to method and apparatus for interworking between Internet Protocol (IP) telephony protocols were patent eligible.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TLIG Maintenance Services, Inc. v. Fialkowski
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence supported piercing corporate veil in action for breach of contract and breach of implied warranty of good workmanship based on substandard work performed on home; sole shareholder and her boyfriend made numerous personal purchases from corporate account, money from corporate account was used to pay for service performed on shareholder's automobile, money from corporate account was used to purchase haircuts, groceries, and food at bars and restaurants, there were no receipts or other documents to demonstrate how cash withdrawals from corporate account were spent, and boyfriend did not limit his personal spending from corporate account to profit that would be earned from project.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual who was not a shareholder could not be held individually liable in action against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TLIG Maintenance Services, Inc. v. Fialkowski
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Boyfriend of corporation's sole shareholder could not be held individually and personally liable for breach of contract and breach of implied warranty of good workmanship for substandard work he performed on home for corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual who was not a shareholder could not be held individually liable in action against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Stage Presence Incorporated
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiffs, that is, individuals and entities that allegedly were hired by Chapter 11 debtor to provide audio, editing, teleprompter, music mixing, and other services in connection with televised charity event, stated a claim for liability on an alter ego/veil-piercing theory against the individual producer who allegedly owned and controlled debtor by alleging that this individual used debtor to conduct his own affairs, that he ignored corporate formalities and corporate distinctions between debtor and other entities with which he was affiliated, and that he caused debtor to engage in transactions with this individual and with affiliated entities for which no consideration was paid.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Plaintiffs stated claim for liability based on alter ego or veil-piercing theory against individual who allegedly controlled debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Stage Presence Incorporated
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiffs, that is, individuals and entities that allegedly were hired by Chapter 11 debtor to provide audio, editing, teleprompter, music mixing, and other services in connection with televised charity event, could not impose contractual liability on two of the benefit program's individual producers by piercing the corporate veil of debtor, absent any allegation that the producers in question were officers, directors, employees, or owners of debtor, or that they exercised such control over the finances and assets of debtor that they were an equitable owner of debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Plaintiffs stated claim for liability based on alter ego or veil-piercing theory against individual who allegedly controlled debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Stage Presence Incorporated
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced, it is generally not a "misuse" of corporate forms to say that a contract liability belongs only to the contracting party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Plaintiffs stated claim for liability based on alter ego or veil-piercing theory against individual who allegedly controlled debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Adtile Technologies Inc. v. Perion Network Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations of developer of multi-sensor advertising technology and services for smartphones and tablets that corporate officer and another employee listed both Israeli parent corporation and its subsidiary as their place of employment on social media website were insufficient to support an agency or alter ego theory, and were thus insufficient for district court to pierce corporate veil and attribute subsidiary's alleged actions to parent corporation, on developer's breach of contract and trademark infringement action against parent corporation and subsidiary; parent corporation and its subsidiaries maintained separate books, records, and accounts.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal or general jurisdiction over Israeli corporation that did not advertise in forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Keg Restaurants Arizona, Inc. v. Jones
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support verdict that unity of control existed between parent corporation and subsidiaries, which acted as a restaurant franchisor, as would support piercing of corporate veil to hold parent liable for acts of subsidiaries in breaching contracts with franchisee relating to building of a restaurant; parent and subsidiaries were sublicensed and sub-sublicensed to use same trademarks, trade names, and proprietary rights in connection with franchise, parent had financially assisted subsidiaries, parent and subsidiaries all provided same business address, and entities did not maintain formalities between separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Contract appointing franchisor as franchisee's agent regarding restaurant project was supported by consideration, even if not in form of money.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Keg Restaurants Arizona, Inc. v. Jones
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: Recognizing parent corporation and its subsidiaries, which acted as a restaurant franchisor, as entities separate and distinct from each other would have worked a fraud, supporting piercing of corporate veil to hold parent liable for acts of subsidiary in breaching contracts with franchisee relating to the building of a restaurant, where subsidiaries entered into agreements with franchisee, resulting in different responsibilities for each entity and also resulting in no entity having entered into any agreement with franchisee to actually build a restaurant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Contract appointing franchisor as franchisee's agent regarding restaurant project was supported by consideration, even if not in form of money.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carpenter Properties, Inc. v. JP Morgan Chase Bank Nat. Ass'n
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold national bank liable for acquired subsidiary's purported breach of brokerage contract was not warranted under Mississippi law, absent showing that bank frustrated broker's contractual expectations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil to hold national bank liable for acquired subsidiary's breach of brokerage contract was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Norfolk Southern Railway Company v. Pittsburgh & West Virginia Railroad
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, parent real estate investment trust (REIT) and its wholly-owned subsidiary that was lessor of railroad line were not alter egos, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold REIT liable under lease and for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract with lessee, where subsidiary observed corporate formalities by holding board meetings and rendering decisions by corporate resolution, paid dividends to parent shareholder, remained solvent and well-capitalized, maintained corporate records and bank account separate and distinct from REIT that also received income from other subsidiaries, and continued to operate as it did prior to reverse triangular merger creating parent-subsidiary relationship.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Railroads. Lessor's fraud against lessee of railroad line did not justify award of punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fairpoint Companies, LLC v. Vella
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Even though homeowner sufficiently alleged that corporate parent dominated electrical company's work performed on her property, she failed to allege that parent abused the corporate form of electrical company for purpose of committing wrongdoing against her or to avoid obligations to her, so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil in order to hold parent liable for breach of contract based on electrical company's abrupt termination of work before finishing renovation work on her property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff failed to allege abuse of corporate form in order to pierce corporate veil to hold parent liable on breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Job v. Simply Wireless, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, sellers' allegations that there was unity of ownership and interest between buyer and its affiliate, that buyer was intentionally undercapitalized in order to discourage creditors from taking legal action to collect debts, and that buyer's assets were moved into affiliate for purpose of rendering buyer judgment-proof were sufficient to state plausible claim for piercing corporate veil to hold affiliate liable in sellers' breach of contract action.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Penalty provision of installment contract for sale of company's stock was unenforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Andretti Sports Marketing Louisiana, LLC v. Nola Motorsports Host Committee, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Louisiana's single business enterprise doctrine could not be applied to hold individual race track owner liable for breach of racing services agreement entered into by a corporation that was allegedly affiliated with owner, since the doctrine only applied where multiple business entities acted as one.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sports marketing company failed to plead that corporation and LLC involved in auto race were a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Northbound Group, Inc. v. Norvax, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: In an alter ego claim under Illinois law, showing that observance of separate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice is especially difficult for a party to make in a breach of contract action where courts should apply even more stringent standards to determine when to pierce the corporate veil than they would in tort cases.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary was not the alter ego of its parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Growtech Partners v. Accenture LLP
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a contract may be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Party waived right to enforce arbitration provision by its pre- and post-suit actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Simons v. Park City RV Resort, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Construction company, its sole owner, and a limited liability company (LLC) of which owner was a member and manager did not have such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities no longer existed, and therefore homeowner could not pierce the corporate veil based on an alter ego theory for construction company's alleged defective construction of home, even if owner and his wife managed construction company, owner took a $50,000 loan from construction company, construction company did not have a complete accounting of homeowner's project, and construction company eventually ended up insolvent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner failed to show unity of interest and ownership between construction company and its president to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Author seeking compensation for movie rights to her novel, "Gravity," failed plausibly to allege that entertainment company could be held liable as a principal with respect to the contract and guaranty into which motion picture and production companies entered.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Author's amended complaint failed to allege plausible claims against entertainment corporation on successor-in-interest theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ultratech, Inc. v. Ensure NanoTech (Beijing), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, a director or officer is not personally liable on contracts signed by the director or officer for and on behalf of the corporation, unless the director or officer purports to be bound individually or acts as the alter ego of the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Forum-selection clause, which provided for venue to change based on change in headquarters location, inured to successor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ultratech, Inc. v. Ensure NanoTech (Beijing), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Sales agent's president was alter ego of agent, such that, under California law, he could be personally liable for breach of sales agency agreement with manufacturer and seller of atomic-layer deposition systems used in manufacture of semiconductor devices, where president was also agent's principal and sole owner, controlled all aspects of agent's business and day-to-day operations, and negotiated and signed agreement, and, given this controlling position, it would be plainly inequitable for president to escape liability for subverting confidentiality and exclusivity protections he negotiated and agreed to on behalf of agent simply because he was not personally party to agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Forum-selection clause, which provided for venue to change based on change in headquarters location, inured to successor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: EV Scarsdale Corp. v. Engel & Voelkers North East LLC
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Veil piercing is not a viable basis to impute breach of contract liability unless plaintiffs establish that the owners of the entity, through their domination of it, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the party asserting the claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Franchisees' fraudulent inducement claim under New York Franchise Sales Act was not barred by agreements' merger clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: EV Scarsdale Corp. v. Engel & Voelkers North East LLC
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Franchisees' allegations regarding corporate structure of entities affiliated with franchisors were insufficient to support veil piercing claim, as required to impute liability on breach of contract claims to entities; complaint merely described complex international corporate structure but did not explain why that structure was legally inappropriate or different from other corporations, allegations of sharing of office space and resources did not show that entities were shams, and complaint did not allege that abuse of corporate form was for the purpose of defrauding franchisees.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Franchisees' fraudulent inducement claim under New York Franchise Sales Act was not barred by agreements' merger clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Phillips v. Carlton Energy Group, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Two corporations were subject to alter ego liability, under Nevada law, to investor in a coalbed methane prospect for corporate energy company operator's breach of contract with investor and tortious interference with investor's agreement with owner of the prospect; all three corporations were inseparable from operator and thus, insofar as energy company's operations were concerned, inseparable from each other, and operator's pursuit of his interests in the prospect was to benefit himself and the three corporations.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Requirement of reasonable certainty of proof applies when lost profits are used to determine market value of property for which recovery is sought.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Green v. Ziegelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Principal of corporate judgment debtor operated debtor as his alter ego or as mere instrumentality of his will, and therefore piercing of corporate veil was warranted to make principal personally liable for judgment obtained against debtor by judgment creditors in breach of contract action, where principal was sole owner, director, and officer of debtor, principal was sole agent of debtor and one of two employees, debtor was entirely dependent on principal's financial support in order to continue operations, principal used debtor to cover his personal expenses, principal had not properly maintained debtor's corporate formalities, principal misrepresented financial condition of debtor both in his individual capacity and as principal of debtor, and misrepresentation prevented judgment creditors from recovering their loss from debtor after breach of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to render principal personally liable for judgment obtained against corporate judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Matthys v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Allegations of patient at substance abuse treatment facility operated by corporation stated a claim under Colorado law for piercing the corporate veil of two other corporations under alter ego theory, in action for breach of contract and fraud, alleging that treatment facility was not non-religious as promised, and that it did not offer treatment by qualified professionals and instead attempted to recruit patient into a church; patient alleged that corporate operator was subsidiary of second corporation which, in turn, was subsidiary of third corporation, and that third corporation oversaw church's drug rehabilitation activities and governed and controlled nearly every aspect of corporate operator's and second corporation's business activities.
Document Preview: TORTS  Emotional Distress. Alleged conduct of operator of substance abuse treatment facility was outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hilton Worldwide, Inc. Global Benefits Administrative Committee v. Caesars Entertainment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent company can be held liable as a party to the subsidiary's contract if the parent's conduct manifests an intent to be bound by the contract; such intent is inferable from the parent's participation in the negotiation of the contract, or if the subsidiary is a dummy for the parent, or if the subsidiary is controlled by the parent for the parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Non-bankruptcy case could be transferred to district where related bankruptcy proceeding was pending.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that closely held corporation might not retain sufficient assets to satisfy an inchoate claim that another company possibly had against it did not, in and of itself, give rise to basis for disregarding the corporate form and granting company's motion to pierce corporate veil, where company, which had entered into contract to employ corporation as its agent and was the party obligated to make payments, in form of commissions, to corporation, did not show that corporation was established to evade any payment obligation owed to company and did not cite any evidence that corporation re-directed funds to its owners that were specifically intended for company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: Even alleged negligent performance of contractual duties does not justify the disregard of the corporate entity under Mississippi law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant's sole employee did not engage in fraud, precluding piercing of corporate veil on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AZTE, Inc. v. Auto Collection, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Trial court's determination to pierce the corporate veil and hold owner of 90 percent of corporation's stock personally liable for judgment based on breach of contract was warranted, given not only owner's domination and control of the corporation generally, but his domination and control over the transaction at issue, as well.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of corporation exercised domination and control warranting piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The "Norman test" is a two-part test to determine when a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil and obtain judgment against individual shareholders; the first part of the test, often called the "formalities requirement", requires the movant to show such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and the second part of the test, often called the "fairness requirement", requires the movant to show that observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or condone an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Under the two-part Norman test to determine whether a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil, the second prong of the test, the fairness requirement, is addressed to the conscience of the court, but the first prong of the test, the formalities requirement, is determined by examining seven factors, called the Colman factors: (1) undercapitalization of a one-person corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: It is possible that evidence of even one of the seven Colman factors may be sufficient to suggest both elements of a party's alter-ego theory in a breach of contract action against a corporation, and therefore preclude summary judgment against that party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: General contractor, which was not in privity of contract with homeowners association, was not alter ego of condominium developer, and piercing of corporate veil thus was not warranted in condominium association's contract action, even though contractor owned majority interest in developer and served as its manager, the two entities employed same individuals, and subcontractors were paid from developer's account by contractor's staff, where the two entities had separate organizational documents, ownership, bank accounts, tax returns, books, and records, developer was not undercapitalized, legitimate reason existed for appearance of contractor's logo in developer's documents, and observance of corporate form would not sanction fraud, promote injustice, or condone inequitable results.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stone v. Theatrical Inv. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Arbitrator's piercing of corporate veil to hold president and sole shareholder of corporation jointly and severally liable for full amount awarded to investment trust in contract dispute did not provide basis for vacating the arbitration award; although arbitrator did not make any formal findings supporting veil-piercing, neither party requested any, there was evidence to support arbitrator's finding, and corporation and president submitted a single pre-hearing brief that discussed their conduct interchangeably.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitrator had authority to appoint receiver in contract dispute between theatrical investors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Store owner failed to establish that owners of computer systems provider were its alter ego, as required under Ohio law to support breach of contract claim against the provider's owners as individuals.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Savings clause in Ohio's four-year statute of limitations for fraud claims did not operate to toll limitations period.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Store owner failed to establish that owners of computer systems provider used corporate form to commit fraud or illegal act against store owner, as required under Ohio law to pierce the corporate veil in store owner's breach of contract action.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Savings clause in Ohio's four-year statute of limitations for fraud claims did not operate to toll limitations period.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In breach of contract cases, courts apply an even more stringent standard to determine when to pierce the corporate veil than in tort cases; the reason is that a party seeking relief for a breach of contract presumably entered into the contract with the corporate entity voluntarily and knowingly and expecting to suffer the consequences of the limited liability status of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Distributor of foreign company's baked goods failed to plead that foreign company was alter ego of its domestic owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In a breach of contract case, in addition to proof of a unity of interest and ownership and a finding that adhering to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice, additional compelling facts, such as a finding of fraud, may also be required to support piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Distributor of foreign company's baked goods failed to plead that foreign company was alter ego of its domestic owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Where there is no evidence of any misrepresentation, no attempt to conceal any facts, and the parties possess a total understanding of all of the transactions involved, courts will not pierce the corporate veil in a breach of contract situation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Distributor of foreign company's baked goods failed to plead that foreign company was alter ego of its domestic owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Claybar v. Huffman
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Subcontractor's allegations that contractor and its owner did not observe corporate formalities, did not maintain corporate records, and did intermingle funds were sufficient to state a claim for piercing the corporate veil, as required under Alabama law to hold owner individually liable for alleged fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor's allegations were sufficient to state a claim for piercing the corporate veil against contractor and its owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego or other similar theories may be used to pierce the corporate veil in breach of contract action and to hold shareholder personally liable for the breach only if: (1) actual fraud is shown, and (2) it was perpetrated primarily for direct personal benefit of shareholder. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: "Actual fraud," of kind required under Texas law in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold debtor, in his capacity as corporate shareholder and director, personally liable for corporation's breach of contract in failing to pay one of its supplier for component parts received and used by corporation to manufacture electronic circuit boards, did not necessarily have to involve misrepresentation by debtor, so that fact that debtor may have had no interaction with any of supplier's representatives until after goods were shipped and made no misrepresentations did not necessarily mean that corporate veil could not be pierced in order to hold debtor personally liable for corporation's breach of contract.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, courts may deduce fraudulent intent from all the facts and circumstances, and generally look at totality of shareholder's actions to determine whether he or she committed an actual fraud, of kind required in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold shareholder personally liable for breach of corporate contract. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: "Actual fraud," of kind required under Texas law in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold shareholder personally liable for breach of corporate contract, is not equivalent to tort of fraud. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraud-based dischargeability exception requires showing of misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Winmark Corp. v. Brenoby Sports, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, there was no evidence that girlfriend of owner of former franchised retail sporting goods store or owner's son were operating new sporting goods store on franchised location or were otherwise aiding and abetting owner in violating post-termination non-compete covenant set forth in franchise agreement, or that new store was merely alter ego of franchisee or owner, and thus girlfriend and son were not bound by covenant; while son was listed as co-manager of new store, he did not own store and was merely an employee, and neither girlfriend nor son were personal guarantors or owners of franchisee. West's F.S.A. § 542.335(1)(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Injunction. Preliminary injunction prohibiting former franchisee from violating non-compete agreement was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Winmark Corp. v. Brenoby Sports, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, there was no evidence that individual to whom former owner of franchised retail sporting goods store sold assets of franchise, and who was operating new sporting goods store at franchised location, or new store were alter ego for owner to secretly operate new store, or that individual or new store were under owner's control, and thus individual and new store were not bound by post-termination restrictive covenant contained in franchise agreement between franchisor and owner. West's F.S.A. § 542.335(1)(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Injunction. Preliminary injunction prohibiting former franchisee from violating non-compete agreement was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jaffer v. Standard Chartered Bank
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Partners, whose partnership proceeds were placed in Ghanaian bank, failed to show that bank that did business in the United States and owned roughly two-thirds of Ghanaian bank's outstanding shares exercised requisite degree of dominion and control over Ghanaian bank needed to pierce corporate veil, in partners' action against United States bank, alleging breach of a depository contract and seeking recovery of money in Ghanaian bank account; even though Ghanaian bank used some of United States bank's branding, banks had no common directors, kept separate accounting books and business records, and issued separate annual reports.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Parties. Dismissal for failure to join indispensable party was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: CNH Capital America LLC v. Hunt Tractor, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
