Headnote: Under Kentucky law, alleged injustice experienced by creditor of inability to collect a debt from debtor was insufficient to support breach of contract action against shareholder of debtor under a theory of piercing the corporate veil, notwithstanding that debtor's payment of another debt using proceeds owed to creditor under their financing agreement allowed the shareholder to obtain release of personal guaranty owed to another creditor.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Conveyance. Shareholder of debtor was a mere beneficiary of allegedly fraudulent transfer and thus not liable as transferee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Patriot Universal Holdings, LLC v. Formax, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: An assignment is an agreement like any other, and, if there is a meeting of the minds, then the agreement may be enforced notwithstanding any corporate formalities.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Assignments and Licensing. Patent licensee and sublicensee had standing to bring infringement action against competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Llewellyn-Jones v. Metro Property Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, individual employees of property management firm were not parties to contract for management of rental properties that real estate investors purchased from firm, and thus not liable for firm's alleged failure to perform management services, where employees were agents of firm, were not the alter egos of the firm, and did not agree to be held personally liable.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine did not apply to bar investors' fraudulent inducement claim against sellers of sham investments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Solnes v. Wallis & Wallis, P.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing the corporate veil of corporation that acted as escrow agent for yacht sale, so as to hold corporation's agent liable in his individual capacity, was not warranted in buyer's action for breach of an implied contract, absent evidence that corporation was formed or operated for an improper or fraudulent purpose or that agent dominated and controlled corporation to the extent that it lacked an independent existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted in action by yacht buyer against escrow agent and its agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haller v. Advanced Indus. Computer Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Former employee did not allege that former employer had a corporate relationship with third party, with which employee had a stock purchase agreement for employer's shares, as required to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold employer liable for third party's alleged breach of the agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Former employer was not liable to employee for third party's alleged breach of stock purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crawford Professional Drugs, Inc. v. CVS Caremark Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: "Background principles" of state contract law, when relevant, allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Signatories were equitably estopped from refusing to arbitrate with nonsignatories to arbitration agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Xiotech Corp. v. Express Data Products Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: District court could not pierce corporate veil to hold chief executive officer (CEO) of two corporate retail resellers of computer data storage equipment personally liable for resellers' breach of contract with supplier, although CEO owned controlling interest in resellers, where CEO did not dominate resellers, CEO did not orchestrate cash flow between resellers, and CEO did not use corporate form to perpetuate fraud or other tort.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold CEO, who owned controlling interest in corporation, liable for corporation's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The mere fact that a corporation commits an unfair labor practice, or breaches a contract, or commits a tort, does not mean that the individual shareholders of the corporation should personally be liable. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as could support piercing of corporate veil in landowner's action for breach of contract and slander of title action brought against contractor's shareholders, where contractor had run at a profit for many years, and there was no evidence that contractor's dwindling capital was due to anything other than a general downturn in the economy and a specific downturn in the construction industry. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: There was no evidence of any causal link between alleged failure of contractor corporation to respect corporate formalities, through lack of detail in recordkeeping, and injustice alleged by landowner, as would be required to pierce corporate veil in landowner's action against contractor for breach of contract and slander of title based on unfinished project and contractor's filing of mechanic's lien. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bates v. Bankers Life and Cas. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, breach of contract claim against parent corporation of long-term health care insurer survived motion to dismiss on theory of actual agency; plaintiffs variously alleged that revenues from subsidiary insurer accounted for vast majority of parent corporation's income and profits and that parent crossed the line from acting as mere investor to treating insurer as its own business. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(6), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under Oregon law, breach of contract claim against insurer's parent survived motion to dismiss on theory of actual agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crowley Marine Services, Inc. v. Vigor Marine LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Ship repair service provider was not entitled to off-set of damages incurred after shipowner's ship that it had contracted to repair was partially submerged and declared a loss after drydock at which it was being repaired collapsed, even though the drydock was repairer's wholly owned subsidiary and stored the ship after it was righted until the shipowner came to collect it, where the repairer and shipyard were separate corporate entities, all losses were assigned to the shipyard, and owner's contract was with repairer.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Collision. A ship repair service provider was not entitled to off-set of damages after ship it contracted to repair sank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fillmore East BS Finance Subsidiary LLC v. Capmark Bank
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: E-mails between bank's management and management of another business entity did not demonstrate overlapping management and employees as required to support claim that the two were merely alter-egos and that piercing the corporate veil was warranted in finance institution's breach of contract action against bank.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. General allegations of common ownership and management were insufficient to state claim for alter-ego status.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, there was a lack of corporate separateness between subsidiary propane company, its parent, which was not-for-profit limited liability company (LLC), and its grandparent, which was electric cooperative, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company, although propane company paid its own salaries and other expenses, propane company purchased its own assets and did business with third parties separate from cooperative, propane company was never referred to as a division of cooperative or LLC, cooperative did not use propane company's assets in its business, and formal legal requirements of propane company were observed, where cooperative was sole owner of LLC, which in turn was sole owner of propane company, entities had at least one common officer, cooperative guaranteed loans and donated capital to propane company, proceeds from sale of propane company to buyer went directly into cooperative's financial account, cooperative permitted propane company to use its real estate, and cooperative's board of directors served as LLC's ownership group, which governed propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, continued recognition of subsidiary propane company would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company against parent and grandparent companies, where proceeds from buyer's purchase of propane company were transferred to grandparent company for nothing in return, such that if buyer was successful in its claims, it could not recover anything from propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nature's Plus Nordic A/S v. Natural Organics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, absent a formal merger, a parent company may not enforce the contract of its wholly-owned subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Distributor did not materially breach the distribution contract's minimal sales requirement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bonacasa Realty Co., LLC v. Salvatore
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Commercial landlord was not entitled to piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: SIG, Inc. v. AT & T Digital Life, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a corporation's officer is not liable for the corporation's contracts unless he or she signed in an individual capacity, or unless the corporate veil was pierced or the corporate entity should be ignored because it was found to be formed or used for fraudulent purposes, or the corporation was merely alter ego of shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Court declined to consider, on motion to dismiss, extraneous evidence of a click-through agreement on defendant's website.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: World Class Const. Management Group v. Baylor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, in breach of contract actions, piercing the corporate veil allows individual corporate owners to be held liable for breaching contracts between their corporations and third parties, even though they were not personally in privity with the third parties.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. A fact issue existed as to whether escrow agent released funds without authorization precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Spitz v. Proven Winners North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, companies that allegedly used developer's marketing concept for pet-safe plants, but failed to pay her any fee, were not liable for breach of contract, absent any evidence that purported agents with whom developer allegedly entered into an oral contract for a per plant royalty had authority to enter into any contracts on behalf of companies, or were alter ego of companies, or that would warrant piercing the corporate veil, such as undercapitalization of purported agent or mere facade.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Trade Secrets. Companies that allegedly used marketing concept without paying were not liable for misappropriation of a trade secret.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: A party's breach of contract alone is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil; there must be evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A shareholder of a corporation did not exercise dominion and control over the corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Musical performer was aware that a corporation scheduling an event at which performer was to appear did not have the money owed under the performer's contract, and that a shareholder of a corporation was attempting to come up with the money owed, barring the performer from piercing the corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable for an alleged intentional wrong resulting from the corporation's failure to pay under the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A shareholder of a corporation did not exercise dominion and control over the corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Shareholder of corporation did not exercise dominion and control over corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud that would warrant musical performer's piercing of the corporate veil to recover against shareholder for wrongs allegedly committed resulting from corporation's failure to pay money owed under a contract; there was no indication that shareholder knew at the time the contract was made that the corporation would be unable to pay, and failure to pay merely amounted to a breach of contract rather than an intentional wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A shareholder of a corporation did not exercise dominion and control over the corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: GS2 Engineering & Environmental Consultants, Inc. v. Zurich American Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Columbia Division.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, parent company of wholly owned subsidiary had no obligation to insured under a professional liability insurance policy issued by subsidiary, even though parent company's logo was present on the insurance policies' declaration pages and endorsements, and parent company's address was to be used for notice of claims under the policies, where there was no evidence that parent company wrote the insurance policies at issue.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Insured's failure to report notice of claim to professional liability insurer during same policy period precluded coverage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: BP Environmental Services, Inc. v. Republic Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, a waste hauler was not liable for an alleged breach of contract between its parent corporation and another waste hauler, where the subsidiary waste hauler was independent from its parent corporation, and the parent corporation did not exercise control over the subsidiary hauler such that piercing the corporate veil under an alter-ego theory was warranted.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A second waste hauler did not tortiously interfere with the contract between an original waste hauler and its client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Malmsteen v. Universal Music Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a nonsignatory parent corporation can be held liable for breach of contract if its intent to be bound by the contract were inferable from the parent's participation in the negotiation of the contract, or if the subsidiary is a dummy for the parent, or if the subsidiary is controlled by the parent for the parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contract provision with royalty rate for records sold through normal retail channels governed downloads of musician's music.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Malmsteen v. Universal Music Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that nonsignatory parent company participated in negotiation of contract between record company and musician, that record company was dummy for parent company, or that record company was controlled by parent company for parent's own purposes, as required, under New York law, to hold parent company liable for record company's alleged breach of contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contract provision with royalty rate for records sold through normal retail channels governed downloads of musician's music.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Beltran v. Vincent P. Miraglia, M.D., P.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Physician whose professional association allegedly entered into agreements with another professional association to share office space and expenses could not be held personally liable for his association's alleged failure to pay its share of expenses under such agreements, where there was no evidence indicating that physician personally entered into any of the alleged agreements, no evidence of wrongdoing that would support piercing the corporate veil, and no evidence physician agreed to be personally liable for the debt.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Pleading. Mid-trial amendment of complaint to add professional association as a defendant did not relate back to original complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kehoe Component Sales Inc. v. Best Lighting Products, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, manufacturer's chief executive officer (CEO) could not be held personally liable to distributor for manufacturer's alleged breach of contract, absent justification for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Under Ohio law, damages provision in supply agreement's non-compete provision was unenforceable penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Burke v. Ability Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, where the alter ego doctrine applies to allow piercing of the corporate veil, the two affiliated corporations are treated as one for purposes of determining liability for breach of contract or breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations supported piercing corporate veil, as would establish personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Montalbano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will not pierce corporate veil in breach of contract situation, where there is no evidence of any misrepresentation, and no attempt to conceal any facts, and where parties possess a total understanding of all of the transactions involved.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate principal was not personally liable for Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Harris v. American Intern. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Although Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings and other documents submitted as evidence by insured reflected financial relationship between nonresident holding company and its subsidiaries, including resident insurer, such evidence did not demonstrate pervasive level of control required to permit exercise of personal jurisdiction over holding company in Oklahoma, under alter-ego theory and due process clause, during diversity action for breach of automobile insurance contract; evidence was not sufficient to show that holding company exercised control over day-to-day business of insurer, including issuance of insurance policies, insurance coverage, review of claims, decisions regarding whether a claim would be paid, or other ongoing activities of an insurance subsidiary doing business in Oklahoma. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Jurisdiction. Financial structure of holding company and insurer did not support exercise of personal jurisdiction over holding company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Signal Peak Energy, LLC v. Eastern Montana Minerals, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Under Montana law, coal mine lessor's allegations that lessee was failing to pay full royalty amount for coal mined under the lease, based upon lessee's alleged sale of coal to a related entity at a reduced price to lower the price-based royalty payments owed under the lease, failed to state a claim against corporate owners of coal mine lessee for unjust enrichment; lessor failed to allege that corporate owners were retaining money owed to lessor, and that their alleged abuse of the corporate form resulted in an injustice to lessor.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Lessor's allegations, that lessee misrepresented payment of royalties, pleaded fraud with particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Serio v. Baystate Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: The corporate veil will not be pierced to redress the breach of a contractual obligation in the absence of fraud when the party seeking to pierce the corporate shield has dealt with that corporation in the course of its business on a corporate basis.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted in absence of fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: On Command Video Corp. v. Roti
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Company's owner failed to operate it as corporation, thus weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Illinois law, in entertainment company's suit against owner, seeking to enforce default judgment entered in Colorado state court in breach of contract suit, where company was inadequately capitalized, with only $1,000 in capital, it commingled its revenue with that of sister company, which in addition paid company's liabilities on both van lease and video–services contract with entertainment company, and it did not keep records and apparently had no corporate officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit seeking to enforce underlying statecourt default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: On Command Video Corp. v. Roti
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Company in business of supplying equipment and licensing software for in–room entertainment in hotels, motels, and resorts did not contend that owner of two companies, one of which was true owner of hotel to which company provided video services and other of which was assetless, false owner of that hotel, was personally enriched by his failure to observe proper corporate formalities, and thus piercing corporate veil to hold owner personally liable on company's claim to enforce default judgment entered in Colorado state court in breach of contract suit was unwarranted under Illinois law, even though owner received salary from true owner of hotel, where there was no indication that it was excessive or that it prompted his decision to substitute assetless, false owner for true owner in contract with company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit seeking to enforce underlying statecourt default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dana Partners, L.L.C. v. Koivisto Constructors & Erectors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Trumbull County.
Headnote: Owner of contractor did not engage in fraud so as to warrant piercing of the corporate veil in contractual dispute with property owner, where, although owner was sole shareholder of contractor and owner's actions in overcharging property owner caused financial injury to property owner, overcharging was a result of owner's negligence, rather than purposeful or reckless actions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of contractor did not engage in fraud so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Awuah v. Coverall North America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Arbitration. Franchisees, whose agreements only referenced arbitration clauses in other agreements, were required to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: SMS Assist L.L.C. v. East Coast Lot & Pavement Maintenance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, snow removal subcontractors' sole owner was not their alter ego, as would justify piercing corporate veil and holding owner liable in contractor's action alleging fraud and breach of contract; although owner asserted complete control and intermingled funds between subcontractors, subcontractors observed corporate formalities, did not comingle assets with those of owner, and were capitalized with significant assets.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Snow removal contractor could not prevail on its fraud claim against subcontractor under Illinois law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Adams v. Raintree Vacation Exchange, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the veil remains a possible ground for enforcing a forum selection clause against a party's affiliate, if for example the corporation that signed the contract containing the clause was a mere shell, but it is not the only ground.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent of seller's successor could enforce forum selection clause in sellers contracts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sass v. TMT Restoration Consultants Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Contractor and architect were not alter egos such that one exercised complete domination over the other sufficient to warrant piercing the corporate veil and holding architect liable to project owner for breach of contract, to which architect was neither party nor signatory, in connection with construction work on apartments, although contractor and architect had overlapping ownership, a common officer, and common office space and facilities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contractor and architect were not alter egos, as would warrant piercing corporate veil in project owner's contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Last Time Beverage Corp. v. F & V Distribution Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence warranted piercing of corporate veil of defendant corporation and defendant limited liability company (LLC) for which defendant individual was mutual owner, in beverage distributors' action against LLC and corporation for breach of contract, relating to soft-drink franchise distributorship agreements; corporation and LLC had overlapping ownership, officers, and personnel, they shared same office space with other commonly-owned business entities, they failed to observe certain formalities such as keeping certain records, and LLC was not adequately capitalized, without substantial loan from individual defendant, to undertake the business venture.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Trade usage testimony was admissible in action for breach of soft-drink distributorship agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: New corporation was the alter ego of contractor and thus was liable for subcontractor's judgment against contractor, where the two entities had similar names and business purposes and shared an employee and a business address, the new corporation was owned by the husband of the woman who owned the contractor, and the new corporation was formed shortly after the subcontractor sued the contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Johnson v. Diamond Shine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Bowling Green Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, a mere breach of contract does not constitute an "injustice" sufficient to support claim for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Kentucky court had personal jurisdiction over Ohio defendant in breach of contract suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is possible when the corporate form has been used as an alter ego of another person or corporation or if it has been used to perpetrate a fraud, evade an existing obligation, create a monopoly, circumvent a statute, protect a crime, or justify wrong; but the Legislature has required a more stringent standard for piercing the corporate veil in contract actions. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil in action by general contractor for breach of contract and negligence, even if it lacked the funds or cash flow to pay all of its bills, where any such lack of funds did not render shareholders or officers liable for corporate debt, and contractor did not produce any evidence of subcontractor's capital, other assets, debts, and liabilities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Forfeiture of subcontractor's corporation charter did not support personal liability for corporate officers or shareholders in action by general contractor for breach of contract and negligence, where there was no evidence that the liability case was created or incurred after the corporate forfeiture. V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 171.255.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Smoot v. B & J Restoration Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to disregard cleaning and restoration business's corporate structure and impose individual liability on shareholders for breach of the business's contractual obligations under purchase agreement and restrictive covenant, in action by buyer of business for breach of contract and fraud, absent any showing that the shareholders failed to observe corporate formalities and operated the corporation as their personal business, or that any public policy would be defeated by recognizing business as a legitimate corporation; jury found shareholders had not committed fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Buyers and sellers of business did not intend for business's officers to sign purchase agreement in their individual capacities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: While corporate officers were personally liable for their own fraudulent misrepresentations to investors that they convinced to invest with company, and for their conversion of sums invested, they could not be personally liable under Kentucky law for corporation's breach of its contracts with investors, unless bankruptcy court found that corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Defendants' status as Chapter 7 debtors and size of compensatory award counseled against punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporate veil could be pierced in order to hold corporate shareholders personally liable for corporation's breach of its agreements with investors, given evidence that corporation was nothing more than alter ego of its shareholders, who commingled funds that corporation obtained from investors in their personal accounts and used corporation as piggy bank to pay their personal obligations, that corporation did not keep records or observe other corporate formalities, and that corporation was utilized by shareholders in order to commit fraud on investors by inducing them to invest in what were represented to be newly drilled gas wells, but which, in many cases, had been drilled long ago and had production that did not approach that which was represented to, and formed basis for artificially inflated "profits" initially paid to, investors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Defendants' status as Chapter 7 debtors and size of compensatory award counseled against punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bizjak v. Gramercy Capital Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that real estate trust used related entities to commit fraud or other inequity so as to permit piercing corporate veil, as required for underwriter's breach of contract claims against related entities based on oral agreement with real estate trust.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Independent Contractors. Underwriter was independent consultant rather than employee of real estate trust.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cobalt Partners, L.P. v. GSC Capital Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint filed by parties that agreed to purchase $4 million in restricted shares of fund as part of private placement, to the effect that affiliated entity exercised complete domination and control over fund, which had no employees of its own and was wholly dependent on this affiliated entity for its business operation, and to effect that affiliated entity had misused this control to cause fund to breach its contractual obligation to seek to register its stock for the financial benefit of affiliated entity, sufficiently alleged basis for piercing corporate veil and holding affiliated entity liable for fund's alleged breach of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were sufficient to state veil-piercing claim to hold affiliated entity liable for alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carlone v. Lion & the Bull Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was appropriate under New York law, in order to hold film production company's principal officer liable for company's actions in lender's New York–law breach of contract claim related to $115,000 "bridge loan" to help fund production of motion picture, where officer completely controlled and dominated company, company had only $50 in its corporate account before transfer of loan proceeds, company had no other assets or corporate headquarters, officer and his partner were sole corporate officers and meetings between them were informal, company conducted no other business during its existence, company did not exercise any discretion independent of officer's exercise of discretion, and officer used his control of company and his personal relationship with lender to effect loan.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was appropriate to hold principal liable for film production company's actions related to loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rogers v. Louisville Land Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Knoxville.
Headnote: Evidence did not support disregarding cemetery company's corporate veil to hold company's sole shareholder personally liable to decedent's mother for breach of contract arising out of inadequate maintenance of cemetery in which decedent was buried, even though shareholder used his own money in an unestablished amount to pay corporate debt, and shareholder decided when maintenance of the cemetery would occur, decided whether a complaint about cemetery maintenance would be ignored, contracted with individuals to perform maintenance work on the cemetery, and was responsible for writing cemetery maintenance work paychecks; there was no proof that any of shareholder's acts were not performed for the benefit of company or that any of those acts were inconsistent with shareholder's responsibility as president of company to maintain the cemetery.
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Mother failed to prove that company's failure to adequately maintain cemetery caused her to suffer serious mental injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: 904 Tower Apartment LLC v. Mark Hotel LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Purchasers of luxury apartments in mixed hotel and cooperative apartment development stated claim against developers, under New York law, for alter ego liability for breach of contract and fraud by alleging that defendants either owned or were principals and controlling members of developer, had used available cash for the most pressing needs of any one of their several hotels or related operations, used common office space and employees to run their numerous operations, and generally operated all of their affiliates as a unified enterprise without heeding corporate formalities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Sales of luxury apartments did not fall within scope of New York's Deceptive Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: B & H Nat. Place, Inc. v. Beresford
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: There was no evidence, as required under District of Columbia law, that individual shareholders in restaurant franchise used corporate entity to perpetrate fraud or other wrongs, as required to hold them individually liable under theory of alter-ego for franchise's alleged breach of restrictive covenant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Court interpreted location restrictions contained in franchise agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Best Cartage, Inc. v. Stonewall Packaging, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Paper company did not commit any wrongdoing as required under the instrumentality test to pierce the corporate veil and hold paper company responsible for cardboard manufacturer's alleged breach of contract with trucking company after cardboard manufacturer had been placed in receivership; paper company was within its rights to supply materials to cardboard manufacturer based on consignment and had the right to retrieve its rightfully owned materials once cardboard manufacturer faltered, and paper company did not create cardboard manufacturer for the sole purpose of entering into transportation agreement, nor did cardboard manufacturer's creation unjustly insulate paper company from any liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Trucking company sufficiently alleged partnership between paper company and cardboard manufacturer which signed contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Swinerton Builders v. Nassi
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: When the corporate veil is pierced, a shareholder who did not sign the corporate contracts at issue may be held personally liable for the contractual obligations of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate president was liable for attorney fees incurred by creditor as result of veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Holloway Automotive Group v. Lucic
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: District court lacked equitable jurisdiction to pierce the corporate veil to hold corporation's president and sole shareholder personally liable for liquidated damages owed to authorized luxury car dealer by corporation after corporation breached car purchase agreements requiring it to pay dealer $7,500 as liquidated damages for each car that was exported out of North America within one year of execution of agreements by exporting cars it had bought from dealer outside North America less than two weeks after purchasing them, as district court lacked general equitable power, and piercing of the corporate veil was not justified as a sanction against shareholder for testifying falsely, as piercing the corporate veil was not a sanction, but an equitable remedy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court lacked equitable jurisdiction to pierce corporate veil to hold corporation's president personally liable for liquidated damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: KDH Electronic Systems, Inc. v. Curtis Technology Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Sonar system programmer's allegations that sonar system manufacturer "may function" as chief executive officer's (CEO) alter ego, and that CEO used manufacturer "to suit his purposes and without regard to proper corporate formalities" failed to state breach of contract claims against CEO under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sonar system programmer stated a breach of contract claim against manufacturer under Pennsylvania law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gameologist Group, LLC v. Scientific Games Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, fact that party to a contract with plaintiff, and corporation that purchased such party, were both in the lottery industry and that many employees had gone to work for purchasing corporation did not suffice to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Defendants' use of the term bling was not likely to cause consumer confusion, as required to support Lanham Act claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pope v. Heritage Communities, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported finding that property development company, general contractor, and property management/sales company had an amalgamation of interests, in class action brought by condominium owners and property owners association against property developers for negligence, breach of warranties, and breach of fiduciary duty; the three corporations shared a location, telephone number, and board members, the delineation of employees between them was vague, and the development company held itself out to the homeowners as the corporation responsible for construction defects in its warranty and through representations to the homeowners by its chief operating officer.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jury. Property development companies were not prejudiced by trial court's misstatement of law on negligence in instructing jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lawson v. Life of the South Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law may allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Credit insurer was not entitled to enforce arbitration clause of underlying loan agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Although, previously, Texas law allowed for the corporate veil to be pierced under three expansive categories, namely, where the corporation is the alter ego of its owners and/or shareholders, where the corporation is used for illegal purposes, and where the corporation is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, a litigant seeking to pierce the corporate veil for breach of contract now must also prove that the defendant shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate an actual fraud on the obligee primarily for the direct personal benefit of the shareholder. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of corporation controlled by debtor failed to establish actual fraud, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, for creditor of corporation controlled by debtor to impose liability on debtor for the contractual debt which the corporation owed to creditor, creditor had to prove that (1) debtor's conduct amounted to actual fraud on creditor, and (2) debtor's conduct was primarily for his direct personal benefit. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of corporation controlled by debtor failed to establish actual fraud, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gowen v. Tiltware LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Poker company's affiliates were not liable for alleged breach of company's oral contract with poker player, pursuant to which player was to function as a celebrity representative in return for an ownership interest in the company, absent any allegation that affiliates were alter egos of company.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Poker player stated claims for breach of contract and promissory estoppel against poker company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: FLB, LLC v. 5Linx
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Even assuming that franchisee's president had subjective belief that he was dealing with franchisor's president in his personal capacity when negotiating franchise agreement, piercing corporate veil of franchisor was not warranted under New York law in franchisee's action for breach of contract, absent evidence that franchisor's president had abused the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Franchisor's president did not tortiously interfere with franchise agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ProTherapy Associates, LLC v. AFS of Bastian, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Virginia, Lynchburg Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, operator's control of nursing homes was insufficient, without more, to pierce corporate veil and hold operator liable, as parent corporation, for nursing homes' breach of restrictive covenant in nursing homes' therapy services agreements with provider of physical-therapy services, which prohibited nursing homes from indirectly employing provider's therapists.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Nursing homes breached restrictive covenants in service agreements with provider of physical-therapy services.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: A finding of fact of alter ego, standing alone, creates no cause of action under Oklahoma law; it merely imposes liability against a second corporation or individual upon an underlying cause of action, such as fraud or breach of contract, brought against the first corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Etex Apparel, Inc. v. Tractor Intern. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations that two defendant corporations had common owners, shared office, and that, after one corporation ceased its operations, other corporation continued in former corporation's business and, together with new licensee, sold goods to "some" of former corporation's former customers, were insufficient to satisfy heavy burden necessary to pierce corporate veil or to establish alter ego relationship between corporations, as required to sustain breach of contract claims, arising from plaintiff's relationship with former corporation, against surviving corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff did not satisfy burden to pierce corporate veil or show alter ego relationship among defendants in contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, control an investment company's sole member had over company was so complete that company had no separation from member, as required to hold member individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement, since member was and always had been sole member of company, member was only person authorized to direct withdrawals and transfers from company escrow account, and member exercised sole and complete control in regard to company's dealings with investor and bank.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, investment company's sole member exercised control over company as means to perpetrate fraud against bank, as required to hold member individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement, since member, once he had engaged services of bank, sent different versions of escrow agreement attachments to bank and investor, and member intended for bank to comply with his instructions for withdrawals and transfers of funds from escrow account.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, bank in which investor's money was held in escrow was injured by having to defend itself in lawsuit arising out of false representations investment company's sole member made to investor, and thus member could be held individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Trenwick America Reinsurance Corp. v. IRC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Confused intermingling did not occur, as required to pierce corporate veil under Massachusetts law, where plaintiff was not confused about identity of legal entity with which it was contracting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Reinsurer engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices in violation of Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Trenwick America Reinsurance Corp. v. IRC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: A lack of confusion on the part of the other contracting parties precludes veil-piercing under Massachusetts law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Reinsurer engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices in violation of Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kallman v. Pinecrest Modular Homes, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Principal of corporate home construction services provider, and principal of provider's consultant, could not be liable for corporations' alleged breach of verbal contract to provide home construction services, since contract was with provider, principals had acted in their corporate capacities, and there was no basis upon which to pierce the corporate veil to hold them personally liable in that principals had not abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against customer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Corporate principals could not be liable for corporations' alleged breach of verbal contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, life insurer alleged to have wrongly rescinded policy was not alter ego of its parent company, despite presence of parent's logo on correspondence from its subsidiary; companies were separate and distinct legal entities with separate and distinct management and operations, and no "inequitable result" would occur if the two entities were considered to be separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, life insurer alleged to have wrongly rescinded policy was not agent of its parent company but, rather, companies were separate entities that operated independently, and parent did not exert control over its subsidiary's actions in issuing or rescinding policies.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, for purposes of piercing corporate veil to hold developer, as managing member of corporation that owned property being developed into townhomes, individually liable for breach of contract for townhouse project, developer "controlled" the corporation, where developer directed all aspects of townhouse project, developer participated in construction meetings as an owner, developer identified itself as project owner in correspondence and in construction contract and terminated contract with general contractor, and corporation had no employees of its own and it shared same office as developer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Even though developer, as managing member of corporation that owned property being developed into townhomes, was not a signatory to contract for the construction of the townhomes, developer was liable for breach of contract, under Missouri law, to general contractor under theory of principal-agent relationship, where developer totally dominated and controlled corporation which was a mere business conduit; developer was intimately involved in all aspects of townhome project, contract stated on its face that developer was owner of the project, routine correspondence about project was on developer's letterhead and identified developer as owner, developer participated in construction meetings as owner and issued meeting notes on its letterhead, developer terminated construction contract, and corporation had no employees of its own and shared the same office as developer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced under Puerto Rico law as to owner of booking agency sued by musician for breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty, where there was no evidence that owner had committed fraud or disregarded corporate formalities; agency held annual shareholders' meetings, held business meetings exclusively at office, kept business and personal taxes separate, had independent companies keep its books, and issued shares of stock.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to owner of booking agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, plaintiff hoping to persuade court to pierce corporate veil must establish that directors acted with intent to defraud and that creditors cannot collect from corporation debt owed them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to owner of booking agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: American Decorative Fabrics, LLC v. Jordan Alexander, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: There was no evidence that a director/treasurer of a corporation had any domination or control of a corporation to warrant piercing the corporate veil in a case where the corporation breached a contract by failing to pay for fabric. There was no evidence that the director had any knowledge of the corporation's purchase of the fabric. Nor was there any evidence that the director benefited from the breach. The evidence demonstrated that the director had resigned as a figurehead officer prior to the contract, and that she had no involvement in the day-to-day activities of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no evidence that a director/treasurer of a corporation had any domination or control of a corporation to warrant piercing the corporate veil in a case where the corporation breached a contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate buyer's sole owner was not personally liable under California law for the contractual obligations of corporate buyer under the alter ego doctrine; seller's only evidence of a unity of interest was the fact that owner was buyer's sole owner, and many other undisputed facts indicated that buyer and owner did not share a unity of interest-e.g., buyer's employees only did corporate work, buyer's corporate location was separate from owner's home, and buyer's finances were kept separate from owner's finances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate buyer's sole owner was not personally liable for the contractual obligations of corporate buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Port Drivers Federation 18, Inc. v. All Saints Exp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Trucking company and parent corporation sued by contracting truckers lacked sufficient alter-ego relationship to warrant piercing of corporate veil as to parent under New Jersey law; allegations that company was undercapitalized, did not pay dividends and did not have functioning board of directors did not suffice for court to find that company was mere instrumentality of parent.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Carriers. Primary business exemption to federal Truth in Leasing regulations was inapplicable to truckers' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Latham v. Burgher
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
