Title: Fresh Del Monte Produce N.V. v. Eastbrook Caribe A.V.V.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Defendants were not liable for violating release executed by related company, following settlement agreement between the parties of a prior action, on theory that defendants were acting as equitable assignees of related company in commencing prior action, absent any evidence from which to conclude that defendants and related company were alter egos of each other or otherwise ignored the corporate form, as to make one accountable for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Defendants were not liable for violating release executed by related company in settlement agreement between parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dombroski v. WellPoint, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Belmont County.
Headnote: Alleged breach of duty to act in good faith in handling claim for a second cochlear implant was an unjust or inequitable act for piercing health insurer's corporate veil to hold parent and sister corporations liable; parent corporation's control over its subsidiaries allegedly was exercised in such a manner as to violate duty of good faith and fair dealing.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Insured stated claim against health insurer's parent and sister corporations for bad faith denial of claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dombroski v. WellPoint, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Belmont County.
Headnote: Insured's allegations of loss from control and wrong exercised by parent corporation over health insurer and other subsidiaries in denying claim for second cochlear implant as investigative satisfied injury or unjust loss element for piercing insurer's corporate veil to hold parent and sister corporations liable for alleged bad faith; insured claimed physical and pecuniary loss, emotional distress, impaired earning capacity, and lessened likelihood of a successful future implant.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Insured stated claim against health insurer's parent and sister corporations for bad faith denial of claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Adams v. Unum Life Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Rome Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, insurer's parent corporation was not liable, on an alter ego theory, on insured's breach of contract claims regarding denial of long-term disability benefits; the insurer was not insolvent or unable to meet any judgment, so as to require the insured to seek recourse from the parent, and the corporate forms were not being used to work an injustice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Health. Insurer's parent corporation was not liable, on an alter ego theory, on insured's breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Saucier v. Coldwell Banker JME Realty
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Southern Division.
Headnote: Defendant president/sole shareholder of real estate brokerage firm was not personally liable under Mississippi law, under principles of agency law, for alleged breaches of the firm's contracts with plaintiff real estate agent, i.e., an independent contractor agreement and an on-site sales agreement, which alleged breaches related to alleged misrepresentations of condominium inventories/listings, alleged work conditions impeding productive work, alleged inability to sell or list real estate other than units at a single condominium project, disputes over commission allocation and number of sales attributable to plaintiff, and alleged illegal or unethical activities by the firm, in absence of evidence that defendant's acts in executing the contracts were ultra vires or that defendant acted in bad faith, practiced deceit, or otherwise misled plaintiff into entering the contracts with the firm.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Agents and Brokers. Mississippi real estate agent could not recover statutory penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rosson v. McFarland
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, one must demonstrate: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance, (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals, and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner could not pierce corporate veil because he failed to demonstrate frustration of contractual expectations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rosson v. McFarland
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Homeowner failed to demonstrate that he experienced frustration of his contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance on contract to build home, as required to pierce the corporate veil of development corporation, in his breach of contract action against corporation, builder and corporation's president; contract for building home was between homeowner and the corporation, president told homeowner before he executed the contract that she was building homes through the corporation, homeowner testified he paid the corporation for construction, and all supplies and materials for construction were paid for through the corporation's checking account.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner could not pierce corporate veil because he failed to demonstrate frustration of contractual expectations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Actual fraud was not an independent ground of recovery when home purchasers tried to pierce the corporate veil under the Single Business Enterprise and Alter Ego theories, in their breach of contract and fraud action against builder, developer, related businesses and common owner, and thus a separate question on and a jury finding of actual fraud was not required in order to pierce the corporate veil. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21; Vernon's Ann.Texas Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 279.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pae v. Chul Yoon
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Defendant owner of corporation, which had contracted with plaintiff for the sale and purchase of goods, was personally liable under the agreement by means of piercing the corporate veil, where plaintiff and the corporation entered into a valid agreement, defendant, the sole owner of the corporation, dominated the corporation and was solely responsible for the wrongful failure of the corporation to pay the plaintiff, and there were no corporate formalities, such as a distinction between corporate funds and the defendant's personal funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant owner of corporation which had contracted with plaintiff was personally liable under agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Penn Nat. Gaming, Inc. v. Ratliff
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: The general rule is that the corporate entity will not be disregarded in contract claims unless the complaining party can demonstrate: (1) some frustration of expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; and (3) a demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Parent company of casino operator was not liable for operator's alleged violations of dram shop law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Penn Nat. Gaming, Inc. v. Ratliff
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: The corporate veil will not be pierced, in either contract or tort claims, except where there is some abuse of the corporate form itself.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Parent company of casino operator was not liable for operator's alleged violations of dram shop law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Antaeus Enterprises, Inc. v. SD-Barn Real Estate, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the director of a corporation ordinarily is not personally liable for causing the corporation to breach its contracts unless grounds exist to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New Hampshire law applied in determining whether corporation's owner was liable for corporation's breach.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tower Investors, LLC v. 111 East Chestnut Consultants, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Investor, which had entered into forbearance agreement with real estate development subsidiary and its parent company to refrain from collecting for one year on subsidiary's defaulted loan, and law firm, which provided legal services to subsidiary and parent and whose partners constituted the members of investor, were separate entities, and equitable doctrine of piercing the corporate veil did not apply, such that investor did not commit an anticipatory breach of the forbearance agreement when firm brought action against subsidiary and parent to collect unpaid legal fees; parent and subsidiary had full knowledge of the relationship between firm and investor when they requested legal services and asked for investment money, parent's general counsel rather than firm drafted forbearance agreement, such agreement was supported by consideration, and parent and subsidiary could not pierce the corporate veil to circumvent a situation from which they had benefited. Rules of Prof.Conduct, Rule 1.8.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Investor, whose members came from law firm, did not breach forbearance agreement when firm brought action to collect fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tower Investors, LLC v. 111 East Chestnut Consultants, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In breach of contract cases, courts should apply more stringent standards to determine when to pierce the corporate veil than they would in tort cases, because the party seeking relief in a contract case is presumed to have voluntarily and knowingly entered into an agreement with a corporate entity, and is expected to suffer the consequences of the limited liability associated with the corporate business form.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Investor, whose members came from law firm, did not breach forbearance agreement when firm brought action to collect fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tower Investors, LLC v. 111 East Chestnut Consultants, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: In a breach of contract case additional compelling facts beyond those required in a tort case, such as a finding of fraud, may be required in order pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Investor, whose members came from law firm, did not breach forbearance agreement when firm brought action to collect fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tower Investors, LLC v. 111 East Chestnut Consultants, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Where there is no evidence of any misrepresentation, no attempt to conceal any facts, and the parties possess a total understanding of all of the transactions involved, courts will not pierce the corporate veil in a breach of contract situation.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Investor, whose members came from law firm, did not breach forbearance agreement when firm brought action to collect fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Southern Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, potentially wrongful conduct of life insurer could serve as a basis to attach liability against corporation that acquired insurer's parent corporation, and acquiring corporation's subsidiary, in consolidated actions brought by independent contractors hired by insurer to market and sell insurance products, alleging claims for declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, and breach of contract, although insurer was not properly named as a defendant in the actions, where acquiring corporation and its subsidiary had ample opportunity to prove that liability should not be imputed against them for potentially wrongful acts of insurer, and, under the single business enterprise theory, it would be unfair for a corporation to fragment itself in the manner independent contractors alleged in order to avoid liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under single business enterprise theory, affiliated corporations could be liable for acts of separate corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Banks v. Correctional Services Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under New York law, parent and subsidiary corporations are treated as separate legal entities, and a contract by one does not legally bind the other.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Putative employee sufficiently stated age discrimination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Banks v. Correctional Services Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to hold a parent liable for a subsidiary's breach of contract bears the burden of establishing that the parent corporation exercised complete domination of the subsidiary corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Putative employee sufficiently stated age discrimination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Banks v. Correctional Services Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil could not be pierced to hold president of company plaintiff had contracted with personally liable for breach of contract, where president acted in official capacity when signing contract, he no longer had ownership interest in company, and he did not terminate employee's contract.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Putative employee sufficiently stated age discrimination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Servo Kinetics, Inc. v. Tokyo Precision Instruments Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, alleged breach of contract, namely, an exclusive distribution agreement, by Japanese manufacturer of servo valves was type of "fraud or wrong" that would support piercing corporate veil, so as to hold manufacturer's parent corporation liable in breach of contract action by valve distributor, where although distributor contracted with manufacturer when manufacturer was a separate entity, facts that would justify piercing the corporate veil all arose as result of parent's acquisition of manufacturer, and alleged rumors that parent would acquire manufacturer, at time agreement was entered, were not binding in any way upon distributor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer's alleged breach of agreement was type of fraud or wrong that would support piercing parent's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation v. MDL Active Duration Fund, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Institutional investor stated basis for piercing corporate veil under Ohio law, to permit investor to pursue its unjust enrichment claims against principal of corporate investment advisor to corporate investment fund, on allegations, among other things, that principal, who was investor's primary contact with advisor and fund, was person who personally provided investor with investment advice and was given authority to make decisions regarding investor's investments, and principal engaged in fraudulent acts which were possible by reason of his position with advisor and fund.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investor stated claim based on relationship and injury which was distinct from its status as shareholder in investment fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: John John, LLC v. Exit 63 Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Building company, real estate company, and development company were not alter egos of each other, so corporate veil would not be pierced in action, inter alia, for reformation of contract, for judgment declaring that certain property was subject to equitable restriction, and to recover damages for breach of contract; in affidavit, member of all three companies stated that each of them had different ownership and engaged in different field of business, although they did share office space.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Building company, real estate company, and development company were not alter egos of each other, for veil-piercing purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Chira
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Ft. Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a parent corporation was liable for its subsidiary's debt where the subsidiary had no bank account, no assets, no capital, and no employees, and the subsidiary had entered into the contract with the creditor knowing that it had no ability to perform the contract because all of its revenues were deposited directly to the parent's account.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Ex-wife breached her fiduciary duties of loyalty and care, warranting equitable subordination of her claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Heath v. Palmer
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Homeowners could not hold the sole shareholder of the defendant development company personally liable under a theory of corporate "alter-ego," in homeowners' breach of contract and warranty action relating to the construction and sale of their new home, absent evidence that the shareholder was using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Remand was required as to finding that development company's liability was limited to one year from the date of closing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Morningside Fuel Corp. v. Associated Fuel Oil, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Assuming that proposed buyer's corporate veil could be pierced to reach a non-shareholder, proposed seller was required to produce evidence tending to show the requisite wrongful conduct to establish non-shareholder's liability for breach of contract to purchase corporate assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Purported joint venturer did not make prima facie showing that did not breach contract to purchase corporate assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporation which entered into contract to provide magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) device to medical clinic was operated as alter ego of its sole shareholder, as first prerequisite under Ohio law for piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract and fraud in connection with sales transaction, where corporation was undercapitalized and insolvent at time that it entered into sales agreement, and where shareholder admittedly disregarded corporate formalities in allowing salesperson employed by corporation to hold himself out as corporate officer and in using funds in corporate checking account for personal expenditures.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Simple breach of contract cannot suffice as type of illegal or fraudulent act that is required under Ohio law in order to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: While corporate-seller's breach of contract, in failing to deliver magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) device to medical clinic as it had contracted to do, was not type of illegal or fraudulent act that was required under Ohio law in order to pierce corporate veil and to hold its sole shareholder personally liable for any resulting injury to medical clinic, shareholder's conduct, in permitting his undercapitalized and insolvent corporation to enter into this contract to obtain clinic's $77,000 deposit, with full knowledge that corporation did not have MRI device to sell and lacked the financial wherewithal to acquire one, while failing to return medical clinic's deposit when, as shareholder should have anticipated, the corporation was unable to deliver, rose to level of fraudulent use of corporate form, and permitted veil to be pierced to holder shareholder liable for medical clinic's resulting injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: American Capital Corp. v. F.D.I.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: A shareholder's participation in contract negotiations or funding of a particular transaction does not alter its intentional adoption of the corporate form to limit its own liability; to allow a shareholder to recover the same breach of contract damages both individually and through the corporation would result in an impermissible double recovery.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Savings and Loans. Owner of insolvent thrift could not recover equity value of insolvent thrift's stock as damages in Winstar-related action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: d'Elia v. Rice Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Courts are extraordinarily reluctant to lift the veil in contract cases where the creditor has willingly transacted business with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. The owner of a limited liability company was personally liable for tortious acts of the company in which he participated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Camofi Master LDC v. College Partnership, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, investment funds did not so dominate investment banking firm that created them as to render them liable under alter ego theory for company's alleged breach of contract with customer that had borrowed money from funds, even if it was possible that funds were firms' alter egos.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Financial advisor's purported fraudulent inducement could not serve as defense in action to collect sums due under notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sieron & Associates, Inc. v. Department of Ins.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Decision of Fair Access to Insurance Requirements (FAIR) Plan Association not to renew property insurance for single-family homes owned or controlled by corporations that had, as a shareholder, a member of a certain family that owned more than 650 single-family homes in one area did not pierce corporate veil. (Per McGlynn, J., with two Justices concurring specially). S.H.A. 215 ILCS 5/522 et seq.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Property. Nonrenewal of property insurance held by family members did not violate Fair Access to Insurance Requirements Plan statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Farmers Alliance Mut. Ins. Co. v. Naylor
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was unwarranted, for purpose of holding fire investigator who owned fire investigation corporation personally liable, in property insurer's action alleging breach of contract and professional negligence, arising from investigator's alleged failure to preserve evidence of the origin of fire on insured's premises; corporation adhered to corporate formalities, it was operated in a legitimate way to serve the goals of the corporation, rather than for the benefit of the individual investigator, corporation was properly capitalized, and there was no showing that investigator's corporate status was linked to insurer's alleged injury.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Economic loss rule did not bar professional negligence claim arising from service contract with fire investigator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Southeast Texas Inns, Inc. v. Prime Hospitality Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee and Delaware law on piercing corporate veil, the injustice must be more than the breach of contract alleged in the complaint.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Hotel lessor could not recover from corporation for lessee's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Southeast Texas Inns, Inc. v. Prime Hospitality Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee and Delaware law, allegations pertaining to the mere breach of an underlying contract or undercapitalization, alone, do not warrant piercing the corporate veil in order to hold the parent corporation liable for such breach.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Hotel lessor could not recover from corporation for lessee's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jacobson v. Business Machines Experts, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Company purchasing an equipment business was not entitled to an award of damages for breach of contract as imposed against the owner of the business in his individual capacity; the individual owner was not a party to any contract with the purchasing company, and did not use the corporate form of his business to achieve an inequitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Nine checks written on an account sold as an asset by equipment business constituted breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ice Corp. v. Hamilton Sundstrand Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Allegations that parent corporation used contract between its purported subsidiary and plaintiff as a negotiating tool, that parent corporation exercised a large degree of control over purported subsidiary's business operations, and that injustice was possible since parent corporation had received a benefit under the contract for which purported subsidiary might not be liable and for which plaintiff might not be compensated, were sufficient to state claim for breach of contract under Kansas law.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Dismissal of negligent misrepresentation claims was not warranted on ground that they reiterated contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Waste Conversion Technologies, Inc. v. Warren Recycling, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, a waste transfer station bringing a breach of contract claim could not pierce the corporate veil of a landfill operator to hold liable the corporate successor in interest to the operator's landfill permit, as the successor was not a shareholder of the operator.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landfill operator's corporate veil could not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Waste Conversion Technologies, Inc. v. Warren Recycling, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, waste transfer station bringing a breach of contract claim could not pierce the corporate veil of a landfill operator to hold its shareholders liable; the operator's corporate form was not a mere shell, but rather, the shareholders received salaries and were paid for services rendered, and in any event, the type of fraud alleged was that protected by the fraudulent conveyance law and did not rise to the level required to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landfill operator's corporate veil could not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hotel Associates, Inc. v. Howard Johnson Franchise Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, purchase of hotel at foreclosure sale constituted a "change of ownership" within meaning of license agreement's requirement that advance notice of such change be given to licensor, at risk of termination of the agreement, even though same individual was sole shareholder of both corporation that sold the property and corporation that bought the property.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Failure to give notice of change in ownership did not result in automatic termination of hotel license agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Moses Lake Const. Co., Inc. v. Johnson
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3.
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate form was unnecessary to prevent loss to truck lessor, which brought breach of contract action against two related construction companies and their sole shareholder and manager, as lessor had remedy of either suing first company or suing manager individually.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Company specifically waived in lease agreement any claim against truck lessor for damages due to repossession of trucks.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Williams v. Younginer
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Vendor was individually liable to purchasers for breach of express warranty on home regarding leaky basement, given that "homeowners manual" that contained the warranty mentioned only the vendor's personal name and the trade name he used to build and sell homes, not the corporate name vendor claimed was the liable party.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Deeds. Implied warranties of habitability and workmanship did not merge into the deed conveying the property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hollow Road Farms, Inc. v. Quo Vadis Intern., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Equitable concept of piercing the corporate veil was properly applied to support consultant's recovery personally against principal shareholder of client for breach of contract; principal signed contract in his individual capacity and paid consultant with personal funds from checking account held jointly with his wife, an employee wholly unrelated to corporation actually signed these checks, and corporation did not have operating agreement, an actual office or separate telephone line.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Finding that consultant performed obligations of contract was supported by sufficient evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Advanced Const. Corp. v. Pilecki
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Homeowners could not pierce the corporate veil, in breach of contract, breach of warranty, negligence, violation of Home Construction Contract Act, violation of trade practices statutes, and abuse of process action against corporation home builder and its sole shareholder, absent evidence that corporation was undercapitalized, insolvent or bankrupt, or evidence that a verdict against corporation would be worth less than a verdict against shareholder. 10 M.R.S.A. §§ 1486-1490.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Evidence established that shareholder of home builder participated in wrongful acts and was personally liable to homeowners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Creative Soft Solutions v. Soaring Eagle Consulting
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: District court was not required to pierce corporate veil in action brought by consultant against staffing company, alleging breach of contract to develop human resources software package; corporate formalities had been generally followed, with exception of eleventh hour payment via wire transfer on single occasion by principal intending to save company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court was not required to pierce corporate veil in action alleging breach of contract to develop software package.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: MSF Holding Ltd. v. Fiduciary Trust Co. Intern.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, a parent corporation and its subsidiary are regarded under New York law as legally distinct entities and a contract under the corporate name of one is not treated as that of both.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Parent corporation was precluded from enforcing rights assigned to its affiliate under letter of credit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, an inequitable result would not occur based on failure to hold parent corporation liable for judgment obtained against wholly owned subsidiary, in action for fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of warranty, and thus, alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation; there was no showing that parent corporation was involved with any fraud against judgment creditor, or that parent corporation knew what representations that subsidiary made to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Western Reserve Life Assur. Co. of Ohio v. Bratton
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: Exceptional circumstances did not exist to allow for piercing corporate veil of parent holding company under Iowa law, for alleged breach of contract by one subsidiary, based on parent's ownership of several subsidiaries, subsidiaries' shared office space, sale of insurance products by same employees for each subsidiary, and consolidation of administrative, actuarial, and legal activities of each subsidiary under one name.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Verbal agreement had not been integrated and merged into subsequent written agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Export ban enacted by government of Turkmenistan was not a "fraud or injustice," as required to satisfy second prong of test for proving that government was the alter ego of a government-owned oil company with which Argentine company had entered into joint venture agreement; while government's exercise of its sovereign powers to control Turkmenistan's borders in this way may have constituted a wrong to the Argentine company, it was not a wrong based on misuse of the corporate organizational form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Government of Turkmenistan's manipulation of its wholly-owned oil company so as to prevent Argentine corporation that had entered into joint venture agreement (JVA) with oil company from recovering any substantial damage award resulting from oil company's violation of the JVA satisfied the "fraud or injustice" prong of the alter ego doctrine; government dissolved entity that had executed JVA with Argentine corporation and replaced it with oil company, oil company was initially capitalized with the equivalent of only $17,000.00 and was funded by a state oil and gas development fund expressly rendered immune from seizure under newly enacted Turkmenian law, oil company nonetheless became the party bound to arbitrate under the JVA and liable for any adverse award, and at the same time the government issued a number of decrees distancing itself from the joint venture and attempting to limit its potential liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Government of Turkmenistan exercised such complete control over its wholly-owned oil company, which had entered into joint venture agreement (JVA) with Argentine company to conduct hydrocarbon operations in Turkmenistan, as to be its alter ego, such that government could be liable for arbitration award arising out of oil company's violation of the JVA even though not a signatory to the JVA; although oil company exhibited certain "corporate formalities," reality of the corporate relationship was that government caused oil company's incorporation, there was some identity between high-ranking government and company officials, oil company was grossly undercapitalized, oil company was operated as a closely held subsidiary, oil company's revenues were diverted to a state oil and gas fund, and government did not deal with oil company at arm's length, but manipulated it legally and economically to repudiate the JVA and then render it impossible for Argentine company to collect damages.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporate veil would be pierced to hold a corporation's principal personally liable for the corporation's breach of a "Type II" preliminary agreement binding it to negotiate in good faith with a cable television network terms necessary to achieve the telecasting of a boat racing season; the principal put his own money into the corporation, then took it out again and transferred his funds to the another entity, and the principal completely dominated the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, specifically, the exercise of a renewal option and the negotiation of its terms.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Giordano ex rel. Estate of Brennan v. Atria Assisted Living, Virginia Beach, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, there are five instances where a non-signatory to a contract may be bound: incorporation by references; estoppel; agency; assumption; and veil piercing/alter ego.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Daughter did not act as mother's apparent agent in signing agreement for residence in assisted living facility.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: R.J. Brunelli & Co., Inc. v. Jamm Realty Corp.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Principal of corporation that sought to purchase commercial property was not personally liable for corporation's obligations under brokerage agreement with real estate broker, where there was no evidence that principal, as an individual, sought to use corporate form to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, and there was no evidence that broker considered itself to be dealing with principal in his personal capacity rather than as the representative of corporation's interests.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Agents and Brokers. Issue of whether broker was entitled to commission based on sale price of property was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Widlar v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Evidence proffered by customer of dating referral company at summary judgment hearing in her breach of contract action against company and its principal, which showed that principal was company's sole shareholder and sole director and that he personally made the decision to close the business and terminate its employees, was sufficient to support a finding that principal had such complete control over corporation that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, for purposes of customer's attempt to pierce the corporate veil and hold principal personally liable for corporation's acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Customer of dating referral company failed to present evidence that principal used his control of company to commit fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Performance under a contract is a "positive legal duty," for purposes of the element, for piercing of corporate veil, that defendant must use his control of the corporation to commit fraud or wrong such as the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cass v. Sands
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted with respect to shareholder of parent corporation concerning subsidiary corporation's alleged breach of asset purchase agreement concerning automobile dealership and alleged breach of employment contract; subsidiary corporation was sufficiently capitalized, corporate formalities were followed in formation of both corporations, and neither corporation was used to promote fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mages v. Johanns
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: The mere fact that an individual enters a valid and enforceable contract with a corporation does not give the individual an interest in the corporation or make the corporation his alter ego.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Subsidies. Corporation's interest in farmer's crop did not negate separate interest that farmer had in his own farming operation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Status of president of construction company as a nonshareholder in company did not preclude piercing the corporate veil and imposing personal liability on president in home purchasers' breach of contract action.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence for construction company would have sanctioned a fraud, promoted injustice, or promoted inequitable consequences, and thus, piercing the corporate veil of construction company was warranted, where the evidence indicated that president incorporated company and placed nominal ownership and control in the hands of his wife to shield himself personally from liabilities to which his general contracting activities exposed him, and that once a breach of contract lawsuit was filed against company, president began to sell off company's assets to the detriment of company's potential judgment creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Manshion Joho Center Co., Ltd. v. Manshion Joho Center, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate defendants' corporate veils in order to hold individual defendant personally liable in action for breach of property sale and commission agreements; individual defendant dominated and controlled his corporations, disregarded corporate formalities, used corporate funds to pay his personal bills, and effectively stripped the assets of the corporation transferred to him by plaintiff to enrich himself while making the corporation judgment proof, thus committing a wrong against plaintiff that resulted in injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Doctrine of unclean hands did not bar vendor from recovering damages for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cox Indus. Equipment Co., Inc. v. Smiley
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Allegation that officers and shareholders of company that provided plaintiffs with payroll services controlled and completely dominated the company's policy and business practices, leaving the corporate entity no separate mind or existence of its own, was sufficient, under Missouri law, to pierce the corporate veil, with respect to breach of contract claim.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Complaint stated claim for RICO conspiracy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ray-Tek Services, Inc. v. Parker
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Fact that sole stockholder and officer of corporate distributor of medical equipment controlled its operations was, by itself, insufficient basis for disregarding corporate form and attaching liability to officer individually for breach of joint venture agreement; other relevant factors for piercing the corporate veil included confused intermingling of business activities, assets, or management, observance of corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, no payment of dividends, insolvency at time of litigated transactions, siphoning away of corporate assets, nonfunctioning of officers and directors, and use of corporation by officer for his individual benefit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Distributor's officer, as fiduciary, was jointly and severally liable to account for joint venture's profits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Even if corporate owner of nursing home breached its contractual obligation to pay therapy services contractor for its services, such breach, standing alone, did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: A simple breach of contract, in the absence of a more substantial factual predicate indicative of some corporate malfeasance, with direct bearing on the plaintiff's injury, is insufficient to establish shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against plaintiff, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Failure of corporate owner of nursing home to apply Medicaid and Medicare reimbursement funds received by nursing home towards nursing home's contractual obligation to pay therapy services contractor for its services did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor; there was no evidence that nursing home was legally required to apply the funds to its contractual obligation, nor was there evidence of any legal restrictions on nursing home's use of Medicaid and Medicare reimbursement funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Even if corporate owner of nursing home could have drawn on its line of credit with bank, to pay invoices from nursing home's therapy services contractor, failure to make such draws did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor; shareholder was not legally required to draw on line of credit, failure to make draws avoided increasing corporation's debt to a secured creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Even if failure of corporate owner of nursing home to draw on its line of credit with bank, to pay invoices from nursing home's therapy services contractor, allowed shareholder, as guarantor of corporation's debt to bank, to avoid increasing his personal liability to bank, such conduct did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Music Express Broadcasting Corp. v. Aloha Sports, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Geauga County.
Headnote: Company demonstrated that control of corporation was exercised in such a manner as to commit illegal act against person seeking to pierce the corporate veil, as element of Belvedere test to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on majority shareholder; majority shareholder benefited from trades that were made with company's stations, deposited funds in his personal account without proper accounting, misrepresented corporation's ability to perform terms of contract entered into with company, and ceased operations without notice to company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. That other persons exercised management authority did not preclude finding that corporation was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re National Audit Defense Network
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Parent corporation of company with which Chapter 7 debtor had contracted to process its customers' credit card payments could not be sued for breach of contract under the credit card processing agreement executed by debtor and company; as a subagent hired without debtor's express or implicit authority, the parent corporation was not in contractual privity with debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee had no turnover claim against company that processed credit card payments made by debtor's customers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Maroun v. Wyreless Systems, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2005 Term.
Headnote: Refusing to pierce the corporate veil of employer, to make shareholders personally liable to employee who joined the start-up company as chief executive officer (CEO), would not result in injustice; employee had been warned that the business was justgetting off the ground, that the business would need to be developed, that more funds needed to be raised, that the business was not yet organized, and that failure of fundraising efforts was possible.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Employer's representations were not actionable as fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in breach of contract class action lot purchasers brought against corporate developer, developer's corporate owner and principal behind both corporations after lake in development failed to hold water, that principal was the alter ego of the corporate developer and thus liable for judgment rendered against developer; there was evidence that, while controversy over the breach of contract was pending, developer at the request of principal transferred $2.4 million worth of land contracts to its corporate owner in return for a promissory note without requesting any security for the note, principal never appeared in court or at depositions to explain the transfer, there was evidence that corporate owner of developer subsequently transferred over $5 million in assets to principal such that there were no assets to pay note to developer, and there was no evidence of any transfers of funds from principal back to the corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Foamex, L.P. v. Superior Products Sales, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, seller failed to provide proof of fraud or equivalent misfeasance, as required to pierce corporate buyer's veil and hold its sole shareholder liable, in breach of contract action, for payment allegedly due for products that buyer purchased prior to going out of business, even though shareholder undertook to personally pay some of debts buyer owed to seller, where seller and buyer were each sophisticated business entities sharing a business relationship spanning several years, during which time seller could have required a written guarantee from shareholder personally.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent proof of fraud or equivalent misfeasance on part of shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, allegations that corporate seller's shareholder was the "prime mover" in timber agreement, which corporation allegedly breached, and "knew and assisted" in fraudulent sale of corporation's property by unauthorized individual purporting to be corporation's agent were insufficient to show that shareholder engaged in improper conduct, as would support buyer's claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder, where buyer did not rely on any representation by shareholder in entering into timber agreement with corporation, and there was nothing in the record to refute shareholder's deposition testimony that he did not know of unauthorized individual's representation of corporation and transfer of corporation's property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, shareholder's initial capitalization of corporation with only $2,500, when compared to corporation's later agreement to sell $170,000 worth of timber, was not gross undercapitalization, as would support buyer's claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability for alleged breach of timber contract on shareholder, where there was no showing that shareholder formed corporation without due regard for projected internal costs; unauthorized fraudulent sale of timber land by individual who purported to be corporation's agent was not a reasonably foreseeable liability, nor a risk associated with corporation's normal operating costs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, fact that administratively dissolved corporation was now out of business and could not pay judgment against it was not a sufficient basis on which to conclude that it was undercapitalized when formed, as would support claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability for alleged breach of contract on shareholder who formed corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, allegations that corporation's shareholder improperly drained corporation's assets by making distributions, loans, racehorse purchases, and payments were insufficient to show that shareholder engaged in improper "milking" of corporation, as would warrant piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder for corporation's alleged breach of contract, where there was no evidence supporting allegations, and purported milking did not cause corporation to breach contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, even if corporation's shareholder improperly drained corporation's assets by making distributions, loans, racehorse purchases, and payments, buyer had adequate statutory remedy for corporation's alleged breach of timber sales contract, and thus, extraordinary remedy of piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder for corporation's alleged breach was not warranted; statute allowed for enforcement of default judgment that buyer obtained against corporation by potentially recouping any shareholder distributions made to shareholder during liquidation of corporation's assets. West's Or.Rev. Stat. Ann. § 60.645.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Perry v. Unum Life Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold disability insurer's parent company liable for insurer's alleged breach of contract resulting from denial of benefits; parent company was not party to contract, and insured did not allege that insurer had insufficient assets to satisfy her claim.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Disability. Parent of disability insurer was not liable for tortious interference with insurance contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Moses v. Martin
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, celebrity wardrobe stylist's allegations that managing agency with which she had contract acted as alter-ego, business conduit and instrumentality of its principal, and that principal used proceeds from alleged racketeering activity for personal purposes, were sufficient to state claims against principal, including breach of contract and fraud, based on piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. A managing agency could not be held vicariously liable under RICO for acts of its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wafra Leasing Corp. 1999-A-1 v. Prime Capital Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, an exception to the general rule that an officer is not liable for his corporation's breach of contract exists when facts are proven sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Damages. Investor could not seek unjust enrichment or disgorgement damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rimade Ltd. v. Hubbard Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in order to pierce corporate veil in cases based on claims of breach of contract, plaintiff must demonstrate that defendant shareholder caused corporation to be used for purpose of perpetrating, and that shareholder did perpetrate an actual fraud on plaintiff primarily for direct personal benefit of shareholder. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil could not be pierced based on shareholder's alleged fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veils of affiliated corporations could not be pierced, in order to hold them liable for corporate defendant's alleged breach of contract, upon theory that they had knowingly and intentionally procured corporate defendant's breach; other party to contract failed to allege any facts, apart from ownership of corporate defendant's stock and control that these affiliated corporations thereby had over corporate defendant, to support its veil-piercing claim.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.
