Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mars Electronics of N.Y., Inc. v. U.S.A. Direct, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's domination of corporation, with respect to two specific transactions, was used to perpetrate a fraud against judgment creditor so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable under New York law; however, absent evidence of fraud or wrongful conduct, there was an insufficient basis under New York law upon which to pierce corporate veil as to remaining transactions.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of corporation sought to hold corporation's sole shareholder personally liable for the judgment. Upon creditor's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Trager, J., held that: (1) evidence established that sole shareholder dominated and controlled every aspect of corporation's business affairs such as to render corporation shareholder's alter ego under New York law, and (2) shareholder's domination of corporation, with respect to two specific transactions, was used to perpetrate a fraud against judgment creditor so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable under New York law. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Anderson v. McAllister Towing and Transp. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, general manager of corporate employer's operations in Middle East had full authority, as employer's alter ego, to enter into employment contract with third party on employer's behalf.
Document Preview: Captain of vessel brought action against his former employers and vessel, seeking wages, severance pay and other damages stemming from termination of his employment. Following bench trial, the District Court, Vollmer, J., held that: (1) personal jurisdiction could not be exercised over vessel due to captain's failure to properly serve vessel; (2) former employers' notice of their intent to raise issue of Saudi Arabian law was untimely and inadequate; (3) captain was unable to recover wages under sections of Seaman's Wage Act providing remedies to seamen; (4) geographic scope of captain's employment contract was not ambiguous; and (5) individual who entered into employment contract with captain on former employers' behalf had actual authority to do so. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Anderson v. McAllister Towing and Transp. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, manager in charge of corporate employer had valid authority, as employer's alter ego, to enter into employment contract with third party on behalf of employer.
Document Preview: Captain of vessel brought action against his former employers and vessel, seeking wages, severance pay and other damages stemming from termination of his employment. Following bench trial, the District Court, Vollmer, J., held that: (1) personal jurisdiction could not be exercised over vessel due to captain's failure to properly serve vessel; (2) former employers' notice of their intent to raise issue of Saudi Arabian law was untimely and inadequate; (3) captain was unable to recover wages under sections of Seaman's Wage Act providing remedies to seamen; (4) geographic scope of captain's employment contract was not ambiguous; and (5) individual who entered into employment contract with captain on former employers' behalf had actual authority to do so. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Falcon Associates, Inc. v. Cox
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Corporate homebuilder-vendor, a related corporation, and their principal could be treated as a single entity under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, in a suit by purchasers of a defective home, where the builder-vendor corporation originally had four partners but now consisted only of the principal, issued no stock, paid no dividends, and transferred all its assets to the related corporation after the purchasers began demanding repairs, and where a statement of the case directing that all three parties would be treated as a single entity was never objected to.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Homebuilder-vendor was potentially liable under Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act to purchasers of home even absent intent to deceive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Huard v. Shreveport Pirates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, ultimate inquiry of whether corporate veil should be pierced requires balance of policies behind recognition of separate corporate existence with policies justifying piercing; this balance is less likely to tip in favor of disregarding corporate veil when underlying claim is based on contract.
Document Preview: Former vice president and head coach for football team brought suits against team and its sole owner arising out of their termination.  Actions were consolidated.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, Donald E. Walter, J., refused to impose personal liability on owner, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dennis, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was insufficient evidence of fraud to pierce corporate veil on that basis, and (2) there was insufficient evidence of disregard of corporate formalities to support piercing of corporate veil on that basis. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mangum v. Maryland Cas. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Reverse piercing of corporate veil was unjustified in order to treat close corporation's sole shareholders and their child as Class I insureds entitled to stack underinsured motorist (UIM) benefits under policy issued to corporation as only named insured. Code 1976, § 38–77–160.
Document Preview: Sole shareholders of named insured sought declaratory judgment that they were entitled to stack underinsured motorist (UIM) coverages under corporation's policy.  The Circuit Court, Greenville County, Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Acting Judge, entered summary judgment in favor of insurer.  Shareholders appealed. The Court of Appeals, Stilwell, J., held that: (1) policy issued to close corporation as only named insured had no Class I insureds entitled to stack UIM benefits, and (2) sole shareholders and their child were thus Class II insureds, not Class I insureds, as to corporate vehicle. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Seller, which sold repossessed vehicles for finance company, and automobile dealerships, with which finance company had master dealer agreements, were not operated as single business entity, as required to hold dealers liable under Texas law for seller's for breach its consignment agreement with finance company; evidence of transfer of funds among corporations, transfer of one group of seller's employees to one of the dealers, and existence of one common shareholder were insufficient to establish single corporate identity.
Document Preview: Finance company sued automobile seller for breach of consignment contract under which seller sold repossessed automobiles, and also against other dealers with which finance company had master dealership agreements. On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) seller and other dealers were not operated as single business entity; (2) there was no actual fraud by seller; and (3) there was no fiduciary duty on part of seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Maltz v. Union Carbide Chemicals & Plastics Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, parent and subsidiary corporations are treated as separate legal entities under New York law, and contract by one does not legally bind the other.
Document Preview: Marble care franchisees brought action against franchisor, franchisor's parent and grandparent corporations, and various officers, directors and employees, alleging various tort and contract violations.  On defendants' motion to dismiss, the District Court, Kimba M. Wood, J., on report and recommendation of Katz, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) law of state in which franchises were located applied to their tort claims, and New York law applied to their contract claims; (2) allegations were sufficient to state claim for alter ego liability against parent under New York law; (3) warranty disclaimer in chemical purchase agreement was sufficiently conspicuous and specific to be enforceable under New York law; (4) franchisees' allegations were sufficient to state fraud claim; (5) allegations were sufficient to state negligent misrepresentation claim; (6) allegations were sufficient to state civil conspiracy claim; (7) allegations were sufficient to state claim for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Payroll Exp. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, corporation which was legitimately engaged in business of cashing payroll checks for over 20 years was not mere alter ego of husband and wife that owned and controlled it, such that shareholders' wrongful acts in diverting funds from corporation had to be considered acts of corporation itself, so as to preclude coverage for such wrongful acts under employee dishonesty and crime policies issued to corporation; corporation, which kept its own books and appeared to have had its own bank accounts, creditors and clients, served many legitimate business purposes and was not mere vehicle for shareholders' misconduct.
Document Preview: Insurance - Prior losses in excess of $2.3 million that insured failed to disclose on its application for insurance were material as matter of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, university student was "equitable owner" of computer software company that was established to market software developed by student because student exercised considerable authority over company to point of completely disregarding corporate form and acting as though its assets were his alone to manage and distribute, and student thus could be held personally liable for company's actions by piercing corporate veil, regardless of fact that student was neither shareholder, officer, director, nor employee of computer software company.
Document Preview: Salesperson for computer software company which was controlled by university student who had developed computer software brought action against company, successor corporation, and student, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Kaplan, J., 931 F.Supp. 1115, granted salesperson's motion to compel student and company to arbitrate claims, pursuant to salesperson's contract with company, but denied motion to arbitrate claims against successor corporation, staying those claims pending outcome of arbitration with student and company.  Student appealed, and salesperson cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Miner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Court of Appeals had jurisdiction over cross-appeal; (2) Court of Appeals would exercise jurisdiction over appeal under doctrine of pendent appellate jurisdiction; (3) student was equitable owner of company who...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: NorDar Holdings, Inc. v. Western Securities (USA) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas statute, actual fraud is required in order to disregard corporate entity and hold shareholder liable for corporation's contractual obligations under single business enterprise theory. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against shareholder of debtor corporation, seeking to collect deficiency on debtor's promissory note under doctrines of alter ego and single business enterprise. The District Court, Sanders, Senior District Judge, held that debtor corporation's financial statement, which allegedly glossed over debtor's limited liquid assets, was insufficient to establish that corporation and its shareholder perpetrated actual fraud against creditor, as required to impose liability on shareholder under single business enterprise or alter ego theory. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Horsehead Industries, Inc. v. Metallgesellschaft AG
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent company can be held liable as party to its subsidiary's contract if parent's conduct manifests intent to be bound by contract, which intent is inferable from parent's participation in negotiation of contract, or if subsidiary is dummy for parent, or if subsidiary is controlled by parent for parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders Agreement. Complaint stated cause of action for breach of shareholders agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Classic Office Supplies, Inc. v. Classic Commercial Office Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Court properly pierced corporate veil and imposed corporate obligation for rescission of contract upon corporation's sole officer, director and shareholder; such individual intentionally made material misrepresentation of fact upon which other party to contract relied, forming basis for recission.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Veil. Court properly pierced corporate veil to impose corporate obligation for rescission of contract upon corporation's sole officer, director and shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Classic Office Supplies, Inc. v. Classic Commercial Office Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Court properly awarded judgment on corporate contract to shareholder, where parties had agreed at trial to disregard corporate forms since all involved corporations had been dissolved.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Veil. Court properly pierced corporate veil to impose corporate obligation for rescission of contract upon corporation's sole officer, director and shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dieter Engineering Services, Inc. v. Parkland Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: In case involving alleged breach of contract, to pierce corporate veil in order to hold shareholders actively participating in operation of business personally liable for such breach to party who entered into contract with corporation, there is normally two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and of individual shareholders no longer exist (disregard of formality as requirement) and (2) inequitable result would occur if acts are treated as those of corporation alone (fairness requirement).
Document Preview: Successor in interest to civil engineering firm brought suit in breach of contract against shopping center developer to recover amounts due for work performed and also sued shareholders and successor corporations of developer.  The Circuit Court, Randolph County, John L. Henning, J., directed verdict on issue of shareholder and successor corporation liability in favor of civil engineering firm, and entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of successor in interest for amounts owing under contract.  Defendants appealed. The Supreme Court of Appeals, McHugh, C.J., held that: (1) fact that successor in interest did not obtain certificate of authority as foreign corporation until after action was commenced did not require dismissal of action; (2) evidence did not show any defect that would have rendered assignment from civil engineering firm to successor in interest void; and (3) corporate veil was properly pierced to allow shareholder liability on contract debt....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Barnco Intern., Inc. v. Arkla, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Pierce of corporate veil between subsidiary corporation and parent corporation to hold parent corporation liable on contract entered into by subsidiary was not warranted, even though parent and subsidiary occasionally shared employees and several of the same individuals served on boards of both corporations; exact records were maintained as cash moved from one entity to the other, parent was not undercapitalized, subsidiary's board of directors conducted its affairs by consensual written minutes, subsidiary conducted business on its own, and subsidiary did not seek parental endorsement before entering into contract. (Per Hightower, J., with one Judge concurring in result and one Judge concurring in part and dissenting in part.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Parent corporation was not obligated under contract entered into by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Theberge v. Darbro, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: When plaintiff attempts, in context of contractual dispute, to pierce corporate veil, courts generally apply more stringent standards, as party seeking relief in contract case is presumed to have voluntarily and knowingly entered into agreement with corporate entity, and is expected to suffer consequences of limited liability associated with corporate business form.
Document Preview: Vendor and purchaser/subsequent vendor of real property sued person controlling ultimate purchaser, and another corporation controlled by him, seeking to recover amount remaining on note executed by purchaser/subsequent vendor to secure purchase price of property, which had been assumed by ultimate purchaser.  The Superior Court, Androscoggin County, Brennan, J., entered judgment for original vendor and purchaser/subsequent vendor and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Glassman, J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil, even though controlling person had allegedly represented that he would stand behind ultimate purchaser's obligations, as controlling person had not guaranteed note in question. Vacated and remanded. Lipez, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Skrzypczak v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Disregarding corporate form between automobile insurer and wholly owned subsidiary was unwarranted, and, thus, parent insurer that issued policy replacing policy issued by subsidiary could not defensively pierce its own corporate veil and avoid liability for failure to obtain written rejection of underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage in connection with the new policy. West's A.I.C. 27-7-5-2(b), 27-7-6-3.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Automobile. Insurer required to obtain written rejection of UIM coverage in connection with policy to replace policy issued by wholly owned subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Strodtman v. Integrity Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Adjacent landowners' allegations that president of developer negotiated with them resulting in contract to provide landscaping if landowners would not oppose development, that president acted on behalf of developer in agreeing to obligations that became part of contract, and that president acted alone during contract negotiations, did not show that president acted in way that ignored, controlled or manipulated developer's corporate form so as to warrant piercing of corporate form to hold president personally liable for developer's breach of contract.
Document Preview: REAL ESTATE - Contracts. Developer breached clear provision of contract with adjacent landowners by transferring land to another owner and thereby precluding its performance of contractual landscaping obligation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Outokumpu Engineering Enterprises, Inc. v. Kvaerner EnviroPower, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Delaware corporation, which was construction contractor being sued for breach of construction contract, was not alter ego of Swedish corporation having Norwegian corporation as common parent, so as to bring Swedish corporation within reach of Delaware long-arm statute; while there was some indication of Swedish corporation's involvement in affairs of Delaware corporation, there were no allegations that corporate structure in question was "shell game" or that there was any abuse of corporate forum to effect any fraud. 10 Del.C. § 3104(c)(1, 2).
Document Preview: Owner brought construction contract suit against contractor, which was Delaware corporation, its Delaware corporate parent, which was in turn a subsidiary of a Norwegian corporation not sued, and a Swedish corporation which was a subsidiary of the Norwegian corporation.  Motions to dismiss were made. The Superior Court, New Castle County, Herlihy, J., held that: (1) court lacked general personal jurisdiction over Swedish corporation; (2) court lacked specific personal jurisdiction, as Swedish corporation was not in same corporate chain as contractor and its parent and there was no basis for piercing corporate veils; (3) long-arm jurisdiction did not exist over Swedish corporation based upon its guarantee of performance by contractor, as it was not shown that payment of guarantee was to be made in Delaware; and (4) due process rights of Swedish corporation would be violated if Delaware court assumed jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hart v. Steel Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced to find sole shareholder personally liable for fraud in inducement of contract to sell business of corporation; shareholder was alleged to have fraudulently represented to buyers that corporation had income, in most recent accounting period, of $176,301.94, while in reality corporation had lost $4,344.76, and shareholders' equity had been fraudulently represented as $129,212.36, while in fact corporation was undercapitalized at a negative $51,434.34.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sale of business contract rescindable for fraud in inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Strong v. Hegarty
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division Boston Municipal Court Department
Headnote: Based on facts that no shareholder or director meetings were ever held, that individual defendant made all business decisions, that no employee salaries or wages were ever declared and that business workers' compensation insurance policy was subscribed to by defendant as an individual, trial court could properly disregard corporate entity and hold individual defendant personally liable on contract claim and claim brought under M.G.L.A. c. 93A.
Document Preview: This case has a protracted history before this Court.  After a trial in 1990, the plaintiffs prevailed on their complaint which alleged breach of contract, breach of warranty and violations of G.L.c. 93A against co-defendants Brendan Hegarty and Hegarty Construction Co., Inc., arising out of construction work on the plaintiffs' home done in 1985.  The initial trial court awarded $15,000 in damages, which were trebled under G.L.c. 93A, plus $5,000 in attorneys' fees.  The individual defendant, Brendan Hegarty, appealed the issue of his personal liability to this Court which remanded the matter to the initial trial judge to resolve an inconsistency in the trial judge's findings, specifically that both the corporate defendant and the individual defendant are liable to the plaintiffs. (Record Appendix at 269.)  The initial trial judge issued a Memorandum After Remand on November 22, 1991, in which he found,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Orlando Regional Healthcare System, Inc. v. Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division. .
Headnote: Defendant hospital system's merger with another system, whereby other system purchased defendant's stock and merged its subsidiary into defendant, did not effect a "transfer" of defendant's interest in a hospital it operated in joint venture with plaintiff hospital system and thus did not trigger plaintiff's right of first refusal under joint venture agreement, where defendant remained viable corporation with its subsidiary retaining direct ownership interest in the hospital; separate corporate existence of defendant and its subsidiary could not be ignored, under Florida law, absent proof that acquiring system maintained those corporations' separate identities to perpetrate fraud, mislead creditors or otherwise misuse the corporate form.
Document Preview: Plaintiff hospital system brought suit, alleging that defendant hospital system breached its joint venture agreement with plaintiff by not offering it the opportunity to purchase defendant's interest in hospital the parties operated in a joint venture. The District Court, G. Kendall Sharp, J., held that defendant breached provision of joint venture agreement entitling plaintiff to purchase defendant's interest in the venture if defendant received purchase offer from certain enumerated companies or their affiliates. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: MCI Telecommunications Corp. v. John Mezzalingua Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Telephone local exchange carrier's (LEC) corporate parent, which was not party to contracts between carrier and carrier's central switching service and call transferring unit customer, was not liable to customer under New York law for breach of contract or breach of warranty, arising from fraudulent third-party long-distance telephone calls placed through customer's system, despite contention that parent exercised such control over carrier that court should pierce the corporate veil between parent and carrier; there was no support for piercing the corporate veil, and customer submitted no evidence to support negligence claim against parent.
Document Preview: Long-distance telephone company brought action against telephone local exchange carrier's (LEC) central switching service and call transferring unit customer, seeking recovery of charges for fraudulent third-party long-distance telephone calls placed through customer's system.  Customer brought third-party complaint against carrier and carrier's corporate parent, asserting contract and negligence claims, and seeking indemnification and/or contribution.  Company, carrier, and parent moved for summary judgment, and customer moved for leave to file amended answer and to refer matter to Federal Communications Commission (FCC).  The District Court, Scullin, J., held that: (1) Commission did not have primary jurisdiction over action and, thus, referral of action to Commission was not required; (2) customer would not be granted leave to amend its answer to add affirmative defenses and counterclaims; (3) parent, which was not party to contracts...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kregos v. Latest Line, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Even if corporation breached its contract with plaintiff, such breach would not satisfy requirement, of Connecticut's instrumentality rule for disregarding corporate entity, that control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights.
Document Preview: Writer of daily newspaper feature column brought suit against corporation which contracted with him to write the column, and the sole officers, directors and shareholders of the corporation, alleging breach of contract, and against syndicator of the column, alleging tortious interference with contract.  On individual defendant's and syndicator's motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) fact questions precluded summary judgment on claim seeking to pierce corporate veil to hold individual defendants personally liable for acts of their corporation, but (2) there was no evidence to support crucial elements of writer's tortious interference claim against syndicator. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gonzales County Water Supply Corp. v. Jarzombek
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Incorporated individual's purportedly inconsistent statements about organization of his drilling business to water supply corporation with which he had contracted to drill well did not rise to level of deception and guile necessary to disregard individual's corporate form under Castleberry alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Incorporated individual's purportedly inconsistent statements about organization of his drilling business did not warrant disregard of corporate form in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: While affirmative defenses in action seeking to hold individuals and corporations jointly and severally liable for arbitration award were relevant to issue of attachment of property, they had no significance with regard to issue of alter ego status of defendant corporations for purposes of cause of action to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Company brought action seeking to hold individuals and corporations jointly and severally liable for arbitration award and moved for prejudgment order to attach real property.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) decision in an earlier case involving the same defendants, which squarely considered alleged alter ego status of particular property owning defendants was sufficient to establish alter ego status in current case; (2) there was probable cause that plaintiff had valid claim for breach of contract; and (3) where alter ego status was established and some defendants did not contest jurisdiction, jurisdiction was established over alter ego defendants who contested jurisdiction. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Prime Commercial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, alter ego doctrine invoked in cases involving fidelity insurance policies does not require piercing of corporate veil and does not require total identity of shareholders, directors and officers.
Document Preview: Insurance. under Georgia law, debtor-insured's controlling shareholder and chief executive officer was not employee, covered by employee fidelity policy, because debtor did not control shareholder's performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Williams v. Wilson
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in determining whether to disregard corporate veil in contract action, relevant consideration is whether actual fraud has been shown.
Document Preview: Purported third-party beneficiary sued magazine publisher, its affiliate, and others for breach of agreement to open and operate nightclubs.  Publisher and affiliate moved to dismiss beneficiary's petition and to dismiss cross-petitions.  Beneficiary and two defendants filed motions to remand.  The District Court, Orlando L. Garcia, J., held that: (1) publisher was not subject to specific or general jurisdiction; (2) affiliate was not subject to specific jurisdiction; and (3) remand of remaining state law claims was warranted. Motions to dismiss granted; motions to remand granted in part and denied in part. Affirmed, 95 F.3d 1149.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hilton Oil Transport v. Oil Transport Co., S.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Action of primary owner of corporation in foreclosing on his mortgage on barge which had been corporation's principal asset, after barge had been grounded and rendered valueless and with knowledge of debt to company which had chartered tug to the corporation, pending insurance claim for loss of the barge, and arbitration claim against foreign government, was not, without more, fraudulent, illegal or improper so as to justify piercing the corporate veil in suit by tug owner for charter hire.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Detention of vessel not commercial frustration of charter party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ragan v. Tri-County Excavating, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, subcontractor was "alter ego" of contractor, even though subcontractor and contractor maintained corporate formalities and there was no finding of fraud or illegality; subcontractor was part of group of family-owned companies and owned by three daughters of contractor's president and majority stockholder, subcontractor's sole function was to supply operating engineers to contractor, subcontractor was grossly undercapitalized and had never paid dividends, subcontractor's president knew little about its operations, contractor's president participated in subcontractor's hiring, surety on contractor's labor and material payment bond obtained from subcontractor indemnification for any payments surety made on bond, subcontractor failed to object to contractor's proposed plan in bankruptcy proceedings to subordinate debt to subcontractor to those of all other creditors.
Document Preview: Union and administrator of fringe benefit funds associated with union brought action against employer-subcontractor, contractor, and surety on contractor's labor and material payment bond seeking unpaid fund contributions, union dues, liquidated damages, and attorney fees.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Raymond J. Broderick, J., 1994 WL 67703, entered judgment for union and administrator, and surety appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Garth, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Court of Appeals had jurisdiction; (2) subcontractor was alter ego of contractor; (3) union was in direct contract with contractor by virtue of collective bargaining agreement with subcontractor and, thus, was not subject to bond provision requiring claimants not having direct contract to give notice within 90 days; (4) Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) did not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Alberto v. Diversified Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under federal alter ego law, finding of injustice or inequity is necessary in cases sounding in contract, but not in those sounding in tort.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Homeowners could not pierce corporate veil on developer or alter ego theory to hold parent liable for developer's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Seymore v. Lake Tahoe Cruises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Individual was not alter ego of cruise company, such that he could be subject to liability for breach of implied contract and breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing to former captain, even though individual was sole shareholder, manager, and director of company, had sole power to declare dividends for himself and sometimes used checks drawn on company's bank account to make payments for personal expenses, where individual also indicated that whenever he used corporate funds for personal purposes it was always properly documented as a dividend or loan.
Document Preview: Former cruise ship captain sued cruise company and its sole shareholder under whistleblower statute which protects seamen who report statutory or regulatory violations to Coast Guard, federal maritime law and state law.  On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Levi, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact regarding reason for captain's termination precluded summary judgment on whistleblower claim; (2) genuine issue of material fact regarding reason for captain's termination precluded summary judgment on his wrongful termination claim based on federal maritime law; but (3) no basis was shown for piercing corporate veil. Motion denied in part and granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mass v. McClenahan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, attorney's allegation that corporation's sole shareholder agreed to guarantee corporation's obligations under its employment contract with attorney did not warrant piercing corporate veil in order to hold shareholder liable for corporation's breach of employment contract, absent evidence that corporation either would not or could not itself have paid attorney.
Document Preview: Attorney, who was formerly employed by corporation as its attorney, president, and chief executive officer (CEO), sued corporation and its sole shareholder for race discrimination in contracts under §1981, conspiracy to violate civil rights under §1985, and breach of employment contract, and he brought conspiracy claim against companies owned by shareholder.  On defendants' motions for full or partial summary judgment, the District Court, Martin, J., held that: (1) §1981 extended by its terms to attorney-client relationship, and this did not impinge on corporation's First Amendment freedom of association; (2) allegations did not support inference of companies' participation in civil rights conspiracy; (3) allegations against corporation and shareholder did not satisfy conspiracy requirement for civil rights conspiracy claim; (4) fact questions as to attorney's compliance with Nevada professional...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pine Tree Associates v. Doctors' Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: It was not necessary to establish fraud in order for court to consider whether corporate veil should be pierced under alter ego doctrine in action involving contractual dispute.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Allegation of fraud not required in contract suit for piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Aronson v. Price
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Although incorporated body shop's failure to file assumed business name certificate violated statute, it was not grounds to impose personal liability on corporation's shareholder for negligence and breach of contract of corporation; statute did not provide for piercing of corporate veil as sanction for violation. West's A.I.C. 23-15-1-1, 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract and negligence, even though it failed to file assumed business name certificate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Aronson v. Price
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Although incorporated body shop's failure to file assumed business name certificate was breach of required corporate formalities, it was not in of itself grounds to impose personal liability on corporation's shareholder for negligence and breach of contract of corporation; no other factors which courts consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil were present, and corporation observed other formalities such as conducting directors and shareholders meetings, keeping records, and filing annual reports. West's A.I.C. 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract and negligence, even though it failed to file assumed business name certificate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sovereign Metal Corp. v. Ciraco
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil of parent corporation in action regarding plaintiffs' purchase of worthless securities; on motion for summary judgment, plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of complete domination of corporation by its owners with respect to securities transaction or use of that domination to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiffs, and plaintiffs' request for discovery did not make showing of likelihood that there was any such evidence.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil of parent corporation in action regarding plaintiffs' purchase of worthless securities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kolson v. Vembu
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Wisconsin courts will pierce corporate veil where equity so requires in order to enforce contract against natural persons comprising corporation; existence of corporation as separate legal entity will be disregarded, where corporate affairs are organized, controlled and conducted such that corporation has no separate existence of its own and is mere instrumentality of shareholder, and where corporate form is used to evade obligation, to gain unjust advantage or to commit injustice.
Document Preview: Lenders brought suit against corporate guarantor of underlying indebtedness and guarantor's principal for their alleged breach of guaranty agreements and fraud in connection with loans.  Plaintiffs also sought to hold corporate principal personally liable by piercing corporate veil.  On party's cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Shadur, J., Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parol evidence was not admissible to contradict express terms of continuing, absolute and unconditional guaranty; (2) corporate veil would be pierced in order to hold principal personally liable on guaranty; but (3) material questions of fact as to whether lenders justifiably relied on information contained in private placement memorandum, without taking steps to verify that information, precluded entry of summary judgment on fraud claims. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Scandlyn v. McDill Columbus Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section, at Knoxville.
Headnote: Two corporations that owned and managed resort were alter egos and so were both liable for breach of contract to lot owners; corporations utilized same personnel, same individual who was president and chief financial officer of one corporation was president, sole director, and sole shareholder of other corporation, corporations commingled funds, one corporation was undercapitalized, and corporations failed to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Property Maintenance. Resort management corporations breached contract with lot owners to provide utilities and maintenance services.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Schafir v. Harrigan
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold corporation's vice president and director liable for defects in home constructed by corporation was not warranted, where corporation observed requisite formalities, and recognition of corporate form did not sanction a fraud.
Document Preview: Purchasers of home brought action against vendors, real estate agent, and builder, seeking damages for alleged design and construction defects.  The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Michael R. Murphy, J., entered judgment in favor of defendants and purchasers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Greenwood, J., held that: (1) home purchasers could not recover their economic losses based on latent defects caused by allegedly negligent construction of their residence; (2) home purchasers could not recover economic losses from builder under strict liability theory; (3) real estate agent could not be held liable to purchasers for failing to disclose that water pipes that had burst and had been repaired did not conform to existing building and plumbing codes; and (4) merger doctrine barred purchasers from recovering for vendors' alleged breach of warranty contained in earnest money sales agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: De Leonardis v. Subway Sandwich Shops, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Alter ego theory is applicable in contract actions as well as in tort actions.
Document Preview: Landlord brought action for breach of commercial lease against corporate tenant and company which was allegedly tenant's alter ego.  Action was referred to attorney state trial referee, Hanon W. Russell, J., who filed report recommending judgment against tenant, and landlord filed objections and exceptions.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Ansonia-Milford, Jones, J., overruled landlord's exceptions to referee's report and rendered judgment in accordance with report, and landlord appealed.  The Appellate Court, Frederick A. Freedman, J., held that referee erred in granting motion in limine precluding landlord from presenting evidence regarding relationship between tenant and company so as to pierce the corporate veil. Reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U.S. for Use and Benefit of Skip Kirchdorfer, Inc. v. Aegis/Zublin Joint Venture
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, so as to allow subcontractor which had entered into contract with a joint venture, to sue joint venture partner which had assigned contract to its subsidiary; subcontractor had failed to assert what level of capitalization would have been appropriate for subsidiary, and it failed to show assignment, accomplished with subcontractor's consent, had been done with fraudulent intent.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought suit against contractor, its joint venture partner and Miller Act surety, seeking to enforce arbitration award in its favor in connection with excess cost claim for work done on military housing in Cuba. The District Court, MacKenzie, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) Federal Arbitration Act provision calling for enforcement of arbitration award in federal district in which arbitration award was entered, was permissive rather than mandatory; (2) arbitrator's decision was not irrational; and (3) award was enforceable against surety, even though surety claimed some components of award may have been items not recoverable under Miller Act. Award confirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Campo v. 1st Nationwide Bank
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To prevail in breach of contract action under alter ego theory of liability under New York law against corporation whose subsidiaries dealt with residential subdivision developer, developer had to establish that corporation, through its domination of subsidiaries, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: Residential subdivision developer brought action against entities that had agreed to finance purchase of property and to fund construction projects and their parent bank, alleging breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty, and tortious interference with business and contract relationships.  Defendants moved to dismiss complaint, and developer moved to amend complaint.  The District Court, Bartels, J., held that: (1) developer stated action for breach of contract under New York law against entities; (2) developer stated cause of action for breach of contract against bank under alter ego theory; and (3) developer alleged requisite elements of joint venture under New York law so as to state cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty. Motion to dismiss denied, motion to amend complaint granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Garner v. Hoffman
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Upon termination of plastic surgery agreement between two professional corporations, there was no basis to hold one plastic surgeon personally liable on theory he treated corporation as his "alter ego"; there was nothing to suggest funds were commingled or corporate formalities were ignored.
Document Preview: Contracts. Purchaser of interest in office building failed to prove promise sufficient to justify reliance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weinreich v. Sandhaus
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veils were pierced to impose joint and several liability upon owner and sibling corporation for breach of agreement to share profits from laser light show given that owner was in total control of both corporation that entered agreement and sibling to which ownership of light equipment was transferred, owner used stationery of one corporation to write letter on behalf of the other, sibling corporation's advertising literature indicated that it was an affiliate of the corporation that entered agreement, two corporate entities did not deal with each other at arms length, and corporation that signed agreement had remained dormant for years.
Document Preview: Party which collaborated in developing laser light show systems brought suit for compensation.  Following bench trial, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that, under New York law: (1) letter among collaborators was preliminary binding agreement to share profits; (2) owner's control and domination of corporations justified piercing veil; (3) plaintiff's work on system was sufficient to entitle him to recovery of profits under agreement; and (5) plaintiff was entitled to quantum meruit recovery for work performed on other projects. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Warnaco Inc. v. VF Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation that negotiates contract but has subsidiary sign it can be held liable as party to contract, if subsidiary is dummy for parent corporation.
Document Preview: U.S. trademark licensor brought action against Spanish licensee and U.S. parent of purchaser of licensee under Lanham Act and state law based on conduct allegedly violative of license termination agreement.  On motions to dismiss, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) allegations were sufficient to support claim that parent was bound by agreement; (2) claims arose under termination agreement for purposes of its forum selection clause; (3) allegations were sufficient to warrant extraterritorial application of Lanham Act; (4) New York law rather than Spanish or Portugese law applied to unfair competition claims; (5) licensor stated claim under New York statute based on allegations of likelihood of injury to business reputation; and (6) licensor did not state claim under New York law for prima facie tort. Motion to dismiss granted in part, denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Warnaco Inc. v. VF Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation may be liable on contract signed by subsidiary if subsidiary is shown to be mere shell dominated and controlled by parent for parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: U.S. trademark licensor brought action against Spanish licensee and U.S. parent of purchaser of licensee under Lanham Act and state law based on conduct allegedly violative of license termination agreement.  On motions to dismiss, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) allegations were sufficient to support claim that parent was bound by agreement; (2) claims arose under termination agreement for purposes of its forum selection clause; (3) allegations were sufficient to warrant extraterritorial application of Lanham Act; (4) New York law rather than Spanish or Portugese law applied to unfair competition claims; (5) licensor stated claim under New York statute based on allegations of likelihood of injury to business reputation; and (6) licensor did not state claim under New York law for prima facie tort. Motion to dismiss granted in part, denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: New York Ass'n for Retarded Children, Inc., Montgomery County Chapter v. Keator
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Absent allegation of fraud or illegality, or proof that shareholder used his asserted control of corporation to commit any wrongdoing, corporate veil could not be pierced to hold shareholder liable for corporation's breach of manufacturing contract.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. President of corporation was not liable for corporation's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Innkeepers' Telemanagement and Equipment Corp. v. Hummert Management Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate veil could not be pierced in order to hold hotel management companies liable for hotels' alleged breach of their contracts with telecommunications company, though principal officers of management companies were also part owners of hotels, and though management companies had represented themselves to telecommunications company as entities responsible for operation of hotels.
Document Preview: Telecommunications services company brought suit against hotels and hotel management companies for their alleged breach of contract.  The District Court, Aspen, J., held that telecommunications company was collaterally estopped from denying that it had breached its contracts with hotels based on judgment previously entered against it by bankruptcy court at trial of bankrupt hotel's objection to company's claim. Partial summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Oregon RSA No. 6, Inc. v. Castle Rock Cellular of Oregon Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Corporate structure may not be used to avoid contractual obligations and defeat legitimate expectations of other parties under Oregon law.
Document Preview: Limited partner brought action against another limited partner being sold, its parent corporations, and buyer to establish right of first refusal to purchase limited partner's interest.  Plaintiff moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Panner, J., held that: (1) sale of limited partner without offering right of first refusal to plaintiff violated covenant of good faith and fair dealing implied in limited partnership agreement, and (2) limited partner and its parent corporations could be treated as single entity so that parent corporation was subject to plaintiff's right to first refusal. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: St. Katherine Ins. Co. Ltd. v. Insurance Co. of North America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, unless there was evidence to suggest that separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary was illusory and that they were not dealing at arms-length, but were, in effect, abusing corporate form, corporate form ought not to be disregarded in determining coverage under general liability policy's completed operations hazard clause for injuries sustained by parent's employee on completed operation built by subsidiary on parent's property.
Document Preview: Umbrella insurers brought diversity action against general liability insurer and insureds, seeking declaration that loss was not a completed operations hazard loss under general liability policy.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Harry D. Leinenweber, J., entered judgment for defendants, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that loss resulting from fall by employee of parent corporation into sulphur pit built by subsidiary on parent's property was completed operations hazard loss covered by general liability policy insuring both parent and subsidiary. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Ripple, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion and would grant petition for rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wilson v. DelPapa
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Attachment of individual's property in suit for breach of contract to sell business operated by corporation was not improper act of corporate veil piercing; given evidence that individual appeared to be acting in his personal capacity in bargaining with buyers, it was reasonable for court to infer, for purposes of attachment motion, that individual was either acting in his own behalf or on behalf of corporation as undisclosed corporate principal.
Document Preview: In suit for breach of contract, order of attachment was entered by the Superior Court, Hancock County, Mead, J., and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Clifford, J., held that: (1) given ample competent evidence supporting finding as to plaintiffs' likelihood of success, order would not be disturbed even though plaintiffs made certain factual assertions at hearing going beyond the affidavits; (2) underlying contract was not barred by the statute of frauds; and (3) there was sufficient evidence for trial court to have been convinced that it was more likely than not that plaintiffs would recover at least the $150,000 amount attached. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mills v. USA Mobile Communications, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Because contract with corporation is contract with that legal entity and not with individual shareholders, courts are even more reluctant to disregard corporate entity when dispute involves contract as opposed to tort. Code, 31-1-89.
Document Preview: Seller of corporation brought suit against purchasing corporation and its shareholders.  The Circuit Court, Mingo County, Elliott E. Maynard, J., granted summary judgment for all defendants except selling corporation and its representative, and struck damages to be awarded for malicious prosecution. Seller appealed.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Miller, J., held that seller failed to show the type of conduct by shareholders of purchasing corporation necessary to warrant imposing shareholder liability on verdict against corporation, though there may have been inflated promises made to seller. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mills v. USA Mobile Communications, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced if complaining party demonstrates some frustration of contractual expectations regarding party to whom he looked for performance, flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by defendant corporation and its principals, or fraud or other equivalent malfeasance on part of corporate shareholder. Code, 31-1-89.
Document Preview: Seller of corporation brought suit against purchasing corporation and its shareholders.  The Circuit Court, Mingo County, Elliott E. Maynard, J., granted summary judgment for all defendants except selling corporation and its representative, and struck damages to be awarded for malicious prosecution. Seller appealed.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Miller, J., held that seller failed to show the type of conduct by shareholders of purchasing corporation necessary to warrant imposing shareholder liability on verdict against corporation, though there may have been inflated promises made to seller. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Capital Parks, Inc. v. Southeastern Advertising & Sales System, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Waco Division.
Headnote: Veil of corporation would not be pierced to hold one shareholder liable with respect to shareholders' sale of their stock to third party, despite plaintiff's claim that such sale violated plaintiff's right of first refusal with respect to purchase of corporation's subsidiary; plaintiff's option contract bound only corporation and plaintiff, not corporation's shareholders, offer to purchase stock and assets of corporation did not violate option contract, which was only triggered by bona fide offer to purchase subsidiary, and, because corporation would be merged into purchaser, right of first refusal would continue to be liability binding upon purchaser.
Document Preview: Optionee sued corporation for specific performance of agreement granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of corporation's subsidiary.  Corporation moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., held that offer to purchase corporation's stock did not violate optionee's right of first refusal. Motion granted. Affirmed 30 F.3d 627.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Capital Parks, Inc. v. Southeastern Advertising & Sales System, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Waco Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, optionee, which sought specific performance of agreement with parent corporation granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of subsidiary corporation, failed to establish that subsidiary corporation was alter ego of parent, as required to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary, so that offer to purchase stock and assets of parent was not offer to purchase stock and assets of subsidiary; contract was binding only upon parent, and there was no evidence that any of parent's shareholders created parent as corporate fiction to avoid any liability under contract.
Document Preview: Optionee sued corporation for specific performance of agreement granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of corporation's subsidiary.  Corporation moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., held that offer to purchase corporation's stock did not violate optionee's right of first refusal. Motion granted. Affirmed 30 F.3d 627.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Weiss Bros., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Individuals signing covenant not to compete ancillary to franchise agreement on behalf of their corporation were personally bound by covenant; enforcement against individuals was required to protect legitimate interests of franchisor, since corporation was essentially alter ego of individuals.
Document Preview: Quick-lube franchisor brought motion for preliminary injunction to prevent franchisee from using its trademarks or violating noncompetition agreement after franchise agreement was terminated for underreported sales figures.  The District Court, Irenas, J., held that: (1) New Jersey Franchise Practices Act applied based on franchisee's place of business within state, and its gross sales exceeding $35,000, more than 20% of which were derived from franchise; (2) franchisor had good cause for terminating agreement; (3) franchisor was entitled to preliminary injunction to prevent franchisee from using its trademarks; and (4) covenant not to compete was enforceable, subject to further temporal and geographic limitations. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Franchisee which had obtained arbitration award against franchisor was entitled to pierce corporate veil and collect judgment from franchisor's parent corporation where, at time of breach, franchisor had observed no corporate formalities for at least two years, had no assets or paid employees or functioning board of directors, and its operations and assets had been absorbed into the parent and where the action which breached the franchise agreement was taken in name of the parent and not the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Greater Kansas City Roofing
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Showing of inequity necessary to satisfy the second prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil must flow from the misuse of the corporate form, and mere fact that corporation commits unfair labor practice, breaches a contract or commits a tort does mean individual shareholders of corporation should personally be liable.
Document Preview: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) brought action seeking enforcement of supplemental order holding individual shareholder as well as successor corporation liable for unfair labor practice judgment.  The Court of Appeals, Ebel, Circuit Judge, held that NLRB was not entitled to pierce corporate veil even though shareholder disregarded corporate employer as separate entity, absent evidence that shareholder used corporate structure to promote fraud or that disregard of independent corporate existence led to injustice or evasion of legal obligations. Enforcement denied as to shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Matter of Sims
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In absence of fraud, alter ego doctrine is inapplicable to case in which corporations' claims sound in contract rather than tort.
Document Preview: Related corporations filed involuntary bankruptcy petitions against debtors.  The Bankruptcy Court granted relief, and appeal was taken.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Charles Schwartz, Jr., J., reversed, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Barksdale, Circuit Judge, held that separate identity of corporations affiliated with fast-food franchisor would not be disregarded, for purposes of determining number of creditors filing involuntary bankruptcy petition. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Statesville Stained Glass, Inc. v. T.E. Lane Const. & Supply Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: In contract action, corporate entities of dissolved corporation and newly formed corporation, which had common sole shareholder, were not disregarded and sole shareholder was not held individually liable on dissolved corporation's contract, as there was no evidence that shareholder was party to contract, that shareholder used dissolved corporation to conduct personal business or for personal profit, or that shareholder used dissolved corporation to defraud plaintiff, and plaintiff did not contract with newly formed corporation.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate entities of dissolved corporation and newly formed corporation were not disregarded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund Detroit and Vicinity v. Lange
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego is treated as single continuous employer, and contractual obligations of one element of alter ego are binding on the others.
