Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Manchester Hides, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Iowa.
Headnote: Corporation and wholly owned subsidiary were two separate and distinct entities and thus an offset agreement signed by one in favor of debtor was not effective against the other corporation in the absence of evidence that subsidiary was undercapitalized, and corporation and subsidiary kept separate books and separate finances; there was no evidence indicating that subsidiary did not follow corporate formalities, and subsidiary was formed to take advantage of favorable domestic international sales corporations regulations, not to promote fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: Trustee filed turnover complaint.  The Bankruptcy Court, William W. Thinnes, J., held that: (1) subsidiary corporation did not misrepresent character of its business relation with debtor in a no offset agreement; (2) even if there was misrepresentation with respect to character of business transaction between a subsidiary and debtor where no offset agreement was signed, misrepresentation was not material; and (3) creditor was entitled to set off amounts owed debtor. Ordered accordingly. Sell also Bkrtcy., 32 B.R. 629.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tennessee Valley Authority v. Exxon Nuclear Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent corporation will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Supplier of uranium fuel and its parent company appealed from order entered by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert L. Taylor, Chief Judge, 570 F.Supp. 462, granting summary judgment in favor of Tennessee Valley Authority, reversing decision of the TVA Board of Contract Appeals, which held TVA liable on contract for one half of parent company's increased costs in producing uranium fuel.  The Court of Appeals, Gilmore, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that parent company was not entitled to compensation for increased production costs in accordance with special conditions contained in contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Huebner v. Sales Promotion, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: In action for damages and rescission of partnership agreement which was a franchise, trial court did not err in piercing corporate veil and asserting personal jurisdiction over individual defendants who made personal contacts in state sufficient for exercise of jurisdiction over them; the court did not assert personal jurisdiction over them merely because they worked for a corporation subject to Washington jurisdiction. U.S.C.A. Const.Amends. 5, 14.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and others for rescission of partnership agreement and damages.  It was alleged that the agreement violated Washington's Franchise Investment Protection Act.  The Superior Court, Thurston County, Orris L. Hamilton, J., entered summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Worswick, J., held that: (1) the partnership agreement was a franchise where corporation granted individual a license to use its trademark; (2) corporation had notice that it was subject to suit in Washington; and (3) trial court did not err in asserting jurisdiction over the individual defendants, as they were responsible for advertisements in Washington which led to signing of partnership agreement, and as they offered and negotiated other agreements with Washington residents. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hogan v. Mayor & Aldermen of Savannah
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Person who was corporate officer and shareholder brought action against the corporation's uninsured motorist insurer to recover damages for injuries sustained in accident which occurred while he was riding in police car to retrieve apparently impounded company vehicle.  The Superior Court, Chatham County, Oliver, J., granted summary judgment in favor of the insurer, and the corporate officer and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, C.J., held that: (1) the policy did not provide coverage for the plaintiff, who was not a named insured under the policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to view plaintiff as the named insured; and (3) statutory definition of insured as including the personal representative of any of the above did not provide coverage for the corporate officer and shareholder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sicilia Di R. Biebow & Co. v. Cox
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where neither shareholder of corporation which imported citrus juice nor corporation formed by shareholder to market citrus juice in similarly shaped bottle were a party to the importation-distribution contract, for them to be liable under any breach of noncompete provisions of that contract, it was incumbent on the foreign seller to establish those compelling circumstances as would justify piercing the corporate veil to prevent fraud or other inequity and such showing was lacking where corporate formalities were followed and the importing corporation sold the product to the shareholders' corporation at a profit.
Document Preview: Trade dress infringement case was brought based on defendants' copying of plaintiff's design for citrus juice bottles.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert M. Hill, J., dismissed, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Reavley, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court incorrectly applied doctrine of functionality and, hence, its finding that plaintiff's bottle design was not distinctive could not be upheld, and (2) finding that defendant had no intent to infringe plaintiff's trade dress was clearly erroneous.  In addition, the court set forth the law as to the meaning and application of doctrine of functionality. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action it must be shown that the subsidiary was used by the parent for fraud or injustice and it is not alone sufficient to show that subsidiary is a mere agent or conduit of the parent; declining to follow Jetty, Inc. v. Hall McGuff Architects, 595 S.W.2d 918 and National Marine Service, Inc. v. C.J. Thibodeaux & Co., 501 F.2d 940.
Document Preview: Creditor of partnership in which wholly owned subsidiary was general partner sued the parent corporation to recover amount due and unpaid for supplies furnished the partnership.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Walter Ely, J., sitting by designation, rendered judgment against creditor, and it appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 700 F.2d 994, reversed and remanded.  On petition for rehearing, the Court of Appeals, 713 F.2d 139, held that subsidiary was a mere sham entity.  Rehearing en banc was granted, 715 F.2d 157.  The Court of Appeals, en banc, Randall, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, a showing of fraud or injustice is required to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action and that no such showing was made, and (2) in any event, subsidiary could not be properly characterized as nothing more than a piece of paper lying in a file cabinet. Judgment of District Court affirmed. Alvin B....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carroll v. Smith-Henry, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: That parent and subsidiary corporations share common officers or directors does not by itself impose liability on parent for contracts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former employee brought breach of employment contract action.  The Common Pleas Court, Greenville County, Frank Eppes, J., entered judgment in his favor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Goolsby, J., held that allegations contained in complaint and answer placed before trial court issue of whether employee was employed during relevant period by parent corporation or its subsidiary; therefore, trial court erred in refusing parent corporation's requested instruction which related to issue of a parent corporation's liability for a subsidiary's contracts, and that error was reversible, as jury might well have concluded in its absence that a parent corporation is always liable on its subsidiary's contracts. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: E.C.A. Environmental Management Services, Inc. v. Toenyes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Even if fertilizer spreading contract technically bound subsidiary, rather than parent corporation, where parent owned 100% of capital stock of subsidiary, virtually all corporate formalities were abandoned by subsidiary prior to execution of contract, all directors of subsidiary were also directors of parent, it was in course of meeting of board of directors of parent that fertilizer spreading agreement was initially proposed, and subsidiary's operations were financed by parents, subsidiary was alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Fertilizer spreading business gave demand promissory note in amount of $7,000 plus interest at 11 1/212 percent in exchange for loan on that amount.  Additionally, it purchased $1,062 worth of diesel fuel on credit.  Holder of note brought action to recover amount due on promissory note and its subsidiary filed suit to recover amount owed for diesel fuel.  Fertilizer business counterclaimed for breach of commercial contract.  The District Court, Eighth Judicial District, in and for Parish of Cascade, Joel G. Roth, J., entered judgment in favor of fertilizer spreading business, and appeals were taken. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: E.C.A. Environmental Management Services, Inc. v. Toenyes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Where after expiration of fertilizer contract entered into by subsidiary, parent transferred assets of subsidiary to its own books in parcel cancellation of debt, subsidiary effectively ceased business, and consequently, had no assets from which to satisfy judgment for breach of contract, parent could not escape contractual liability by asserting it was not personally liable for obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: NCR Credit Corp. v. Underground Camera, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Where subsidiary was presented to defendant as subsidiary that would finance sales contract and the subsidiary's actions were consistent with that role, while parent was the corporation whose representatives negotiated sales contract, whose system was purchased and installed and whose personnel serviced system, the parent corporation was proper party for plaintiff to sue upon complaint centering dissatisfaction with system purchased and not with financing program, and case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard.
Document Preview: In a suit for money allegedly due and unpaid on a computer sales contract, and on various motions, the District Court, Caffrey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) point charging that defendants conspired to defraud plaintiff to its great harm and detriment was insufficient to inform opposing party of nature of the conspiracy charged; (2) case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard; (3) court having declined to treat parent manufacturer and financing subsidiary corporation as same entity, it was found that subsidiary did not waive parent's right to arbitrate by filing suit in federal court, and where outcome of arbitration might dispose of some or all claims outstanding, proceedings in the court between plaintiff buyer and financing subsidiary would also be stayed pending outcome of arbitration; and (4) description of pending case in news weekly was unlikely to interfere with any litigant's right to fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Tennessee Pools and Recreation, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of contracting company which entered into contract with debtor containing noncompetition agreement and, debtor having done nothing to breach contract containing the noncompetition agreement, corporation and its principals were liable for violation of the agreement.
Document Preview: Debtor brought action against corporation and its principals for breach of noncompetition agreement.  The Bankruptcy Court, George C. Paine, II, J., held that: (1) corporation was alter ego of contracting company which entered into contract containing noncompetition agreement and, debtor having done nothing to breach contract containing the noncompetition agreement, corporation and its principals were liable for violation of the agreement; (2) in light of defendants' flagrant violation of the noncompetition agreement, counterclaim for procuring breach of contract for construction of swimming pool would be dismissed; and (3) debtor was entitled to nominal damages of $10 against corporation, as well as punitive damage award of $2,500 each against corporation and its principals. Judgment for plaintiff; counterclaim and third-party complaint dismissed.
